posts.title: Data centers in space makes no sense
posts.author: ajyoon
posts.title_cn: 太空数据中心毫无意义
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕“太空数据中心是否可行”展开，多数用户认为这一想法缺乏实际意义。核心争议点集中在冷却、成本与延迟问题上。有用户指出，太空是真空环境，散热只能依赖辐射，效率极低，且需要巨大散热器，而将设备送入太空的成本极高。也有用户提到，即使不考虑冷却，数据中心的轨道运行会导致网络延迟大幅波动，不适合对延迟敏感的应用。讨论中部分人认为，该想法可能源于科幻作品的启发，而非实际工程考量。尽管有用户提出在月球建立数据中心或利用太空能源等设想，但普遍共识是，当前技术下太空数据中心在成本、散热和实用性方面均不具可行性。

comments.author: beloch
comments.content: I would not assume cooling has been worked out.Space is a vacuum.  i.e. The lack-of-a-thing that makes a thermos great at keeping your drink hot.  A satellite is, if nothing else, a fantastic thermos.  A data center in space would necessarily rely completely on cooling by radiation, unlike a terrestrial data center that can make use of convection and conduction. You can't just pipe heat out into the atmosphere or build a heat exchanger. You can't exchange heat with vacuum.  You can only radiate heat into it.Heat is going to limit the compute that can be done in a satellite data centre and radiative cooling solutions are going to massively increase weight. It makes far more sense to build data centers in the arctic.Musk is up to something here.  This could be another hyperloop (i.e. A distracting promise meant to sabotage competition).  It could be a legal dodge.  It could be a power grab.  What it will not be is a useful source of computing power.  Anyone who takes this venture seriously is probably going to be burned.
comments.content_cn:
我不认为散热问题已经解决。太空是真空环境，这种"无物质"特性正是保温杯能保持饮品温度的关键。卫星本质上就是一个超级保温杯。与能利用对流和传导散热的地面数据中心不同，太空数据中心必须完全依赖辐射冷却。你无法简单地将热量导入大气层或建造热交换器，真空环境无法进行热交换，只能通过辐射散热。

热量将严重限制卫星数据中心的计算能力，而辐射冷却方案会大幅增加设备重量。在北极建设数据中心远比这合理得多。

马斯克此举必有深意。这可能像超级高铁那样（即用分散注意力的承诺来破坏竞争），可能是法律规避手段，也可能是权力争夺。但绝不可能是实用的计算资源。任何认真对待这个项目的人都可能遭受损失。

comments.author: 2001zhaozhao
comments.content: I was gonna say it is good for low-ping game servers, but then I remembered that the data center would literally be orbiting around the planet and ping would fluctuate by tens of milliseconds every few minutes.
comments.content_cn: 我本想夸它适合低延迟游戏服务器，但转念一想数据中心可是绕着地球轨道运行，延迟每隔几分钟就会波动几十毫秒。

comments.author: Terr_
comments.content: I'm convinced that >30% of this comes from ideas leaking out of fiction such as like Neuromancer, and percolating through the minds of wealthy people attracted to some of the concepts. Namely, the dream of being a hyper-wealthy dynasty, above any earthly government, controlling an extraterritorial Las Vegas Fiefdom In Space. (Which in the book, also hosted a powerful AI.)Then they work backwards, trying to figure out some economic engine to make it happen. "Data centers" are (A) in-vogue for investment right now and (B) vaguely plausible, at least compared to having a space-casino.
comments.content_cn: 我确信这其中超过30%的灵感来源于《神经漫游者》这类科幻作品的理念渗透，它们吸引了部分富豪对这些概念的关注。具体来说，是那种成为超级财富王朝的梦想——凌驾于任何世俗政府之上，掌控一个太空中的域外拉斯维加斯式领地（书中该领地还承载着一个强大的人工智能）。随后他们逆向推导，试图找出某种经济引擎来实现这一愿景。“数据中心”目前（A）正成为投资热点，且（B）至少相较于运营太空赌场，其可行性显得略微可信。

comments.author: elamje
comments.content: I was talking to someone about this the other day. I was part of a team at NASA that developed a cooling system for the ISS and this whole premise makes no sense to me.1. Getting things to space is incredibly expensive2. Ingress/egress are almost always a major bottleneck - how is bandwidth cheaper in space?3. Chips must be “Rad-hard” - that is do more error correcting from ionizing radiation - there were entire teams at NASA dedicated to special hardware for this.4. Gravity and atmospheric pressure actually do wonders for easy cooling. Heat is not dissipated in space like we are all used to and you must burn additional energy trying to move the heat generated away from source.5. Energy production will be cheaper from earth due to mass manufacturing of necessary components in energy systems - space energy systems need novel technology where economies of scale are lost.Would love for someone to make the case for why it actually makes total sense, because it’s really hard to see for me!
comments.content_cn: 前几天我还和人讨论过这个话题。我曾在美国宇航局参与开发国际空间站冷却系统的团队，所以这个设想在我看来完全站不住脚。1. 将物品送入太空的成本极其高昂；2. 进出通道几乎总是主要瓶颈——太空中的带宽怎么可能更便宜？3. 芯片必须经过"抗辐射加固"——即需要更强的电离辐射纠错能力，美国宇航局曾有专门团队为此研发特殊硬件；4. 重力和大气压力其实对散热大有裨益，热量在太空中的散发方式与我们习惯的完全不同，必须消耗额外能量才能将产生的热量从源头移走；5. 由于能源系统所需组件在地球上能大规模生产，地球的能源生产成本会更低——太空能源系统需要新技术，但无法形成规模经济。很希望有人能论证这个设想的合理性，因为在我看来实在难以理解！

comments.author: yawniek
comments.content:
I think what many people miss is that energy became far less location dependent if you put compute next to its generation.
The latency for token generation is not so important. So the ratios between energy consumed, bandwidth and latency would in theory favour building dark token factories in remote but optimal locations. But i guess construction and logistics are an issue.
comments.content_cn: 我认为许多人忽略的一点是，如果将计算设备部署在能源产生地附近，能源对地理位置的依赖就会大大降低。生成令牌的延迟并不那么重要。因此，从理论上讲，能源消耗、带宽和延迟之间的比例关系会倾向于在偏远但条件优越的地点建立隐蔽的令牌工厂。不过，我猜建设和物流会是问题所在。

comments.author: stevep98
comments.content: Surely, the question is: how big do the radiators have to be?gemini says that the NVIDIA DGX H100 is 130kg and takes 11kW.It says space-based radiators in the 100kW range are approx 15kg per kW. And space-based solar panels are approx 1kg per kW.So let's says we're talking about 1 system that bundles 9 DGX H100's. That's 1.2T for the computing system,  1.5T for the radiator, 100kg for the solar panels, and let's say 2T for the propulsion, propellant, guidance, and all the other spacecraft stuff.   That's a total of about 5T, and the radiator is just about 20% of the mass budget.The power radiated is proportional to the 4th power of the temperature, so they would be incentivized to develop a heat exchanger with a high temperature working fluid.
comments.content_cn:
问题显然在于：散热器需要多大？Gemini提到英伟达DGX H100重130公斤，功耗11千瓦。  
据称太空中使用的百千瓦级散热器每千瓦约重15公斤，而太空太阳能电池板每千瓦约重1公斤。  
假设我们讨论的是集成9台DGX H100的系统。计算系统重1.2吨，散热器重1.5吨，太阳能电池板重100公斤，推进系统、燃料、导航及其他航天设备按2吨估算。  
总重约5吨，其中散热器质量占比约20%。  
辐射功率与温度的四次方成正比，因此开发采用高温工作流体的热交换器将具有显著优势。

comments.author: bs7280
comments.content: As a thought experiment, if humanity wanted to go all in on trying to move industrial processes and data centers off planet, would it make more sense to do so on the moon?The moon has:- Some water- Some materials that can be used to manufacture crude things (like heat sinks?)- a ton of area to brute force the heat sink problem- a surface to burry the data centers under to solve the radiation problem- close enough to earth that remote controlled semi-automated robots workI think this would only work if some powerful entity wanted to commit to a hyper-scale effort.
comments.content_cn:
作为一个思想实验，如果人类想要全力尝试将工业流程和数据中心移出地球，选择在月球上进行是否更合理？月球具备以下条件：
- 存在一定水资源
- 拥有可用于制造基础设备（如散热器？）的原材料
- 广阔面积可暴力解决散热问题
- 可通过在表层掩埋数据中心来解决辐射问题
- 距离地球足够近，便于远程控制半自动机器人运作
我认为这只有在某个强大实体愿意投入超大规模资源时才可能实现。

comments.author: lancewiggs
comments.content: It's exiting the 5th best social network and the 10th (or worse) best AI company and selling them to a decent company.It probably increases Elon's share of the combined entity.It delivers on a promise to investors that he will make money for them, even as the underlying businesses are lousy.
comments.content_cn: 它正在剥离第五大社交网络和第十（或更差）大人工智能公司，并将其出售给一家体面的企业。这可能会增加埃隆在合并后实体中的持股比例。此举兑现了他对投资者的承诺，即会为他们赚钱，尽管其基础业务表现糟糕。

comments.author: dathinab
comments.content: The really crazy thing is you don't need to know more then basic (non Hollywood) physics to know how dump this is1. every gram you need to send to space is costly, a issue you don't have at ground level2. cooling is a catastrophe, sure space is cold, but also a vacuum, so the cooling rate is roughly the infrared radiation rate. This means if you are not careful with the surface of a satellite it can end up being very slowly cooked by sunlight alone not including running any higher heat producing component (as it absorbs more heat from sunlight then it emits, there is a reason satellites are mostly white, silver or reflective gold in color). Sure better surface materials fix that, but not to a point where you would want to run any heavy compute on it.3. zero repair-ability, most long running satellites have a lot of redundancy. Also at least if you are bulk buying Nvidea GPGPUs on single digit Million Euro basis it's not rare that 30% have some level of defect. Not necessary "fully broken" but "performs less good then it should/compared to other units" kind of broken.4. radiation/solar wind protections are a huge problem. Heck even if you run things on earth it's a problem as long as your operations scale is large enough. In space things are magnitudes worse.5. every rocket lunch causes atmospheric damage, so does every satellite evaporating on re-entry. That wasn't that relevant in the past, but might become a problem just for keeping stuff like Starlink running. We don't need to make it worse by putting datacenters into space.6. Kessler Syndrom is real and could seriously hurt humanity as a whole, no reason to make it much more likely by putting things into space which don't need to go there.Last but not least, wtf would you even want to do it?There is zero benefit, non nada.
comments.content_cn: 真正疯狂的是，你只需要懂基础（非好莱坞式）物理就能明白这有多蠢。1. 每克送上太空的物质都代价高昂，这是地面不存在的问题。2. 散热简直是灾难——太空确实寒冷，但也是真空环境，冷却速率基本取决于红外辐射率。这意味着如果卫星表面处理不当，仅靠阳光照射就可能让它慢慢"被烤熟"，这还不包括运行任何高发热元件（因为吸收的阳光热量远大于散发热量，这就是卫星多为白色、银色或反光金色的原因）。更好的表面材料确实能缓解问题，但远不足以支持在上面进行高强度计算。3. 完全无法维修——多数长期运行的卫星都依赖大量冗余设计。更何况，即使在地面批量采购价值数百万欧元的英伟达GPU，30%存在某种缺陷也很常见，不一定是"完全损坏"，而是"性能低于应有水平/相比其他单元更差"的故障。4. 辐射/太阳风防护是巨大难题。说实话，即使在地面运行，只要规模够大这都是问题，而在太空环境会恶劣数个量级。5. 每次火箭发射都会造成大气层破坏，每颗卫星再入烧毁同样如此。过去这或许不重要，但光是维持星链这类系统运行就可能引发新问题。我们不需要……

comments.author: lambdaone
comments.content: The thing I find most notable is the lack of any concrete information on how these things are to be cooled, other than quotes like "space cooling is free".If you want to radiate away the heat, you are either limited by the Stefan-Boltzmann equation which requires extraordinarily large radiators at any reasonable operating temperature, or have to develop a "super-Planckian" radiator technology, something which while it may be theoretically possible doesn't seem to actually exist yet as a practical technology.The only other plausible technology I can think of would be to use evaporative or sublimation-based cooling, but that would consume vast quantities of mass in the process, every bit of which would have to be delivered to space first.Has anyone seen any published work that suggests it is actually anywhere near economically feasible to dissipate megawatts of power in space, using either these or any other technology?
comments.content_cn: 我认为最值得注意的一点是，除了“太空冷却免费”这类说法外，没有任何关于如何冷却这些设备的具体信息。如果想要通过辐射散热，要么受限于斯特藩-玻尔兹曼定律，这要求在合理的工作温度下使用极其庞大的散热器；要么必须开发“超普朗克”散热技术，这种技术虽然在理论上可能，但似乎尚未成为实用技术。我能想到的其他可行技术只有基于蒸发或升华的冷却方式，但这会消耗大量物质，且每一份物质都必须先运送到太空。有没有人见过任何已发表的研究表明，无论是通过这些技术还是其他技术，在太空中消散兆瓦级功率实际上具有经济可行性？

comments.author: devin
comments.content: As long as we're pointing out things that don't make sense: A long time ago in the United States we decided to run electricity _everywhere_, even farmhouses in the middle of nowhere. The solution to broadband in the United States is somehow, inexplicably "Let's use satellites" rather than increase tower coverage or run hard lines. It is a _terrible_ solution to this problem based on the cost alone.
comments.content_cn: 既然要指出不合理之处：很久以前美国就决定把电力通到每个角落，连偏远地区的农舍都不例外。然而解决宽带问题的方案却莫名其妙地变成了“用卫星通信”，而不是增加基站覆盖或铺设有线网络。单从成本考虑，这根本是个糟糕透顶的解决方案。

comments.author: antonymoose
comments.content: To Steelman the topic, Musk’s whole alleged mission is to make humans a multi-planet species that can survive an earth killing event.To that end, a small data center space isn’t about unit-economics, it’s a bigger mission. So the question we should consider is what can we put into space the further that mission. Can we put a meaningful sum of human knowledge out there for preservation? It sounds like “yes,” even if we can’t train ChatGPT models out there yet.
comments.content_cn: 为强化这一论点，马斯克宣称的整个使命是让人类成为多行星物种，以应对地球毁灭事件。为此，在太空建立小型数据中心并非出于单位经济效益，而是更宏大的使命。因此，我们应考虑的是，如何通过太空部署进一步推动这一使命。我们能否将大量有意义的人类知识送入太空保存？答案似乎是肯定的，即便目前我们还无法在那里训练ChatGPT模型。

comments.author: Starman_Jones
comments.content: Very confused by this plan. Data centers on Earth are struggling with how to get rid of waste heat. It's really, really hard to get rid of waste heat in space. That seems to be about the worst possible place to put a data center.
comments.content_cn: 对这个计划感到非常困惑。地球上的数据中心正在为如何处理废热而苦恼。在太空中处理废热真的非常非常困难。这似乎是放置数据中心最糟糕的地方。

comments.author: virtualhat
comments.content:
The author seems to have confused a few things.* They assume 1 satalite = 1 GPU. This is quite funny, actually. A single H200 floating in space with a solar panel and an antenna. In reality, a satellite would pack as many chips as the heat/power allows. A Starlink-sized satellite should be able to hold 40 or so chips. There's no reason why a larger satellitte couldn't hold, say, 1024.
* They mention training, but sampling is what makes sense here. Training is a different beast, and requires high reliability, high bandwidth, low latency, and a lot of IO. Space would not be ideal for this. I'd expect training to remain terrestrial and just do sampling in space. (FWIW, sampling will be most of the compute allocation).
* Also, no one upgrades GPUs in datacenters, they just add new nodes and leave the old ones there. Google still has their P100 nodes running. Not being able to fix them, though, is a significant concern.
comments.content_cn:
作者似乎混淆了一些概念。
* 他们假设1颗卫星=1块GPU。这其实挺可笑的——想象一块H200芯片带着太阳能板和天线在太空中漂浮。现实中，卫星会搭载散热和供电系统允许范围内的最多芯片。星链大小的卫星应该能容纳40块左右芯片，而更大尺寸的卫星完全可能装载1024块芯片。
* 他们提到了训练，但这里合理的应用场景应该是推理。训练是完全不同的领域，需要高可靠性、高带宽、低延迟和大量IO操作，太空环境并不适合。预计训练仍将在地面进行，太空只负责推理（值得说明的是，推理将占据绝大部分计算资源）。
* 此外，数据中心从不升级GPU，他们只会增加新节点而保留旧设备。谷歌至今还在运行P100节点。不过太空设备无法维修确实是个重要问题。

comments.author: tgtweak
comments.content: The crux of it is that radiative cooling in space is dependent on exposed surface, not total surface area like a radiator or heatsink on earth - this means if you just put an existing finned heatsink in space it would radiate most of it's heat back to itself - the only net cooling you'd have is the amount that can radiate outwards without hitting itself.For a benchmark - the IIS uses about 4500sqft (420 sqm) of radiators just to keep it's onboard equipment (~70KW) cooled.  That's ~150-200 W/sqm.That means, per GPU, you'd need about 2.5-3.0 sqm of passive radiators.For a 1MW satellite (~8 datacenter racks of GB200/NVL72) you'd need basically half a football field of bleeding-edge solar panels (that also need to radiate their heat on the reverse side) and a similar sized cooling array of heat radiators for the electronics.This is on the scale of 40-50 tons - about 10% of the IIS.  This should fit on falcon heavy or starship - assuming the solar array and radiators can fold up to fit inside.  You could, purely based on weight, launch 2 of these per starship launch.If you consider the Opex savings (electricity, rent, facilities maintenance) and putting 2 of these on a single starship launch, I still think the ROI would be too long.  You're saving about ~$1M per year in Opex but it's costing you $25M to launch it into space and likely an extra ~$50M in satellite equipment (based on starlink satellite costs) on top of the compute.  Will those GPUs still be useful in 10 years? Probably not.I don't think the math is there that justifies the free electricity - even at gigawatt scale (thousands of satellites mass-produced) and at a dramatically lower cost per satellite and per launch.  Getting costs down on this would involve tightly integrating the compute and the satellite hardware which would make upgrading the compute independently from the cooling/power infrastructure in the future a significant challenge.
comments.content_cn:
关键在于太空中的辐射冷却依赖于暴露表面，而非地球上散热器或散热片那样的总面积——这意味着如果直接将现有的鳍片式散热器置于太空，其大部分热量会辐射回自身，实际有效冷却仅限于向外辐射且未被自身吸收的部分。作为参考，国际空间站使用了约4500平方英尺（420平方米）的辐射器，仅用于冷却其内部设备（约70千瓦）。这相当于每平方米散热功率约150-200瓦。

按此计算，每个GPU需要约2.5-3.0平方米的无源辐射器。对于一个1兆瓦的卫星（约相当于8个GB200/NVL72数据中心机架），基本上需要半个足球场大小的尖端太阳能板（其背面也需要辐射散热），以及为电子设备配备类似尺寸的散热阵列。

这类系统的重量规模在40-50吨左右，约占国际空间站重量的10%。假设太阳能板和散热器可折叠收纳，理论上能搭载在猎鹰重型或星舰上。仅从重量考虑，每次星舰发射可运送两套此类系统。

若考虑运营成本节约（电力、租金、设施维护）以及单次发射部署两套系统，我仍认为投资回报周期过长。每年约节省100万美元运营成本，但发射入轨需花费2500万美元，加上计算设备本身，卫星设备可能还需额外投入约5000万美元（基于星链卫星成本推算）。这些GPU在10年后是否仍有价值？恐怕……

comments.author: phire
comments.content: As far as I can tell, Data centres in space only seem viable because their advocates insist on comparing them to standard terrestrial data centres.And nobody ever calls them out on it.Today's data centres are optimised for reliability, redundancy, density, repairability, connectivity and latency. Most of advertised savings come not from placing the data centre in space, but the fact that advocates have argued away the need for absolutely everything that modern data centres are designed to supply, except for the compute.If they can really build a space data centre satellite for as cheap as they claim, why launch it? Just drive it out into the middle of the desert and dump it there. It can access the internet via starlink, and already has solar panels for power and radiators for cooling. IMO, If it can cool itself in direct sunlight in space, it can cool itself in the desert.The main thing that space gains you over setting up the same satellite in the desert is ~23 hours of power, vs the ~12 hours of power on the ground. And you suddenly gain the ability to repair the satellite. The cost of the launch would have to be extremely cheap before the extra 11ish hours of runtime per day outweighed the cost of a launch; Just build twice as many "ground satellites".And that's with a space optimised design. We can gain even more cost savings by designing proper distributed datacenter elements. You don't need lightweight materials, just use steel. You can get rid of the large radiators and become more reliant on air cooling. You can built each element bigger, because you don't have to fit the rocket dimensions. You could even add a wind turbine, so your daily runtime isn't dependant on daylight hours. Might even be worth getting rid of solar and optimising for wind power instead.An actual ground optimised design should be able to deliver the same functionality as the space data centre, for much cheaper costs. And it's this ground optimised distributed design that space data centres should be compared to, not today's datacenter which are hyper-optimised for pre-AI use cases.-------------------Space data centres are nothing more than a cool Sci-Fi solution looking for a problem. There have been mumblings for years, but they were never viable (even bitcoin mining was a bit too latency sensitive). Space data centre advocates have been handed a massive win with this recent AI boom, it's the perfect problem for their favourite solution to solve.But because it's a solution looking for a problem, they are completely blind to other solutions that might be an even better fit.

comments.author: pointlessone
comments.content: While it’s true that there are no floods or earthquakes in space it’s not exactly a safe place to be. Radiation and cosmic rays become a much greater threat. Shielding provided by the atmosphere would have to be replaced.You also underestimate the cooling problem. The fact that space is cold doesn’t mean it’s easy to cool things off in space. On earth the main cooling strategy is to transfer heat through direct contact and move the hot stuff away. Be it air or water, as you mentioned. In space your only option is to radiate heat away. And that’s while half of you is under intense sunlight.I think you also undersell the thread of warfare in space. Sure, a guy with Molotov can’t get you space data center but we’ve had satellite shot down. So maybe not every war is a threat but, say China or Russia (or other space-faring nation) could take care of a satellite if absolutely needed.National seizures are also still a threat. If only being outside national borders was such a great defense we’d see some data centers in the sea by now.So being in space is immune to some of the known problems but also comes with a whole lot of novel issues, not solved at scale yet. And so far I haven’t seen any sufficiently detailed proposed solutions to even consider the trade of known problems with readily available solutions for new issues with lots of unknowns.
comments.content_cn:
虽然太空中确实没有洪水或地震，但这并非绝对安全之地。辐射和宇宙射线构成了更大的威胁，大气层提供的防护屏障必须被替代。您还低估了散热问题——太空的低温并不意味着散热容易。在地球上，主要散热策略是通过直接接触传热并移走热源，无论是空气还是水，正如您提到的。而在太空，唯一的选择是通过辐射散热，且设备一半区域还暴露在强烈日照下。

我认为您也低估了太空军事冲突的风险。确实，手持燃烧瓶的人无法袭击太空数据中心，但我们已有卫星被击落的先例。或许并非所有战争都构成威胁，但中国、俄罗斯（或其他航天国家）在必要时完全有能力摧毁卫星。

国家扣押资产的风险依然存在。如果仅凭位于国境之外就能提供完美防护，我们现在早该看到海上数据中心了。

因此，太空环境虽能规避某些已知问题，却会带来大量尚未大规模解决的新挑战。迄今为止，我尚未见到任何足够详尽的解决方案，能够让人认真考虑用已知问题的解决经验，来交换应对充满未知数的新难题。

comments.author: dfabulich
comments.content: In 2024, Starcloud posted their plans to "solve" the cooling problem. https://starcloudinc.github.io/wp.pdf> As conduction and convection to the environment are not available in space, this means the data center will require radiators capable of radiatively dissipating gigawatts of thermal load. To achieve this, Starcloud is developing a lightweight deployable radiator design with a very large area - by far the largest radiators deployed in space - radiating primarily towards deep space...They claim they can radiate "633.08 W / m^2". At that rate, they're looking at square kilometers of radiators to dissipate gigawatts of thermal load, perhaps hectares of radiators.They also claim that they can "dramatically increase" heat dissipation with heat pumps.So, there you have it: "all you have to do" is deploy a few hectares of radiators in space, combined with heat pumps that can dissipate gigawatts of thermal load with no maintenance at all over a lifetime of decades.This seems like the sort of "not technically impossible" problem that can attract a large amount of VC funding, as VCs buy lottery tickets that the problem can be solved.
comments.content_cn: 2024年，星云公司公布了他们"解决"散热问题的方案。由于太空中无法通过传导和对流向环境散热，这意味着数据中心需要配备能够辐射散出千兆瓦级热负荷的散热器。为此，星云正在开发一种轻质可展开的大型散热器设计——这将是目前太空中部署的最大散热器——主要面向深空辐射散热。他们声称可实现"每平方米633.08瓦"的散热功率。按此效率计算，散出千兆瓦级热负荷需要数平方公里的散热面积，可能达到公顷级别。他们还宣称可通过热泵"大幅提升"散热效能。综上所述，"只需"在太空中部署数公顷的散热器，配合能散出千兆瓦级热负荷且数十年无需维护的热泵系统即可。这类"技术上并非不可能"的课题往往能吸引大量风投资金，因为风投机构就像购买彩票般押注该问题终将得到解决。

comments.content: You are confusing engineering challenges with show stoppers. Cooling in space is a well studied problem with a few possible solutions. They all boil down to needing a lot of mass to radiate heat out to the universe and ways to conduct heat. We've been doing that at small scale for decades. SpaceX is already operating a fleet of many thousands of satellites that they built and engineered. They'd be well familiar with this challenge.Once you have solutions, it turns into a cost problem. And if that cost is too high (for whatever arbitrary threshold you use for that) it becomes an optimization problem.This whole thread reads like a lot of "but ... but ... but ...". It all boils down to people assuming things about what is too much or too hard. And it's all meaningless unless you actually bother to articulate those assumptions. What exactly is too hard here? What would it take to address those issues? What would the cost be? Put some numbers on it. There are also all sorts of assumptions about what is valuable and what isn't. You can't say something is too hard or too costly without making assertions about what is worth paying for and what isn't.The answers are going to be boring. We need X amounts of giga tons launched to orbit at Y amount of dollars. OK great. What happens if launch cost drops by 1 or 2 orders of magnitude? Reducing the cost of launches is great, but it will never be as cheap as zero launches.2. Radio transmissions have equally high bandwidth from Earth, but fiber is a better network backbone in almost every way.3. Radiation events don't only cause unpredictable data errors, they can also cause circuit latch-ups and cascade into system failure. Error-free operation is still better in any case. Earth's magenetosphere and atmosphere give you radiation shielding for free, rad-hard chips will always cost more than standard (do they even exist for this application?), and extra shielding will always cost more than no shielding.4. On Earth you can use conduction, convection, AND radiation for cooling. Space only gets you marginally more effective radiation.5. Solar is cheaper on the ground than in space. The increase in solar collection capability per unit area in space doesn't offset the cost of launch: you can get 20kW of terrestrial solar collection for around the price of a single 1U satellite launch, and that solar production can be used on upgraded equipment in the future. Any solar you put on a satellite gets decommissioned when the inference hardware is obsolete.And this ignores other issues like hardware upgrades, troubleshooting, repairs, and recycling that are essentially impossible in space, but are trivial on the ground.

posts.author: vikaveri
posts.title_cn: 法国X办公室遭突查，英国对Grok展开新调查
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕法国当局突击检查X公司办公室及英国对Grok展开新调查的事件展开。核心争议点在于突击检查的必要性及AI公司的内容责任。部分用户认为，突击检查是标准执法程序，尤其针对涉嫌非法数据提取和传播未成年人非自愿性影像等严重指控。有用户指出，这起事件明确了AI公司需对模型输出内容负责，即使这意味着加强审查。同时，讨论中提到，针对“有组织欺诈性数据提取”的指控可能对整个社交媒体行业产生广泛影响。也有观点认为，马斯克可能将此事件曲解为言论自由问题，但实际焦点在于违法行为及公司的不作为。社区普遍认同执法调查的正当性，但在AI监管与言论自由的平衡问题上存在分歧。

comments.author: utopiah

You are thinking about a company abiding by the law, storing data on its own server, having good practices, etc.The moment a company starts to do dubious stuff then good practices start to go out the window. People write email with cryptic analogies, people start deleting emails, ... then as the circumvention become more numerous and complex, there needs to still be a trail in order to remain understandable. That trail will be in written form somehow and that must be hidden. It might be paper, it might be shadow IT but the point is that if you are not just forgetting to keep track of coffee pods at the social corner, you will leave traces.So yes, raids do make sense BECAUSE it's about recurring complex activities that are just too hard to keep in the mind of one single individual over long periods of time.

comments.author: notepad0x90
comments.content: Yeah, two things to add:1) Even when you move things to a server, or remove it from your device, evidence is still left over without your knowledge sometimes.2) Evidence of data destruction, is in itself as the name implies, evidence. And it can be used to prove things.For example, an ext4 journal or NTFS USN $J journal entry that shows "grok_version_2.4_schema.json"  where twitter is claiming grok version 2.4 was never deployed in France/UK is important. That's why tools like shred and SDelete rename files before destroying them. But even then, when those tools rename and destroy files, it stands out, it might even be worse because investigators can speculate more. It might corroborate some other piece of evidence (e.g.: sdelete's prefetch entry on windows, or download history from a browser for the same tool), and that might be a more serious charge (obstruction of justice in the US).
comments.content_cn: 是的，还有两点要补充：1）即使你将数据转移到服务器或从设备中删除，有时仍会在你不知情的情况下留下痕迹。2）数据销毁的证据，顾名思义，本身就是证据，可以用来证明某些事情。例如，当推特声称Grok 2.4版本从未在法国/英国部署时，显示"grok_version_2.4_schema.json"的ext4日志或NTFS USN $J日志条目就很重要。这就是为什么像shred和SDelete这样的工具在销毁文件前会先重命名它们。但即便如此，当这些工具重命名并销毁文件时，也会显得很突出，甚至可能更糟，因为调查人员可以进行更多推测。它可能与其他证据（例如：Windows上sdelete的预取条目，或浏览器中同一工具的下载历史）相互印证，而这可能导致更严重的指控（在美国是妨碍司法公正）。

comments.author: PaulRobinson
comments.content: It's worth pointing out that in France and the UK, the authorities involved are arms length independent of the political bodies - it's not like the US where if you give the President good vibes you can become head of the FBI, and all you have to do in return is whatever he says. There are statutory instruments (in France, constitutional clauses), that determine the independence of these authorities.They are tasked - and held to account by respective legislative bodies - with implementing the law as written.Nobody wrote a law saying "Go after Grok". There is however a law in most countries about the creation and dissemination of CSAM material and non-consensual pornography. Some of that law is relatively new (the UK only introduced some of these laws in recent years), but they all predate the current wave of AI investment.Founders, boards of directors and their internal and external advisors could:1. Read the law and make sure any tools they build comply2. When told their tools don't comply take immediate and decisive action to change the tools3. Work with law enforcement to apply the law as writtenThose companies, if they find this too burdensome, have the choice of not operating in that market. By operating in that market, they both implicitly agree to the law, and are required to explicitly abide by it.They can't then complain that the law is unfair (it's not), that it's being politicised (How? By whom? Show your working), and that this is all impossible in their home market where they are literally offering presents to the personal enrichment of the President on bended knee while he demands that ownership structures of foreign social media companies like TikTok are changed to meet the agenda of himself and his administration.So, would the EU like more tighter speech controls? Yes, they'd like implementation of the controls on free speech enshrined in legislation created by democratically appointed representatives. The alternative - algorithms that create abusive content, of women and children in particular - are not wanted by the people of the UK, the EU, or most of the rest of the World, laws are written to that effect, and are then enforced by the authorities tasked with that enforcement.This isn't "anti-democratic", it's literally democracy in action standing up to technocratic feudalism that is an Ayn Randian-wet dream being played out by some morons who got lucky.
comments.content_cn: 值得指出的是，在法国和英国，相关机构与政治实体保持独立运作——这不同于美国的情况，在美国如果你给总统留下好印象，就可能成为联邦调查局局长，而你需要做的回报就是听从他的指示。两国通过法定文件（法国为宪法条款）确保这些机构的独立性。它们的职责是依法行事，并接受各自立法机构的监督问责。没有任何法律规定“追查Grok”。但大多数国家都有关于制作传播儿童性虐待材料和非自愿色情内容的法律。其中部分法律相对较新（英国近年才出台相关法规），但这些法律都早于当前的人工智能投资热潮。企业创始人、董事会及其内外部顾问可以采取以下措施：1. 研读法律并确保所开发工具符合规定；2. 被告知工具违规时立即采取果断措施进行整改；3. 与执法部门合作落实法律条文。若企业认为合规负担过重，可以选择退出该市场。一旦选择进入市场，即意味着默示同意并必须明示遵守当地法律。企业不能事后抱怨法律不公（实际上并非如此），指责法律被政治化（如何政治化？被谁政治化？请提供依据），更不能声称其母国市场完全无法实现合规要求……

comments.content: You were downvoted -- a theme in this thread -- but I like what you're saying. I disagree, though, on a global scale. By resilience, I mean to reference something like a monoculture plantation vs a jungle. The monoculture plantation is vulnerable to anything that figures out how to attack it. In a jungle, a single plant or set might be vulnerable, but something that can attack all the plants is much harder to come by.Humanity itself is trending more toward monoculture socially; I like a lot of things (and hate some) about the cultural trend. But what I like isn't very important, because I might be totally wrong in my likes; if only my likes dominated, the world would be a much less resilient place -- vulnerable to the weaknesses of whatever it is I like.So, again, I propose for the race as a whole, broad cultural diversity is really critical, and worth protecting. comments.author: yibg
comments.content: My natural reaction here is like I think most others; that yes Grok / X bad, shouldn't be able to generate CSAM content / deepfakes.But I am having trouble justifying in an consistent manner why Grok / X should be liable here instead of the user. I've seen a few arguments here that mostly comes down to:1. It's Grok the LLM generating the content, not the user.2. The distribution. That this isn't just on the user's computer but instead posted on X.For 1. it seems to breakdown if we look more broadly at how LLMs are used. e.g. as a coding agent. We're basically starting to treat LLMs as a higher level framework now. We don't hold vendors of programming languages or frameworks responsible if someone uses them to create CSAM. Yes LLM generated the content, but the user still provided the instructions to do so.For 2. if Grok instead generated the content for download would the liability go away? What if Grok generated the content to be downloaded only and then the user uploaded manually to X? If in this case Grok isn't liable then why does the automatic posting (from the user's instructions) make it different? If it is, then it's not about the distribution anymore.There are some comparisons to photoshop, that if i created a deep fake with photoshop that I'm liable not Adobe. If photoshop had a "upload to X" button, and I created CSM using photoshop and hit the button to upload to X directly, is now Adobe now liable?What am I missing?
comments.content_cn:
我的本能反应和大多数人一样：是的，Grok / X 很糟糕，不应该能生成儿童性虐待内容或深度伪造品。但我很难自圆其说地解释为什么应该是 Grok / X 而不是用户为此负责。我看到这里有几个论点，主要归结为：
1. 是 Grok 这个大型语言模型生成了内容，而不是用户。
2. 传播问题。内容不只是留在用户电脑上，而是发布在了 X 上。

对于第1点，如果我们更广泛地审视大型语言模型的使用方式，这个论点似乎就站不住脚了。例如，将其用作编程助手。我们现在基本上开始将大型语言模型视为一个更高层次的框架。如果有人使用编程语言或框架来制作儿童性虐待内容，我们并不会追究编程语言或框架供应商的责任。是的，是大型语言模型生成了内容，但用户仍然提供了生成指令。

对于第2点，如果 Grok 改为生成内容供下载，责任是否就消失了？如果 Grok 生成内容仅供下载，然后用户手动上传到 X 呢？如果在这种情况下 Grok 没有责任，那么为什么根据用户指令自动发布就有所不同？如果它有责任，那就不再是关于传播的问题了。

有人将其与 Photoshop 比较，说如果我使用 Photoshop 制作了深度伪造品，那么负责的是我，而不是 Adobe。如果 Photoshop 有一个“上传到 X”的按钮，我使用 Photoshop 制作了儿童性虐待内容并点击按钮直接上传到 X，那么 Adobe 现在就有责任了吗？

我漏掉了什么？

posts.title: I miss thinking hard
posts.author: jernestomg
posts.title_cn: 我怀念深入思考的感觉
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕“怀念深度思考”展开，探讨AI编程工具如何影响开发者的思维模式和工作体验。核心争议在于AI辅助编码是否削弱了深度思考的价值。

部分用户认为AI工具虽提升效率，但可能导致思维惰性。用户指出，AI生成的方案往往趋于“平庸”，要推动创新想法仍需付出大量精力，这与手动编码的思考强度相当。也有用户强调，AI主要满足“构建者”而非“思考者”的需求，自己更倾向于后者。

另一方面，有用户反驳称使用AI时仍在进行深度思考，例如权衡设计选择、技术债务等，认为思考强度并未降低。还有用户区分了“思考量大”和“思考深入”，指出讨论中常混淆两者。

共识在于，许多开发者怀念过去全心投入编程的“心流状态”，而AI工具的交互方式可能难以复现这种沉浸体验。分歧则体现在对AI实际影响的判断上：有人认为它简化了重复劳动，解放了创造力；也有人担忧它让思考变得浅层，削弱了解决问题的根本能力。

comments.author: gyomu
comments.content: This March 2025 post from Aral Balkan stuck with me:https://mastodon.ar.al/@aral/114160190826192080"Coding is like taking a lump of clay and slowly working it into the thing you want it to become. It is this process, and your intimacy with the medium and the materials you’re shaping, that teaches you about what you’re making – its qualities, tolerances, and limits – even as you make it. You know the least about what you’re making the moment before you actually start making it. That’s when you think you know what you want to make. The process, which is an iterative one, is what leads you towards understanding what you actually want to make, whether you were aware of it or not at the beginning. Design is not merely about solving problems; it’s about discovering what the right problem to solve is and then solving it. Too often we fail not because we didn’t solve a problem well but because we solved the wrong problem.When you skip the process of creation you trade the thing you could have learned to make for the simulacrum of the thing you thought you wanted to make. Being handed a baked and glazed artefact that approximates what you thought you wanted to make removes the very human element of discovery and learning that’s at the heart of any authentic practice of creation. Where you know everything about the thing you shaped into being from when it was just a lump of clay, you know nothing about the image of the thing you received for your penny from the vending machine."
comments.content_cn:
2025年3月阿拉尔·巴尔坎的这篇帖子让我印象深刻：https://mastodon.ar.al/@aral/114160190826192080

编程如同取一团黏土，慢慢塑造成你想要的模样。正是这个过程，以及你与塑造媒介和材料的亲密接触，让你在创造的同时理解所造之物——它的特性、容差与局限。在你真正动手之前，你对要创造的东西了解最少。那时你以为自己知道要做什么。而这个迭代的过程，会引导你逐渐理解自己真正想创造什么，无论最初是否意识到这一点。设计不仅仅是解决问题，更是发现该解决的正确问题并解决它。我们常常失败，并非因为没解决好问题，而是因为解决了错误的问题。

当你跳过创造过程，就是用本可学会制作之物的可能性，换取了自以为想制作之物的仿品。得到一个近似想象中目标的现成工艺品，便剥夺了人类最核心的探索与学习体验——这正是任何真正创作实践的本质。当你从一团黏土开始亲手塑造某物时，你对其了如指掌；而若从自动售货机投币取得成品，你对它的认知便止于表象。

comments.author: m0rc
comments.content: I think the article has a point. There seem to be two reactions among senior engineers atound me these days.On one side, there are people who have become a bit more productive. They are certainly not "10x," but they definitely deliver more code. However, I do not observe a substantial difference in the end-to-end delivery of production-ready software. This might be on me and my lack of capacity to exploit the tools to their full extent. But, iterating over customer requirements, CI/CD, peer reviews, and business validation takes time (and time from the most experienced people, not from the AI).On the other hand, soemtimes I observe a genuine degradation of thinking among some senior engineers (there aren’t many juniors around, by the way). Meetings, requirements, documents, or technology choices seem to be directly copy/pasted from an LLM, without a grain of original thinking, many times without insight.The AI tools are great though. They give you an answer to the question. But, many times making the correct question, and knowing when the answer is not correct is the main issue.I wonder if the productivity boost that senior engineers actually need is to profit from the accumulated knowledge found in books. I know it is an old technology and it is not fashionable, but I believe it is mostly unexploited if you consider the whole population of engineers :D
comments.content_cn:
我觉得这篇文章说得有道理。最近我身边的高级工程师似乎有两种反应。一方面，有些人确实提高了工作效率。他们虽然算不上"十倍效率"的工程师，但产出的代码量确实增加了。不过，我并没有观察到他们在端到端交付生产就绪软件方面有实质性的差异。这可能是我自己的问题，没有充分发挥这些工具的全部潜力。毕竟，反复推敲客户需求、持续集成与部署、同行评审以及业务验证都需要时间（而且这些时间来自最有经验的工程师，而不是人工智能）。

另一方面，我有时会注意到一些高级工程师（顺便说一句，现在初级工程师不多）的思考能力明显下降。会议记录、需求文档、技术方案似乎都是直接从大语言模型复制粘贴而来，缺乏原创思考，很多时候也没有真知灼见。

人工智能工具确实很棒，它们能回答问题。但很多时候，如何提出正确的问题，以及如何判断答案是否正确，才是关键所在。

我在想，高级工程师真正需要的生产力提升，或许应该来自书籍中积累的知识。我知道这是老技术，也不时髦，但考虑到整个工程师群体，我认为这些知识大多尚未被充分利用：）

comments.author: thegrim000
comments.content: You know, I was expecting what the post would say and was prepared to dunk on it and just tell them to stop using ai then, but the builder/thinker division they presented got me thinking. How ai/vibe coding fulfills the builder, not the thinker, made me realize that I'm basically 100% thinker, 0% builder, and that's why I don't really care at all about ai for coding.I'll spend years working on a from scratch OS kernel or a vulkan graphics engine or whatever other ridiculous project, which never sees the light of day, because I just enjoy the thinking / hard work. Solving hard problems is my entertainment and my hobby. It's cool to eventually see results in those projects, but that's not really the point. The point is to solve hard problems. I've spent decades on personal projects that nobody else will ever see.So I guess that explains why I see all the ai coding stuff and pretty much just ignore it. I'll use ai now as an advanced form of google, and also as a last ditch effort to get some direction on bugs I truly can't figure out, but otherwise I just completely ignore it. But I guess there's other people, the builders, where ai is a miraculous thing and they're going to crazy lengths to adopt it in every workflow and have it do as much as possible. Those 'builder' types of people are just completely different from me.
comments.content_cn:
说实话，我原本猜到这篇帖子会说什么，准备好好嘲讽一番，直接告诉他们别再用AI了。但他们提出的“建造者/思考者”之分让我陷入了沉思。AI和氛围编程如何满足建造者而非思考者的需求，让我意识到自己基本是100%的思考者和0%的建造者，这也解释了为什么我对编程AI完全无感。我可以花数年时间从头开发操作系统内核或Vulkan图形引擎之类天马行空的项目，这些项目永远不会面世，因为我纯粹享受思考与攻坚的过程。解决难题就是我的娱乐和爱好。最终看到项目成果固然不错，但那并非重点，重点在于攻克难关。几十年来我做过无数无人知晓的个人项目。

我想这正好说明为何我看到所有AI编程相关内容都几乎视而不见。现在我把AI当作高级版谷歌搜索，也会在遇到完全无法解决的bug时用它做最后的方向参考，除此之外根本不会理会。但世界上确实存在另一类人——那些建造者，AI对他们而言如同奇迹。他们正竭尽全力将AI融入每个工作流程，让它承担尽可能多的任务。这类“建造者”与我的思维方式截然不同。

comments.author: helloplanets
comments.content: And when programming with agentic tools, you need to actively push for the idea to not regress to the most obvious/average version. The amount of effort you need to expend on pushing the idea that deviates from the 'norm' (because it's novel), is actually comparable to the effort it takes to type something out by hand. Just two completely different types of effort.There's an upside to this sort of effort too, though. You actually need to make it crystal clear what your idea is and what it is not, because of the continuous pushback from the agentic programming tool. The moment you stop pushing back, is the moment the LLM rolls over your project and more than likely destroys what was unique about your thing in the first place.
comments.content_cn: 在使用智能编程工具时，你需要积极推动想法，避免其退化为最明显或平庸的版本。为了让偏离“常规”的新颖构思得以实现，你所付出的努力实际上与手动编写代码相当，只是两种努力的性质完全不同。然而，这种努力也有其积极面：由于智能编程工具会持续提出质疑，你必须极其清晰地界定自己想法的边界。一旦你停止坚持，大型语言模型便会覆盖你的项目，很可能彻底抹杀其原有的独特之处。

comments.author: urutom
comments.content: One thing this discussion made me realize is that "thinking hard" might not be a single mode of thinking.In grad school, I had what I'd call the classic version. I stayed up all night mentally working on a topology question about turning a 2-torus inside out. I already knew you can't flip a torus inside out in ordinary R^3 without self-intersection. So I kept moving and stretching the torus and the surrounding space in my head, trying to understand where the obstruction actually lived.Sometime around sunrise, it clicked that if you allow the move to go through infinity(so effectively S^3), the inside/outside distinction I was relying on just collapses, and the obstruction I was visualizing dissolves. Birds were chirping, I hadn't slept, and nothing useful came out of it, but my internal model of space felt permanently upgraded. That's clearly "thinking hard" in the sense.But there's another mode I've experienced that feels related but different. With a tough Code Golf problem, I might carry it around for a week. I'm not actively grinding on it the whole time, but the problem stays loaded in the background. Then suddenly, in the shower or on a walk, a compression trick or a different representation just clicks.That doesn't feel "hard" moment to moment. It's more like keeping a problem resident in memory long enough for the right structure to surface.One is concentrated and exhausting, the other is diffuse and slow-burning. They're different phenomenologically, but both feel like forms of deep engagement that are easy to crowd out.
comments.content_cn:
这次讨论让我意识到，“深度思考”可能并非单一模式。研究生时期，我经历过经典版本：彻夜不眠地在脑海中推演关于二维环面内外翻转的拓扑学问题。我已知在普通三维空间中环面无法不自交地完成翻转，于是持续在意识中移动拉伸环面与周围空间，试图理解阻碍究竟存在于何处。

临近破晓时分，我突然顿悟：若允许运动过程穿越无限远点（即等效于三维球面），我所依赖的内外区分便会瓦解，那些可视化阻碍也随之消融。窗外鸟鸣渐起，彻夜未眠虽未带来实际成果，但我对空间的内在认知模型却获得了永久性升级——这无疑是“深度思考”的典型体现。

但还存在另一种相关却不同的模式。面对棘手的代码高尔夫难题时，我可能将其携带一周之久。并非持续专注攻坚，而是让问题始终驻留于意识后台。而后在淋浴或散步时，某种压缩技巧或异化表征会骤然浮现。

这种体验在当下并不显得“艰难”，更像是让问题在记忆中充分浸润，直至合适的结构自然浮现。前者是高度集中、消耗心力的，后者则是弥散式、文火慢焙的。二者在现象层面截然不同，却都让人感受到……

comments.content: People here seem to be conflating thinking hard and thinking a lot.Most examples mentioned of “thinking hard” in the comments sound like they think about a lot of stuff superficially instead one particular problem deeply, which is what OP is referring to.
comments.content_cn: 这里的人似乎把努力思考和想很多事情混为一谈了。评论中提到的“努力思考”的例子大多听起来像是他们肤浅地思考了很多事情，而不是像楼主所指的那样深入思考某个特定问题。

comments.content_cn: 我在想，这里所有声称使用LLM代理能让他们更深入思考的人，是否从未在编程时进入过“心流状态”。我实在无法想象在代理的辅助下，还能连续数小时保持百分之百的精神专注。当然，当我的编码主要通过代理完成时，我的思考方式确实有所不同，但我从未在这个过程中完全沉浸于自己的思绪中。对于那些通过LLM代理找到“心流状态”的人，那是一种怎样的体验？

comments.author: r-johnv
comments.content: I've found that it's often useful to spend the time thinking about the way I would architect the code (down to a fair level of minutia) before letting the agent have a go.That way my 'thinker' is satiated and also challenged - Did the solution that my thinker came up with solve the problem better than the plan that the agent wrote?Then either I acknowledge that the agent's solution was better, giving my thinker something to chew on for the next time; or my solution is better which gives the thinker a dopamine hit and gives me better code.
comments.content_cn: 我发现，在让智能体尝试之前，花时间思考如何构建代码（深入到相当细致的层面）通常很有帮助。这样，我的“思考者”既得到了满足，也受到了挑战——我思考出的解决方案是否比智能体编写的方案更好地解决了问题？然后，要么我承认智能体的方案更优，让我的思考者下次有东西可以琢磨；要么我的方案更好，这能给思考者带来多巴胺的愉悦，也让我得到更优质的代码。

comments.author: bariswheel
comments.content:
Good highlight of the struggle between Builder and Thinker, I enjoyed the writing.
So why not work on PQC? Surely you've thought about other avenues here as well.If you're looking for a domain where the 70% AI solution is a total failure, that's the field. You can't rely on vibe coding because the underlying math, like Learning With Errors (LWE) or supersingular isogeny graphs, is conceptually dense and hasn't been commoditized into AI training data yet. It requires that same 'several-day-soak' thinking you loved in physics, specifically because we're trying to build systems that remain secure even against an adversary with a quantum computer. It’s one of the few areas left where the Thinker isn't just a luxury, but a hard requirement for the Builder to even begin.
comments.content_cn:
对构建者与思考者之间矛盾的精彩凸显，我很欣赏这样的论述。  
那么为何不考虑后量子密码学领域呢？你肯定也思考过其他方向。如果你在寻找一个AI仅能达成70%解决方案就完全失败的领域，那正是这里。你不能依赖直觉编程，因为其底层数学理论——如容错学习或超奇异同源图——概念艰深，尚未被转化为AI训练数据。它需要你钟爱的那种“数日沉浸式”思考，这正是因为我们试图构建即使面对拥有量子计算机的对手也能保持安全的系统。这是少数几个思考者不仅是奢侈品，更是构建者起步必备硬性要求的领域之一。

我不太理解。我觉得思考强度没变，打字反而少了。我精确描述需求并仔细检查。要说变化，我们只是提升了一个工作层级。最终产品还是一样的。

comments.author: fl0ki
comments.content: It really bothers me how many comments on this topic (here and elsewhere) draw a false parallel between LLM-based coding as an abstraction and frameworks and compilers as an abstraction. They're not the same thing and it matters.Frameworks and compilers are designed to be leak-proof abstractions. Any way in which they deviate from their abstract promise is a bug that can be found, filed, and permanently fixed. You get to spend your time and energy reasoning in terms of the abstraction because you can trust that the finished product works exactly the way you reasoned about at the abstract level.LLMs cannot offer that promise by design, so it remains your job to find and fix any deviations from the abstraction you intended. If you fell short of finding and fixing any of those bugs, you've just left yourself a potential crisis down the line.[Aside: I get why that's acceptable in many domains, and I hope in return people can get why it's not acceptable in many other domains]All of our decades of progress in programming languages, frameworks, libraries, etc. has been in trying to build up leak-proof abstractions so that programmer intent can be focused only on the unique and interesting parts of a problem, with the other details getting the best available (or at least most widely applicable) implementation. In many ways we've succeeded, even though in many ways it looks like progress has stalled. LLMs have not solved this, they've just given up on the leak-proof part of the problem, trading it for exactly the costs and risks the industry was trying to avoid by solving it properly.
comments.content_cn:
关于这个话题（无论在这里还是其他地方），许多评论将基于大语言模型的编程抽象与框架和编译器抽象进行错误类比，这实在令我困扰。它们本质不同，且这种差异至关重要。

框架和编译器被设计成无漏洞的抽象层。任何偏离其抽象承诺的表现都属于可被识别、记录并永久修复的程序缺陷。你可以放心地将时间精力投入在抽象层面的逻辑推演，因为最终产物会严格遵循你在抽象层面的设计预期。

而大语言模型从设计上就无法提供这种保证，因此发现并修正实际结果与预期抽象之间的偏差始终是你的责任。如果未能及时发现并修复这些缺陷，就等于为未来埋下了潜在的危机隐患。

（旁注：我理解为何这在许多领域可以被接受，同时也希望人们能明白为何在其他众多领域这不可接受）

我们数十年来在编程语言、框架、类库等领域的所有进步，始终致力于构建无漏洞的抽象层，使程序员能够专注于问题中独特而核心的部分，其余细节则交由最优（或至少最通用）的现成方案实现。尽管在某些方面进展看似停滞，但我们在许多领域确实取得了成功。大语言模型并未解决这个根本问题，它们只是放弃了构建无漏洞抽象层的追求……

comments.author: eggy
comments.content:
I've been coding since the late 70s (Commodore PET 2001), and I've always paired it with real-world physical work—mechanical engineering, rigging, technical diving, hydraulics, welding, electronics, controls, you name it. Programming was just one of the tools, never the whole job.
What I've learned is that the best thinking almost never happens staring at a screen. It happens when you're away from it: reading something deep, building something with your hands, debugging why the thing you designed doesn't work in reality.
I love the updated saying: "Jack of all trades, master of none—but often better than a master of one." In a world obsessed with hyper-specialization, that range is a real advantage.
What bothers me most is how quickly people—especially younger ones—now reach for a phone the second there's any friction. Forgotten a name? Phone. Stuck on a small logic puzzle? Phone. A group of engineers at the lunch table can't remember an actor and within seconds everyone's just silently googling instead of laughing and piecing it together from their collective memory. Where's the fun in that?
Yeah, you get the answer instantly. But you skip the actual mental workout—and the fun of it. Remembering and reasoning are muscles. Use them or lose them. And honestly, the shared back-and-forth is usually the best part.

comments.author: sigbottle
comments.content: Yup, yup! There's so many different ways of thinking hard.For me, thinking about an extremely technical TCS problem, for example, is my version of actively, tirelessly thinking hard. I'm logging a ton of observations, trying new ideas and hypotheses, using a mix of computer simulation and math to try and arrive at a concrete framing and answer.On the other end of the specturm, I have philosophy. It's definitely a different type of hard. Most of my "Aha!" moments come from when I realize I've been strawmanning some argument, and not actually understanding what the person is saying. Why is the person saying this, relative to what, why is this a new observation, etc. Things are so amorphus and you can tweak the problem parameters in so many ways, and it's really tempting to either be too fluid and pretend you understand the thinker (because it's a subset of some conception you already have), or be too rigid and dissolve the thinker as a category error / meaningless. I've never felt the same feeling as I did when doing TCS research, but the feeling was definitely hard thinking nonetheless.In terms of extremely nitty-gritty technical things, like linker bullshit and linux kernel programming, I'm much more familiar with, and these things are more about reading documentation (because the tool won't behave like you want it to) and iteration / testing (because... the tool won't behave like you want it to, so you need to make sure it behaves like you want it to!). This is also a type of thinking - I would call it hard as in the physiological response I have is similar to that of research in the very bad moments, but in terms of my lofty ideals, I don't want to call this hard.... it's very "accidental" complexity, but it's what I get paid to do :/At work, you have a huge idea space to consider, both problem and solution framings, mixing in "bullshit" constraints like business ones. You also throw in the real-time aspect of it, so I can't just either armchair on a problem for a month (unlike Philosophy) or deep dive on a problem for a month (unlike research). I'm technically doing the third type of programming right now, but we'll see how long that lasts and I get put on a new project.I'm not even sure if there's a clean demarcation between any of these. These are certainly better than brainrotting youtube though.

确实如此！深入思考的方式多种多样。对我来说，思考一个极具技术性的TCS问题，就是我积极、不知疲倦地深入思考的方式。我会记录大量观察结果，尝试新的想法和假设，结合计算机模拟和数学方法，力求得出具体的框架和答案。

而在光谱的另一端，则是哲学思考。这无疑是另一种不同的深度思考。我的许多“顿悟”时刻，往往来自于意识到自己一直在曲解某些论点，而没有真正理解对方的意思。对方为何这样说，相对于什么而言，为何这是一个新的观察等等。这些问题非常模糊，你可以从多种角度调整问题参数，很容易要么过于灵活地假装自己理解了思考者（因为这只是你已有观念的某个子集），要么过于僵化地将思考者视为分类错误或无意义。我从未有过与进行TCS研究时相同的感觉，但这无疑也是一种深度思考。

至于那些极其琐碎的技术问题，比如链接器的麻烦事和Linux内核编程，我则熟悉得多。这些事情更多是关于阅读文档（因为工具不会按你期望的方式运行）以及迭代和测试（因为……工具不会按你期望的方式运行，所以你需要确保它按你期望的方式运行！）。这也是一种类型的……

comments.author: Stefan-H
comments.content: Your comment gets to the crux of my thinking about LLM coding. The way I think of what LLM coding is doing is decompressing your prompt into code based on the statistical likelihood of that decompression based on training data. Basically "Build me an IOS app" -> a concrete implementation of an iOS app.  The issue here is that the user supplying the prompt needs to encode all of the potential variables that the AI needs to work with into the prompt, or else the implementation will just be based on the "bog-standard" iOS app based on the training corpus, although with potential differences in the app based on other tokens in the prompt. Is natural language the right way to encode that information?  Do we want to rely on input tokens to the context of a model successfully making it into the output to guarantee accuracy? I think the Kiro Spec driven development starts to get at addressing the inherent issues in LLM based coding assistance, but it is an early step.
comments.content_cn: 你的评论触及了我对LLM编程思考的核心。我认为LLM编程的本质在于：它根据训练数据中的统计概率，将你的提示信息“解压缩”成代码。简单来说，“给我开发一个iOS应用”这个指令，会被转化为一个具体的iOS应用实现方案。这里的关键问题在于：用户必须将所有可能影响AI决策的变量都编码进提示信息中，否则生成的实现方案就只会基于训练语料库中的“标准版”iOS应用——尽管提示中的其他词汇可能会让应用产生一些差异。自然语言真的是编码这类信息的最佳方式吗？我们是否应该依赖输入模型的上下文标记来确保输出结果的准确性？我认为Kiro规范驱动开发开始触及基于LLM的编程辅助工具固有的问题，但这只是初步探索。

comments.author: Fire-Dragon-DoL
comments.content:
I think my message is doing a disservice to explaining what actually happened because a lot of it happens in my head.    1. I received the ticket, as soon as I read it I had a hunch it was related to some querying ignoring a field that should be filtered by every query (thinking)
    2. I give this hunch to the AI which goes search in the codebase in the areas I suggested the problem could be and that's when it find the issue and provide a fix
    3. I think the problem could be spread given there is a method that removes the query filter, it could have been used in multiple places, so I ask AI to find other usages of it (thinking, this is my definition of "steering" in this context)
    4. AI reports 3 more occurrences and suggests that 2 have the same bug, but one is ok
    5. I go in, review the code and understand it and I agree, it doesn't have the bug (thinking)
    6. AI provide the fix for all the right spots, but I said "wait, something is fishy here, there is a commit that explicitly say it was added to remove the filter, why is that?" (thinking), so I ask AI to figure out why the commit says that
    7. AI proceeds to run a bunch of git-history related commands, finds some commit and then does some correlation to find another commit. This other commit introduced the change at the same time to defend from a bug in a different place
   8. I understand what's going on now, I'm happy with the fix, the history suggests I am not breaking stuff. I ask AI to write a commit with detailed information about the bug and the fix based on the conversation
    

There is a lot of thinking involved. What's reduced is search tooling. I can be way more fuzzy, rather than `rg 'whatever'` I now say "find this and similar patterns"

4. AI报告了另外3处使用点，指出其中2处存在相同缺陷，但有一处是正常的  
5. 我亲自审查代码并理解逻辑，确认那处确实没有缺陷（思考中）

我的经历类似，但我觉得自己实际上比大语言模型出现前思考得更费力。以前，一旦像你提到的那些设计选择——风险、约束、技术债务、替代方案、可能性等——都考虑完毕，我就能制定出计划，然后按照这个计划写代码时几乎不需要费力思考。实际上，写代码对我来说是一种放松，我需要在深度思考的间隙获得这种放松。

如今我们把代码编写交给大语言模型，因为它们比人类快得多，但随后却不得不费力地检查大语言模型写的代码是否满足需求。另外，随着初级开发者使用大语言模型，审查他们的拉取请求也变得更困难了。有了人工智能加持的初级开发者更大胆，也更粗心。人工智能经常建议一些他们自己都不理解的复杂代码，他们看到代码能运行就直接提交。有时人工智能还会建议引入初级开发者自己想不到的新库依赖，而评估这些依赖是否合理、值得引入，自然成了资深开发者的职责。拉取请求的平均长度也增加了。而且初级开发者借助人工智能工作得更快，导致我们花在代码审查上的时间更多了。

我感觉自己的工作从两方面都压缩成了代码审查：一边是我的人工智能写的代码，另一边是初级开发者的人工智能写的代码——而且数量还增加了。尽管我喜欢审查代码，但这感觉像是我职业中最难的部分，而我原本喜欢……

comments.author: zackmorris
comments.content: Just wanted to +1 this as a deep thinker who disagrees with the blog post's conclusion. I remember back on the years and decades I wasted dealing with the conceptual flaws inherent to nearly all software, and it breaks my heart.90-99% of programming is a waste of time. Most apps today have less than a single spreadsheet page of actual business logic. The rest is boilerplate. Conjuring up whatever arcane runes are needed to wake a slumbering beast made of anti-patterns and groupthink.For me, AI offers the first real computer that I've had access to in over 25 years. Because desktop computing stagnated after the 2000 Dot Bomb, and died on the table after the iPhone arrived in 2007. Where we should have symmetric multiprocessing with 1000+ cores running 100,000 times faster for the same price, we have the same mediocre quad core computer running about the same speed as its 3 GHz grandfather from the early 2000s. But AI bridges that divide by recruiting video cards that actually did increase in speed, albeit for SIMD which is generally useless for desktop computing. AI liberates me from having to mourn that travesty any longer.I think that people have tied their identity to programming without realizing that it's mostly transcribing.But I will never go back to manual entry (the modern equivalent of punch cards).If anything, I can finally think deeply without it costing me everything. No longer having to give my all just to tread water as I slowly drown in technical debt and deadlines which could never be met before without sacrificing a part of my psyche in the process.What I find fascinating is that it's truly over. I see so clearly how networks of agents are evolving now, faster than we can study, and have already passed us on nearly every metric. We only have 5-10 years now until the epiphany, the Singularity, AGI.It's so strange to have worked so hard to win the internet lottery when that no longer matters. People will stop buying software. Their AI will deliver their deepest wish, even if that's merely basic resources to survive, that the powers that be deny us to prop up their fever dream of late-stage crony capitalism under artificial scarcity.Everything is about to hit the fan so hard, and I am so here for it.

posts.title: New York’s budget bill would require “blocking technology” on all 3D printers
posts.author: ptorrone
posts.title_cn: 纽约预算案拟要求所有3D打印机配备"阻断技术"
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕纽约州预算案拟要求所有3D打印机安装“阻断技术”的提案展开。核心争议在于该政策是否过度限制技术自由，并可能被滥用为商业垄断工具。

多数用户认为该提案脱离实际。有人指出，美国私人自制枪支本就合法（仅禁止销售），此举是“用不可行的方案解决不存在的问题”。也有用户强调，此举将严重阻碍个人学习制造技术与小微制造业发展，类比“难道要因可能有人制毒就禁止销售面粉和烤箱？”

讨论中多次关联到“维修权”问题，担心制造商可能借技术封锁阻止用户打印替换零件，形成垄断。同时，有用户提醒不应只聚焦技术绕开方式，而应质疑政府提出此类监管的合理性。

分歧点在于对枪支问题的认知：部分用户理解无枪地区政策逻辑，但认为在美国语境下此政策缺乏现实基础；另有观点则坚持从根本上反对私人持枪，但承认现实与理想存在差距。讨论普遍认为该提案可能对纽约州工业产生负面影响，尤其涉及CNC设备时可能引发供应链延迟。

And this is quite likely where all the guns used in existing NY crime come from?)I would also note that the Shinzo Abe doohickey wasn't 3D-printed.

comments.author: mayhemducks
comments.content: This is my attempt to answer your question about "what kind of algorithm can you implement to detect something dangerous". Disclaimer though, I agree that the proposed regulation is way too broad and will have unintended consequences as written.If you look at how Apple detects contraband imagery, they hash every image that gets uploaded into the photos app. Those hashes are transmitted to servers that compare them to hashes of known contraband.A similar system could theoretically be used for STL files. So it isn't about detecting exact shapes, it's about preventing printing of STL files that are already known to be dangerous. This would make it harder to illegally manufacture parts for weapons because it would make it much harder to share designs. If you didn't have the knowledge or skill to design a reliable FCU, you would have to find a design someone with that knowledge and skill created - which the printer could theoretically detect with a cryptographic signature.As the original author of the post pointed out though, this could and would be bypassed by actual criminals. As with most things like this, it's probably impossible to prevent entirely, only to make it more difficult.

观察苹果公司如何检测违禁图像：他们会对上传至照片应用的每张图像进行哈希处理，这些哈希值会被传送到服务器，与已知违禁内容的哈希值进行比对。理论上类似系统也可用于STL文件。因此重点不在于精确识别形状，而是阻止打印已知危险的STL文件。这将增加非法制造武器零件的难度，因为设计图纸的共享会变得困难。如果缺乏设计可靠火控单元的知识或技能，人们就不得不寻找具备相关能力者创建的设计方案——而理论上3D打印机可以通过加密签名检测这类文件。

但正如原文作者指出的，真正的犯罪分子能够也必然会绕过这种限制。与大多数类似情况相同，完全预防或许不可能实现，只能增加其操作难度。

欧元防伪标记是纸币上必须包含的特征，否则它甚至不会被认定为真钞。而这只是_一个_特征。制造能够检测其存在的芯片相对简单。另一方面，如果我需要某个物品的替换零件，制造商不太可能提供相关模型。如果制造商确实提供了模型，他们很可能明确预期我可能会使用这些模型来制造替换件。

posts.author: robin_reala
posts.title_cn: 《华盛顿邮报》记者因启用锁定模式致FBI无法解锁其iPhone》
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕FBI因iPhone启用“锁定模式”而无法访问《华盛顿邮报》记者手机的事件展开，核心话题是移动设备安全与隐私保护的实际效果。有人认为锁定模式等高级安全设置确实有效提升了防御能力，也有用户指出桌面端应用（如Signal）的安全隐患更大，可能成为突破口。讨论中提到，执法机构可能通过生物识别（如Touch ID或Face ID）强制解锁设备，但密码仍受法律保护；同时，用户对默认安全设置的实用性存在分歧，部分人认为厂商应更强调隐私功能而非依赖用户主动调整。共识在于，多层安全措施（如结合PIN码与生物识别）能增强防护，但技术漏洞和司法管辖区差异仍可能影响实际安全性。

comments.author: quenix
comments.content: Forget OS updates. The biggest obstacle to exploit persistence: a good old hard system reboot.Modern iOS has an incredibly tight secure chain-of-trust bootloader. If you shut your device to a known-off state (using the hardware key sequence), on power on, you can be 99.999% certain only Apple-signed code will run all the way from secureROM to iOS userland. The exception is if the secureROM is somehow compromised and exploited remotely (this requires hardware access at boot-time so I don't buy it).So, on a fresh boot, you are almost definitely running authentic Apple code. The easiest path to a form of persistence is reusing whatever vector initially pwned you (malicious attachment, website, etc) and being clever in placing it somewhere iOS will attempt to read it again on boot (and so automatically get pwned again).But honestly, exploiting modern iOS is already difficult enough (exploits go for tens millions $USD), persistence is an order of magnitude more difficult.
comments.content_cn: 别管系统更新了。实现漏洞持久化的最大障碍是：一次彻底的系统重启。现代iOS拥有极其严密的安全信任链引导程序。如果你将设备完全关机（使用硬件按键组合），那么在开机时，你可以99.999%地确定，从安全只读存储器到iOS用户空间，全程运行的都将是经过苹果签名的代码。唯一的例外是安全只读存储器本身被远程攻破并利用（这需要启动时具备硬件访问条件，因此我认为可能性极低）。所以，在全新启动时，你几乎肯定运行的是苹果官方代码。实现某种形式持久化最简单的方法是：重复利用最初入侵你的攻击载体（恶意附件、网站等），并巧妙地将它放置在iOS启动时会再次读取的位置（从而自动再次被入侵）。但说实话，攻击现代iOS已经足够困难（漏洞利用价值数千万美元），而实现持久化更是难上加难。

comments.author: coppsilgold
comments.content: I would not recommend that one trust a secure enclave with full disk encryption (FDE). This is what you are doing when your password/PIN/fingerprint can't contain sufficient entropy to derive a secure encryption key.The problem with low entropy security measures arises due to the fact that this low entropy is used to instruct the secure enclave (TEE) to release/use the actual high entropy key. So the key must be stored physically (eg. as voltage levels) somewhere in the device.It's a similar story when the device is locked, on most computers the RAM isn't even encrypted so a locked computer is no major obstacle to an adversary. On devices where RAM is encrypted the encryption key is also stored somewhere - if only while the device is powered on.
comments.content_cn:
我不建议将全盘加密（FDE）完全托付给安全飞地。当你的密码/PIN/指纹无法提供足够熵值来生成安全的加密密钥时，实际上就是在采取这种做法。低熵安全措施的问题在于：这种低熵信息被用于指示安全飞地（TEE）释放/使用真正的高熵密钥，因此密钥必须以物理形式（例如电压电平）存储在设备的某个位置。

设备锁定时情况也类似——大多数计算机的内存甚至没有加密，因此对攻击者而言，已锁定的计算机并非主要障碍。在内存加密的设备上，加密密钥同样存储在某个位置，至少在设备通电期间是如此。

comments.author: pregnenolone
comments.content: RAM encryption doesn’t prevent DMA attacks and perofming a DMA attack is quite trivial as long as the machine is running. Secure enclaves do prevent those and they're a good solution. If implemented correctly, they have no downsides. I'm not referring to TPMs due to their inherent flaws; I’m talking about SoC crypto engines like those found in Apple’s M series or Intel's latest Panther Lake lineup. They prevent DMA attacks and side-channel vulnerabilities. True, I wouldn’t trust any secure enclave never to be breached – that’s an impossible promise to make even though it would require a nation-state level attack – but even this concern can be easily addressed by making the final encryption key depend on both software key derivation and the secret stored within the enclave.
comments.content_cn: 内存加密并不能防止DMA攻击，只要机器在运行，实施DMA攻击就相当容易。安全飞地确实能防止这类攻击，是一种很好的解决方案。如果正确实施，它们没有任何缺点。我之所以不提及TPM，是因为其固有的缺陷；我指的是像苹果M系列或英特尔最新Panther Lake系列中的SoC加密引擎。它们能防止DMA攻击和侧信道漏洞。确实，我不相信任何安全飞地永远不会被攻破——这是一个不可能实现的承诺，尽管这需要国家级别的攻击才能做到——但即使这种担忧，也可以通过让最终加密密钥同时依赖于软件密钥派生和存储在飞地内的秘密来轻松解决。

posts.title: AI is killing B2B SaaS
posts.author: namanyayg
posts.title_cn: AI正在扼杀B2B SaaS
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕“AI是否正在终结B2B SaaS行业”展开。核心争议在于AI技术是否真能取代传统企业级软件服务。有人认为AI辅助编程已能快速构建定制化软件，甚至替代部分SaaS产品，尤其对于功能简单的CRUD应用，开发者可能选择自行开发而非购买服务。也有用户指出，B2B SaaS的核心价值在于提供维护、安全、合规支持等综合服务，企业付费是为规避内部开发的技术债务和运维负担，这与开源软件存在但企业仍选择付费SaaS的逻辑类似。讨论中提到，当前经济下行可能加速企业削减“包装型”SaaS开支，但多数用户认为B2B领域因需求复杂、注重可靠性，对AI替代的抵抗力较强。共识在于，AI虽可能冲击部分低门槛SaaS，但企业级软件市场更看重长期服务与生态整合，而非单纯的功能实现。

comments.author: bandrami
comments.content: It's a tale as old as time that developers, particularly junior developers, are convinced they could "slap together something in one weekend" that would replace expensive SAAS software and "just do the parts of it we actually use". Unfortunately, the same arguments against those devs regular-coding a bespoke replacement apply to them vibe-coding a bespoke replacement: management simply doesn't want to be responsible for it. I didn't understand it before I was in management either, but now that I'm in management I 100% get it.
comments.content_cn: 这就像是一个老生常谈的故事：开发者们，尤其是初级开发者，总是坚信自己可以“用一个周末拼凑出”替代昂贵SAAS软件的东西，并且“只实现我们真正需要的功能”。不幸的是，那些反对他们常规编码定制替代方案的理由，同样适用于他们凭感觉编码定制替代方案：管理层根本不想为此负责。在我进入管理层之前，我也不理解这一点，但现在我完全明白了。

comments.author: kstrauser
comments.content: OTOH, I was hired by an enterprise that was many months into a giant backend rewrite. After wrapping my head around the many plans, I realized they were rewriting Django, badly. One weekend I prototyped the whole thing… in Django. It worked. It met the specs. It was a CRUD app with a REST API.I came in to work Monday morning, showed it off, and inadvertently triggered a firestorm. Later my boss told me not to do that again because it caused havoc with schedules and such.So I quit and found a better job. Sometimes the new guy can make a better version themselves over the weekend, not because they’re a supergenius, but because they’re not hampered by 47 teams all trying to get their stamp on the project.(In before “prime example of overconfidence!”: feel free to doubt. It was a CRUD app with a handful of models on a PostgreSQL backend. They were writing a new Python web framework to serve it, complete with their own ORM and forms library and validation library. Not because the existing ones wouldn’t work, mind you, but more out of not realizing that all these problems were already sufficiently solved for their requirements.)
comments.content_cn:
另一方面，我入职了一家企业，当时他们正在进行一个庞大的后端重写项目，已经持续了好几个月。在理清了众多计划后，我发现他们正在糟糕地重写Django。某个周末，我用Django原型实现了整个系统……它运行起来了，完全符合规格要求。这只是一个带有REST API的CRUD应用。

周一早上我来到公司，展示了这个原型，却无意中引发了一场轩然大波。后来老板告诉我不要再这样做，因为它打乱了日程安排等等。

于是我辞职了，并找到了一份更好的工作。有时候新人能在一个周末自己做出更好的版本，并非因为他们是超级天才，而是因为他们没有被47个团队都想在项目上留下自己印记的阻碍所束缚。

（在“过度自信的典型例子！”之前说明：尽管怀疑吧。这只是一个在PostgreSQL后端上有少数模型的CRUD应用。他们当时正在编写一个新的Python Web框架来运行它，包括自己的ORM、表单库和验证库。请注意，不是因为现有的工具无法工作，而更多是因为他们没有意识到，对于他们的需求，所有这些问题都已经有足够成熟的解决方案了。）

comments.author: 827a

Most of these companies are, financially, doing pretty well; seeing key metric growth, including revenue and profit. This makes sense: AI does not fundamentally change the bargain SaaS brought to the table, that companies would rather pay someone to solve their problems than solve them themselves. However, the stock market doesn't care about this. The stock market doesn't care about anything; it behaves irrationally and non-sensically, and trying to derive any sense of how stable, strong, or successful a company is from stock market valuation is like using lines of code to claim that a software project is really good.

comments.author: theturtletalks
comments.content: It’s not as far-fetched as people think. I see so many comments here doubting you can vibe code a full CRM or e-commerce SaaS, but a skilled AI-assisted programmer absolutely can, especially if they're aware of strong open-source alternatives already out there.For Salesforce-like CRM, there's Twenty[0], a good-enough alternative. For Shopify-style e-commerce, Medusa[1] is a headless commerce platform.The real power comes from using AI to study how these projects implement specific features (payments, inventory, customer dashboards, etc.) and adapt them to your stack. AI excels at finding the "seams" (those connection points where a feature ties into the tech stack) and grasping the full implementation. The trick is knowing precisely where the feature lives in the code (files, functions, modules), because AIs often miss scattered pieces otherwise. That's what I'm building at opensource.builders[2]: turning OSS repos into a modular cookbook with structured "skills" that point to exact details for reliable remixing and porting.SaaS companies are forever beholden to raising their market cap, even in solved spaces like cart, payment processing, and CRMs. Most businesses run on CRUD apps anyway, and if your core app exposes an API, you can build any customization you need on top of it. People here discounting how valuable it is for a business to have the software that runs their business on a tech stack they understand and something they truly own.[0] https://github.com/twentyhq/twenty[1] https://github.com/medusajs/medusa[2] https://opensource.builders
comments.content_cn:
这并不像人们想的那么牵强。我看到这里有很多评论怀疑能否通过“感觉编程”做出完整的CRM或电商SaaS，但一个熟练的AI辅助程序员绝对可以做到，特别是如果他们了解市面上已有的优秀开源替代方案。对于类似Salesforce的CRM，有Twenty[0]这个足够好的替代品。对于Shopify风格的电商，Medusa[1]是一个无头电商平台。

真正的力量在于利用AI研究这些项目如何实现特定功能（支付、库存、客户仪表盘等），并将其适配到你的技术栈中。AI擅长找到“接缝”（功能与技术栈连接的那些关键点）并理解完整实现。关键在于准确知道功能在代码中的位置（文件、函数、模块），因为AI常常会遗漏分散的代码片段。这就是我在opensource.builders[2]正在构建的：将开源仓库转化为模块化的“食谱”，通过结构化的“技能”指向具体细节，实现可靠的重新组合和移植。

SaaS公司永远受制于提升市值，即使在购物车、支付处理和CRM这些已成熟的领域也是如此。大多数企业本就运行在CRUD应用上，如果你的核心应用提供了API，你可以在其上构建任何需要的定制功能。这里的人们低估了一家企业拥有基于自己理解的技术栈、真正属于自身的业务软件所带来的价值。

[0] https://github.com/twentyhq/tw...

comments.author: d_watt
comments.content: I think one of the interesting things here is that AI doesn't need to be able build B2B SaaS to kill it. So much of the overhead of B2B SaaS companies is thinking about multitenancy, intergrating with many auth providers and mapping those concepts to the program's user system, juggling 100 features when any given customer only needs 10 of them, creating PLG upsell flows to optimize conversions, instrumenting A/B tests etc...A given company or enterprise does not have to vibe code all this, they just need to make the 10 features with the SLA they actually care about, directly driven off the systems they care about integrating with. And that new, tight, piece of software ends up being much more fit for purpose with full control of new features given to company deploying it. While this was always the case (buy vs build), AI changes the CapEx/OpEX for the build case.
comments.content_cn: 我认为这里一个有趣的点在于，人工智能无需具备构建B2B SaaS的能力就足以颠覆这个领域。B2B SaaS公司的大量运营成本都耗费在思考多租户架构、对接多种身份验证提供商并将这些概念映射到程序的用户系统、同时维护上百个功能而每个客户实际只需其中十个、设计产品引导式升级流程以优化转化率、搭建A/B测试体系等方面……而具体的企业或公司其实不必为所有这些功能编写代码，他们只需要专注于开发自己真正需要的十个功能，并确保这些功能直接与其关心的集成系统对接，同时满足实际在意的服务等级协议。这种新型的紧凑型软件最终能更精准地满足特定需求，且部署方对新功能拥有完全控制权。虽然"购买还是自建"的抉择始终存在，但人工智能改变了自建方案的资金投入与运营成本结构。

comments.author: epolanski
comments.content: > How to keep asking customers for renewal, when every customer feels they can get something better built with vibe-coded AI products?Wrong take. You don't need to build something better, you only need something good enough that matches what you actually need. Whether you build it or not and ditch the SaaS is more of an economic calculus.Also, this isn't much about ditching the likes of Jira not even mentioning open source jira clones exists from decades.This is more of ditching the kind of extremely-expensive-license that traps your own company and raises the price 5/10% every year. Like industrial ERP or CRM products that also require dedicated developers anyway and you spend hundreds of thousands if not millions for them. Very common, e.g. for inventory or warehouse management.For this kind of software, and more, it makes sense to consider in-housing, especially when building prototypes with a handful of capable developers with AI can let you experiment.I think that in the next decade the SaaS that will survive will be the evergreen office suite/teams, because you just won't get people out of powerpoint/excel/outlook, and it's cheap enough and products for which the moat is mostly tied to bureaucratic/legal issues (e.g. payrolls) and you just can't keep up with it.
comments.content_cn:
当每位客户都觉得自己能用AI编码产品打造出更好的方案时，该如何持续争取客户续约？这个思路不对。你不需要做出更优的产品，只需提供足够匹配实际需求的方案即可。是否自行开发并弃用SaaS，更多是经济层面的考量。

此外，这并非指要抛弃Jira这类工具——毕竟开源仿制品已存在数十年。重点在于摆脱那些捆绑企业、年复一年涨价5%-10%的天价授权软件。例如工业ERP或CRM系统，它们本就需配备专职开发人员，企业投入动辄数十万甚至数百万美元。这在库存或仓储管理等领域尤为常见。

对于这类软件，考虑自研是合理的，尤其是当少数能力出众的开发者借助AI就能快速构建原型进行验证时。我认为未来十年能够存活的SaaS，将是那些经久不衰的办公套件/协作工具（因为人们离不开PowerPoint/Excel/Outlook），以及那些护城河主要建立在行政/法律壁垒（如薪酬系统）上、外部难以跟进的品类。前者价格足够亲民，后者则因合规复杂性形成天然壁垒。

comments.author: btown
comments.content: > What they don’t know, though, is that a poorly architected system will fail, eventually. As every senior programmer (eventually) understands, our job is complex because we have to understand the relationships in the real world, the processes involved, and the workflows needed, and representing it in a robust way to create a stable system. AI can’t do that.I have a strong feeling the future's going to look like this:Company vibe codes to replace a SaaS.Little do they know this creates a time bomb: fragile systems where fundamental architectural defects are papered over by humans who knew the underlying dynamics but didn't articulate them well enough during the initial "vibe-architecture," so they're forced to patching the "impedance mismatches" with data entry or with even more vibe coding.Those humans are eventually laid off, because of course they are. Data quality rapidly deteriorates. Operational mishaps deteriorate relationships with human counterparties. Defects begin to cost thousands to millions.Suddenly, there's demand: not for SaaS, but for actual service businesses. Consultancies that can parachute in, do actual domain-driven design, and un-vibe that code. They do have a stronger-than-ever pool of out-of-work engineers (many from the failed SaaS companies).The SaaS companies that survive understand that the first S no longer stands for Software; it stands for Solutions.
comments.content_cn:
然而他们不知道的是，架构糟糕的系统终将崩溃。正如每位资深程序员（最终）都会理解的，我们的工作之所以复杂，是因为必须理解现实世界中的关联、相关流程与必要工作流，并以稳健的方式将其呈现出来，从而构建稳定的系统。人工智能无法做到这一点。

我强烈预感未来将呈现这样的景象：企业用氛围代码替代SaaS。他们殊不知这埋下了定时炸弹——脆弱的系统中，根本性的架构缺陷被那些了解底层动态却未能在初期"氛围架构"中清晰表述的人类所掩盖，于是他们被迫通过数据录入甚至更多氛围编码来修补"阻抗失配"问题。

这些人最终会被裁员，这是必然的结局。数据质量急剧恶化。运营失误损害与人类合作方的关系。系统缺陷开始造成数千至数百万的损失。

突然间，市场需求转向：不再是SaaS，而是真正的服务业务。咨询公司能够空降现场，实施真正的领域驱动设计，清除那些氛围代码。他们确实拥有比以往更庞大的失业工程师资源池（其中许多人来自失败的SaaS公司）。

幸存下来的SaaS公司终于明白：首字母S不再代表软件，而是解决方案。

comments.author: noduerme
comments.content: My career occupies a weird middle ground where, for 20 years or so, I've catered to smaller businesses that need bespoke solutions (because the SaaS available doesn't conform well to their business logic), but don't have the scale or desire to build and maintain software in-house. Sometimes these are slapped together in a weekend, if that's all that's needed. But in most cases they still become ongoing improvement and maintenance projects for me.This niche position has had some interesting ramifications for them and for me. They clearly incur a lot of technical debt once their business relies on bespoke software. On the other hand, they own the software and can get an immediate response or new feature or upgrade from me, limited only by my time. And in the end, this ends up saving them time and money. It gives me a permanent and unending flow of work. But if I die, they're pretty screwed.One reason I don't vibe code things even now, even simple components that could easily be vibe coded, is that I remember and know where everything is, every function or line of code that might be causing issues, because I wrote it myself. I know right away where to look for a query that might be throwing errors after a database upgrade, for instance.As a manager I assume you would probably not want to go down the road of hiring someone like that, but for companies of a certain size it's an acceptable compromise. However, I wouldn't want to hire someone like that myself unless they were extremely reliable and didn't rely on AI to write any of their code.
comments.content_cn:
我的职业生涯处于一种奇特的中间地带：二十年来，我一直服务于那些需要定制化解决方案的小型企业（因为现有的SaaS产品难以适配其业务逻辑），但这些企业既没有规模也没有意愿自主构建和维护软件。有时这些方案只需一个周末就能仓促搭建完成——如果客户仅需如此。但在大多数情况下，它们仍会成为我持续优化和维护的项目。

这种特殊定位对客户和我本人都产生了有趣的影响。一旦企业业务依赖于定制软件，它们显然会背负大量技术债务。但另一方面，他们完全拥有软件所有权，并能随时获得我的即时响应、新功能开发或升级服务——唯一限制因素是我的时间。最终这反而为他们节省了时间和成本。对我而言，这带来了永无止境的工作流。可如果我遭遇不测，他们就会陷入困境。

即便到现在，我仍不愿使用可视化编程工具——哪怕是那些能轻松通过可视化构建的简单组件——原因在于我亲手编写了所有代码，因此能清晰记忆每个功能模块和可能引发问题的代码段的位置。例如，数据库升级后若出现查询异常，我能立刻定位问题根源。

作为管理者，您或许不愿雇佣我这类人员，但对于特定规模的企业而言，这仍是一种可接受的折中方案。不过，若非要雇佣这类人员，除非他们具备极致的专业素养……

comments.author: mschuster91
comments.content: > In the 1990s there were people who thought OOP with point and click tools like FoxPro and Delphi would make it so easy to create software that everything could be built in-house without expert programmers. The invention of SQL was supposed to eliminate roles like Report Writer and Data Analyst because now business people could just write their own queries "in English" and get back answers.And yet, precisely that happened in the end, just not with the tools envisioned. Excel, VBA and, where you had one knowledgeable employee, MS Access makes for incredibly powerful and incredibly hard to maintain "shadow IT" - and made even more difficult when someone sneaked in a password, because that takes a bit of an effort to remove [1], knowledge that is easy for us today to find, but not when I was young.Also, back in the IE6 era, there was a lot of point-and-click created web interfaces... just that it wasn't HTML5 or even HTML. It was an <object> tag loading some ActiveX written by some intern in VB6, or Java, or Flash. I sort of miss that era but also, it was a damn security nightmare. Flash with its constant stream of security vulnerabilities was ripe for exploits, but at least it didn't run native code with full user privileges by design. I'm not kidding, theoretically you could go and import/use functions from any system DLL up to and including Kernel32. OLE/OCX, ActiveX... a design way ahead of its time.[1] https://stackoverflow.com/questions/272503/removing-the-pass...
comments.content_cn: 上世纪90年代，有人认为使用FoxPro和Delphi这类点击式工具的面向对象编程会让软件开发变得极其简单，以至于无需专业程序员就能内部构建一切。SQL的发明本应消除报表编写员和数据分析师这类角色，因为业务人员现在可以直接"用英语"编写查询并获取答案。然而，最终这种情况确实发生了，只是并非通过预想的工具实现。Excel、VBA以及在某些有技术员工的场景下使用的MS Access，构成了极其强大却难以维护的"影子IT"系统——当有人偷偷设置密码时情况会更棘手，因为清除密码需要费些功夫[1]，这种知识如今对我们来说很容易获取，但我年轻时并非如此。此外，在IE6时代，存在大量通过点击操作创建的网页界面……只不过它们用的不是HTML5甚至不是标准HTML，而是由实习生用VB6、Java或Flash编写的ActiveX控件加载在<object>标签里。我有些怀念那个时代，但那确实是个安全噩梦。Flash持续不断的安全漏洞极易被利用，但至少它的设计初衷并非以完整用户权限运行原生代码。说真的，理论上你甚至可以从系统DLL（包括Kernel32）导入和使用函数。OLE/OCX、ActiveX……这些设计理念远远超前于它们的时代。[1] https://stackoverflow.com/questions/272503/removing-the-pass...
