posts.title: A sane but bull case on Clawdbot / OpenClaw
posts.author: brdd
posts.title_cn: 关于Clawdbot/OpenClaw的合理但乐观的预测
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕Clawdbot/OpenClaw这类AI助手工具的实际效用与风险展开。核心争议在于其是否真正提升了生活效率，以及用户隐私与安全是否得到保障。

许多用户质疑其必要性：有人认为记录冰箱库存或追踪Airbnb价格等操作过于繁琐，且现有应用已能实现类似功能；也有用户指出，让AI直接管理银行账户或拥有2FA权限存在显著安全隐患，建议使用独立账户进行风险隔离。讨论中提到，部分支持者将这类工具视为缓解生活焦虑的“服务型陪伴”，但反对者强调AI仍会犯错，而作者可能未充分验证其可靠性。

社区普遍认同的是，当前AI工具的实际价值可能被高估，且安全措施至关重要。分歧主要集中在对效率提升的判断上——一方认为这些自动化流程节省了心智负担，另一方则认为其操作成本甚至高于手动处理。此外，有用户注意到，对AI持怀疑态度的人往往只接触过其受限版本，这可能影响他们的评价。

comments.author: louiereederson
comments.content: - Why do you need a reminder to buy gloves when you are holding them?- Why do you need price trackers for airbnb? It is not a superliquid market with daily price swings.- Cataloguing your fridge requires taking pictures of everything you add and remove which seems... tedious. Just remember what you have?- Can you not prepare for the next day by opening your calendar?- If you have reminders for everything (responding to texts, buying gloves, whatever else is not important to you), don't you just push the problem of notification overload to reminder overload? Maybe you can get clawdbot to remind you to check your reminders. Better yet, summarize them.
comments.content_cn:
- 你手里正拿着手套，为什么还需要提醒去买手套？
- 爱彼迎的价格为什么需要追踪器？这又不是价格每日波动的超流动性市场。
- 给冰箱里的东西编目录需要拍下每样放入和取出的物品，这似乎……太繁琐了。记住有什么不就行了？
- 难道你不能通过打开日历为第二天做准备吗？

comments.author: mmahemoff
comments.content: Giving access to "my bank account", which I take to mean one's primary account, feels like high risk for relatively low upside. It's easy to open a new bank (or pseudo-bank) account, so you can isolate the spend and set a budget or daily allowance (by sending it funds daily). Some newer payment platforms will let you setup multiple cards and set a separate policy on each one.An additional benefit of isolating the account is it would help to limit damage if it gets frozen and cancelled. There's a non-zero chance your bot-controlled account gets flagged for "unusual activity".I can appreciate there's also very high risk in giving your bot access to services like email, but I can at least see the high upside to thrillseeking Claw users. Creating a separate, dedicated, mail account would ruin many automation use cases. It matters when a contact receives an email from an account they've never seen before. In contrast, Amazon will happily accept money from a new bank account as long as it can go through the verification process. Bank accounts are basically fungible commodities, can easily be switched as long as you have a mechanism to keep working capital available.
comments.content_cn:
允许访问“我的银行账户”——我理解为主要账户——感觉风险高而收益相对有限。开设新的银行（或类银行）账户很容易，因此可以通过隔离消费、设置预算或每日限额（通过每日转账）来控制风险。一些新兴支付平台还支持设置多张卡片并为每张卡设定独立的使用规则。

隔离账户的另一个好处是，万一账户被冻结或注销，能有效限制损失。由机器人控制的账户因“异常活动”被标记的风险并非为零。

我能理解让机器人访问电子邮件等服务也存在极高风险，但至少对追求刺激的Claw用户而言，其高收益潜力可见一斑。创建独立专用的邮箱会破坏许多自动化使用场景——当联系人收到陌生账户的邮件时，体验会大打折扣。相比之下，只要通过验证流程，亚马逊很乐意接受新银行账户的付款。银行账户本质上是可替代的商品，只要有维持流动资金的机制，切换账户并不困难。

comments.author: oersted

posts.title: 1 kilobyte is precisely 1000 bytes?
posts.author: surprisetalk
posts.title_cn: "1千字节正好是1000字节吗？"
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕“1KB是否严格等于1000字节”展开，核心争议在于计算机存储容量单位应采用二进制（1024进制）还是十进制（1000进制）标准。有人认为内存测量基于计算机架构的二进制组织模式，坚持1KB=1024B是行业传统；也有用户指出存储设备厂商长期使用十进制单位（如硬盘容量），且国际单位制（SI）前缀标准化具有优势。讨论中提到，部分用户支持使用“kibibyte”（KiB）等二进制单位以明确区分，但实践中许多人仍习惯传统叫法。分歧主要在于：一方主张保留二进制单位体系（尤其在内存领域），另一方认为应统一采用十进制或明确区分两种标准。共识在于，多数用户承认两种标准并存的现状，且认为明确单位定义（如使用KiB/MiB）有助于减少混淆。

comments.author: kstrauser
comments.content: I'm sticking with power-of-2 sizes. Invent a new word for decimal, metric units where appropriate. I proposed[0] "kitribytes", "metribytes", "gitribytes", etc. Just because "kilo" has a meaning in one context doesn't mean we're stuck with it in others. It's not as though the ancient Greeks originally meant "kilo" to mean "exactly 1,000". "Giga" just meant "giant". "Tera" is just "monster". SI doesn't have sole ownership for words meaning "much bigger than we can possibly count at a glance".Donald Knuth himself said[1]:> The members of those committees deserve credit for raising an important issue, but when I heard their proposal it seemed dead on arrival --- who would voluntarily want to use MiB for a maybe-byte?! So I came up with the suggestion above, and mentioned it on page 94 of my Introduction to MMIX. Now to my astonishment, I learn that the committee proposals have actually become an international standard. Still, I am extremely reluctant to adopt such funny-sounding terms; Jeffrey Harrow says "we're going to have to learn to love (and pronounce)" the new coinages, but he seems to assume that standards are automatically adopted just because they are there.If Gordon Bell and Gene Amdahl used binary sizes -- and they did -- and Knuth thinks the new terms from the pre-existing units sound funny -- and they do -- then I feel like I'm in good company on this one.0: https://honeypot.net/2017/06/11/introducing-metric-quantity....1: https://www-cs-faculty.stanford.edu/~knuth/news99.html
comments.content_cn:
我坚持使用2的幂次方大小。在适当场合为十进制、公制单位创造新词。我曾提议[0]使用“kitribytes”、“metribytes”、“gitribytes”等术语。不能因为“千”在某个语境中有特定含义，就认定它必须被套用于所有场景。古希腊人最初使用“kilo”时也并非特指“恰好一千”。“Giga”原意只是“巨大”，“Tera”本意为“怪物”。国际单位制并没有垄断这些表示“远超目测计数范围”的词汇所有权。

唐纳德·克努特本人曾指出[1]：
> 那些委员会的成员提出这个重要议题值得肯定，但当我听闻他们的提案时，感觉它注定无法推行——谁会自愿用MiB来表示“可能字节”呢？因此我提出了上述建议，并将其写入了《MMIX导论》第94页。如今令我惊讶的是，委员会提案竟已成为国际标准。但我仍极不情愿采用这些听起来古怪的术语；杰弗里·哈罗说“我们必须学会接受（并念出）”这些新造词，但他似乎认为标准仅凭存在就能自动获得采纳。

既然戈登·贝尔和吉恩·阿姆达尔都使用二进制大小——他们确实如此——而克努特也认为基于既有单位创造的新术语听起来滑稽——它们确实如此——那么在这件事上，我觉得自己与这些杰出人士站在了同一阵线。

作者在将信息论转换为国际单位制方面探讨得不够深入。国际单位制试图用自然界中感知到的常数来固定标准度量。一米（距离）是光在真空中往返传播的距离，对应铯原子特定次数的振荡（时间）。这并不意味着我们会调整米的定义以符合观测结果——毕竟如果光速真的是30万公里/秒而非约299792公里/秒，大家会更满意。

另一个问题在于不应混用不同的度量单位。国际单位制的设计初衷是将所有度量统一为相同的十进制指数体系（如厘米、米、千米对比英尺、英寸和码）。但作者试图解决这个问题时，甚至未能符合我们预期的标准化国际单位制。

什么是字节？有时是8比特。
什么是千比特？1000比特。
什么是千字节？1000字节或1024字节。
现在我们已经混用了基于比特或字节定义的单位，同时还在1000或1024的指数基础上增加了8倍乘数。

如果你认为比特至少是信息的最小可分单位，这甚至是不正确的。如果信息单位确实需要重新规范，你可能会同意“0”的数量才是信息的最小可分单位。一千个“0”就是1000个零。一个“字节”可定义为最多包含256个零。一个“兆零”可包含多达一百万个零。这对任何人来说都缺乏直观意义……

comments.author: wtallis
comments.content: NAND flash has overprovisioning even on a per-die basis, eg. Micron's 256Gbit first-generation 3D NAND had 548 blocks per plane instead of 512, and the pages were 16384+2208 bytes. That left space both for defects and ECC while still being able to provide at least the nominal capacity (in power of two units) with good yield, but meant the true number of memory cells was more than 20% higher than implied by the nominal capacity.The decimal-vs-binary discrepancy is used more as slack space to cope with the inconvenience of having to erase whole 16MB blocks at a time while allowing the host to send write commands as small as 512 bytes. Given the limited number of program/erase cycles that any flash memory cell can withstand, and the enormous performance penalty that would result from doing 16MB read-modify-write cycles for any smaller host writes, you need way more spare area than just a small multiple of the erase block size. A small portion of the spare area is also necessary to store the logical to physical address mappings, typically on the order of 1GB per 1TB when tracking allocations at 4kB granularity.
comments.content_cn: NAND闪存即使在单个晶片层面也存在过度配置，例如美光第一代256Gbit 3D NAND每个平面包含548个区块而非512个，每页容量为16384+2208字节。这种设计既为缺陷修复和纠错码预留空间，又能以良好良率提供至少标称容量（以2的幂次单位计），但意味着实际存储单元数量比标称容量隐含值高出20%以上。十进制与二进制计量差异形成的弹性空间，主要用于应对必须整块擦除16MB区块的不便，同时允许主机发送小至512字节的写入指令。考虑到任何闪存单元可承受的编程/擦除周期数有限，且若为较小主机写入操作执行16MB读取-修改-写入循环将导致巨大性能损失，所需备用空间远不止擦除区块大小的整数倍。部分备用区域还需存储逻辑至物理地址映射表，按4kB粒度追踪分配时，通常每1TB容量需约1GB映射空间。

国际单位制前缀的含义不由惯例、普遍用法或古老传统决定，而是由国际单位制本身规定，这有充分的理由。我们曾有几千年时间依靠地方和贸易传统来设定度量衡，那是一场噩梦，这也正是我们最终采用国际单位制的原因。计算领域若重蹈覆辙，立即重新制造长吨和短吨的混乱局面，绝非明智之举。

comments.author: soneil
comments.content: It goes back way further than that.  The first IBM harddrive was the IBM 350 for the IBM 305 RAMDAC.  It was 5 million characters.  Not bytes, bytes weren't "a thing" yet. 5,000,000 characters. The very first harddrive was base-10.Here's my theory. In the beginning, everything was base10.  Because humans.Binary addressing made sense for RAM.  Especially since it makes decoding address lines into chip selects (or slabs of core, or whatever) a piece of cake, having chips be a round number in binary made life easier for everyone.Then early DOS systems (CP/M comes to mind particularly) mapped disk sectors to RAM regions, so to enable this shortcut, disk sectors became RAM-shaped.  The 512-byte sector was born.  File sizes can be written in bytes, but what actually matters is how many sectors they take up.  So file sizing inherited this shortcut.But these shortcuts never affected "real computers", only the hamstrung crap people were running at home.So today we have multiple ecosystems.  Some born out of real computers, some with a heavy DOS inheritance.  Some of us were taught DOS's limitations as truth, and some of us weren't.
comments.content_cn:
它的历史远比那更久远。第一台IBM硬盘是用于IBM 305 RAMDAC的IBM 350。它存储500万个字符——不是字节，当时字节的概念还未形成。最早的硬盘采用的是十进制计数。

我的理论是这样的：起初，所有事物都基于十进制，因为人类习惯如此。二进制寻址对内存来说很合理，特别是它能轻松将地址线解码为芯片选择信号（或磁芯存储块等），让芯片数量以二进制整数形式存在，这为所有人简化了工作。

后来早期的DOS系统（尤其是CP/M）将磁盘扇区映射到内存区域，为了实现这种快捷操作，磁盘扇区便采用了类似内存的结构。512字节扇区由此诞生。文件大小可以用字节表示，但真正重要的是它们占用了多少扇区。因此文件大小的计算沿用了这种快捷方式。

但这些快捷方式从未影响“真正的计算机”，只限制了家用电脑的性能发挥。

所以今天我们拥有多种生态系统：一些诞生于真正的计算机，一些则深受DOS传统影响。我们中有些人被灌输DOS的局限性为真理，而另一些人则没有。

comments.content: > setting weights and measures by local and trade tradition and it was a nightmareAdding to your point, it is human nature to create industry- or context-specific units and refuse to play with others.In the non-metric world, I see examples like: Paper publishing uses points (1/72 inch), metal machinists use thousands of an inch, woodworkers use feet and inches and binary fractions, land surveyors use decimal feet (unusual!), waist circumference is in inches, body height is in feet and inches, but you buy fabric by the yard, airplane altitudes are in hundreds to tens of thousands of feet instead of decimal miles. Crude oil is traded in barrels but gasoline is dispensed in gallons. Everyone thinks their usage of units and numbers is intuitive and optimal, and everyone refuses to change.In the metric(ish) world, I still see many tensions. The micron is a common alternate name for the micrometre, yet why don't we have a millin or nanon or picon? The solution is to eliminate the micron. I've seen the angstrom (0.1 nm) in spectroscopy and in the discussion of CPU transistor sizes, yet it diverts attention away from the picometre. The bar (100 kPa) is popular in talking about things like tire pressure because it's nearly 1 atmosphere. The mmHg is a unit of pressure that sounds metric but is not; the correct unit is pascal. No one in astronomy uses mega/giga/tera/peta/etc.-metres; instead they use AU and parsec and (thousand, million, billion) light-years. Particle physics use eV/keV/MeV instead of some units around the picojoule.Having a grab bag of units and domains that don't talk to each other is indeed the natural state of things. To put your foot down and say no, your industry does not get its own special snowflake unit, stop that nonsense and use the standardized unit - that takes real effort to achieve.

根据地方和行业传统设定度量衡简直是一场噩梦。正如你所说，人类天性就是创造行业或特定场景下的单位，并拒绝与其他体系兼容。在非公制世界里，我看到这样的例子：出版业使用点（1/72英寸），金属机械师使用千分之一英寸，木匠使用英尺、英寸和二进制分数，土地测量员使用十进制英尺（少见！），腰围用英寸衡量，身高用英尺和英寸衡量，但买布料却按码计算，飞机高度用数百到数万英尺表示而非十进制英里。原油交易按桶计量，汽油却按加仑出售。每个人都认为自己使用的单位和数字直观且最优，且都拒绝改变。

posts.title: Lessons learned shipping 500 units of my first hardware product
posts.author: sberens
posts.title_cn: 首批500件硬件产品出货的经验教训
posts.abstract:
该帖子讨论了硬件产品从设计到量产的经验教训。作者分享了首批500件产品的生产历程，引发社区对硬件创业挑战的广泛讨论。

多数用户认同硬件开发复杂度常被低估，有人指出“亲手制造实物与软件开发存在巨大差异”。讨论中提到中国供应链的双面性：既有用户称赞其能实现高性能低成本生产，也有人认为过度追求成本控制可能导致质量隐患，例如“为节省微薄成本使产品快速损坏”。

关于生产策略存在分歧：有人认为小批量手工试产可降低初期风险，也有用户指出直接量产是验证市场的必要步骤。产品设计方面，部分用户赞赏高流明灯具的创新性，但对主动散热设计提出疑问。此外，有用户关注到认证流程的缺失，质疑频繁修改设计是否影响最终测试。

普遍共识是：对产品的极致关注是首批订单成功的关键，而经验积累将优化后续批次。多位用户结合自身硬件创业经历表示共鸣，认为这类实践分享极具参考价值。

comments.author: ggm
comments.content: This is the second article about hardware supply from China I've read and it reads very much the same, albiet in a different niche (the other one was about SBC construction) -Anything you don't specify will be done least cost, and there is no amount of "least" which cannot be chased in manufacture.The other one noted if you don't specify the density of plastic for bags, or paper for bags and packing, you get clingfilm thinner than you thought existed, and paper which is almost tissue in its weakness. You don't even get boxes to put the boxes in, if you don't specify boxes to be delivered in boxes. So now wrapping a pallet becomes a nightmare if they don't stack. And if you don't specify how many to stack, and how to pad the stack, they won't do unit height stacking if it costs labour time. Your risk.Some of this like the casting mistake, or the knob thing, could happen anywhere and you have to be close to final manufacture spec to find out e.g. the metal coating impinges on the knob at the free space you specified, because your test rig didn't have powder coating. Or, that a design feature you need like the light entry holes, is used by the casting engineer as pour points because it looked like you'd specified mould pour points not functional holes.But other things like "yea, you didn't spec how long to make the tails so we cut the tails as close as we could" is just the cheapening above: if you don't SAY its a 10cm tail for the connector, it will be 2cm, if saving 8cm of cable saves money for them.I've read some stuff which says the cost of 5 SBC boards with pre-applied SMD is now so low, you might as well order 5 so you get at least 1 which works. That means they will wind up working out your tolerance for failure, and produce goods to meet that: if 1 in 5 is viable, thats what they'll target.
comments.content_cn:
这是我读到的第二篇关于中国硬件供应的文章，内容大同小异，只是领域不同（另一篇是关于单板机结构的）——任何你没有明确指定的细节，都会以最低成本的方式处理，而且在制造过程中，对“最低”成本的追求是没有底线的。另一篇文章提到，如果你没有规定包装袋塑料的密度或纸张的厚度，你得到的塑料薄膜会薄得超乎想象，纸张则脆弱得几乎像纸巾。如果你没有要求箱子必须装在更大的箱子里运输，你甚至不会得到外包装箱。这样一来，如果货物堆叠不稳，托盘包装就会变成一场噩梦。如果你没有规定堆叠层数和缓冲方式，他们绝不会为了增加工时而去进行单元高度堆叠。风险全由你承担。

其中一些问题，比如铸造错误或旋钮问题，在任何地方都可能发生，你必须接近最终制造规格才能发现。例如，金属涂层侵入了你指定的旋钮自由空间，因为你的测试设备没有粉末涂层。或者，你需要的设计特征（如透光孔）被铸造工程师当成了浇注点，因为他们认为你指定的是模具浇注点而非功能孔。

但其他情况，比如“是的，你没规定线尾要多长，所以我们尽可能剪短了线尾”，这纯粹是上述降低成本的做法：如果你没有说明连接器需要10厘米的线尾，他们就会只留2厘米，只为节省那8厘米的线材……

comments.author: mtlynch
comments.content: Congrats on launching your first 500 units!I had a similar experience. I quit my job as a SWE at Google and built a hardware product on top of the Raspberry Pi.[0]I don't really have anything helpful to add, but I relate a lot to all of the gotchas you encountered. Shipping a hardware product made me appreciate software so much more, especially SaaS products where you can ship a fix immediately.With hardware, it's painfully easy to make a mistake and not realize it for 3-6 months. And by that point, you have this whole manufacturing pipeline you have to halt and unwind. And with overseas manufacturing, tariffs, and shipping costs, you can't even unwind some of this stuff, and you just end up with useless material that you paid 5-6 figures for.We're definitely spoiled in the software world with the relative ease of fixing bugs.[0] https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=23927380
comments.content_cn: 恭喜你首批500台产品成功上市！我也有过类似的经历。我辞去了谷歌软件工程师的工作，基于树莓派开发了一款硬件产品。[0]虽然我没有什么特别有用的建议可以补充，但对你遇到的所有难题都深有同感。做硬件产品让我更加体会到软件的好，尤其是SaaS产品可以即时推送修复补丁。在硬件领域，犯一个错误却要等3-6个月后才察觉的情况实在太常见了。到那时，整个生产线都不得不暂停并回溯处理。加上海外制造、关税和运输成本，有些环节甚至无法逆转，最终只能堆积价值五六位数的废料。软件世界里我们能相对轻松地修复漏洞，这确实让我们被宠坏了。[0] https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=23927380

comments.content:

Your Murphy's law references are spot on; I feel comforted reading I'm not the only one this happens to! Misery does love company, and it's important to hang on that I think, so that you don't lose hope :)
comments.content_cn: 无论你是否拥有类似的个人经历，这篇文章都写得很好，能带来深刻见解。作为一名同时从事硬件和软件工作的人，我深有体会创造实体产品所面临的挑战——人们很容易低估这两者之间的难度差异。你对墨菲定律的引用十分精准；读到并非只有自己遭遇这些事，我感到宽慰！痛苦确实喜欢有人相伴，我认为坚持这一点很重要，这样才不会失去希望。

comments.author: jasonkester
comments.content: That's the thing that drives me nuts about buying stuff manufactured in China.They'll make this amazing Remote Control Car, with good suspension, a battery that lasts half an hour, plenty of power, and just all around amazing.  But then it'll break after a day because somebody saved 1/20th of a penny by speccing this impossibly thin wire the thickness of a human hair to hook that powerful battery to the powerful motor and inside the remote.They could have used actual wire-sized wire and had the most amazing product ever, for roughly zero more cost.  (Possibly less, since surely it must cost _more_ to manufacture and solder micron-diameter wiring).  It just makes no sense.
comments.content_cn: 这就是购买中国制造产品最让我抓狂的地方。他们能造出这么棒的遥控车——悬挂系统出色，电池续航半小时，动力充沛，各方面都令人惊叹。但用了一天就坏了，就因为有人为了省下不到半分钱，选用了细如发丝的导线来连接大功率电池和强力电机以及遥控器内部。他们本可以用正常规格的电线，以几乎零成本造出绝世好产品（甚至可能更省钱，毕竟焊接微米级导线肯定成本更高）。这完全说不通。

comments.author: pinkmuffinere
comments.content: I would not advise jumping to mass production for your first deliveries, i think your story would have had less stress and more lower risk of failure of the first n (maybe 10?)  units was bespoke, made lovingly by hand in a machine shop somewhere. I don’t think this is unusual advice, it matches the ethos of the lean startup, and pg’s “do things that don’t scale”.We made our first hardware by hand, i believe we did 15 units. I remember my cofounder broke down because he couldn’t take the pressure of receiving fifteen orders and now we had to make FIFTEEN by hand, lol. But we were able to figure out SO MANY issues before mass production. And of course even then many slipped through
comments.content_cn: 我不建议首批交付就贸然进入大规模生产。我认为，如果最初那批（也许是10台？）产品能采用定制化方式，由某个机械车间精心手工制作，你的创业历程会减少许多压力，首批产品失败的风险也会更低。这并非特立独行的建议，它符合精益创业的理念，也与保罗·格雷厄姆“做无法规模化之事”的主张不谋而合。我们的首款硬件就是手工制作的，大概做了15台。我记得当时我的联合创始人差点崩溃——接到15个订单后，他难以承受必须手工制作整整十五台产品的压力，现在回想起来确实令人莞尔。但正是这种方式让我们在大规模生产前发现了大量问题。当然即便如此，许多瑕疵还是未能避免。

comments.author: Taek
comments.content: I'm late to this thread but I've manufactured about a dozen SKUs and I think you could have saved an enormous amount of grief with one simple step:If you are American, and you are manufacturing 500 units, do it in America. Yes, it's more expensive per-unit, but at 500 units you don't need a tiny per-unit cost.American manufacturing is more flexible, higher agency, and people tend to adapt to underspecified instructions better. The communication loops are stronger.That said, America has enormous tradeoffs. If you need 10,000 of a part in 4 hours because something weird happened, China can make it happen. America... might take months. But if your batch size is 500, it's better for an American living in America to cut their teeth on American manufacturing and go to China when you need 10,000+ units per run.

美国制造业更灵活，自主性更强，人们更擅长处理不明确的指令，沟通回路也更顺畅。

当然，美国制造也有明显短板。如果因突发状况需要在4小时内生产1万个零件，中国能做到，而美国可能需要数月。但若批量仅为500件，对生活在美国的创业者而言，更适合先通过美国制造积累经验，等到单次产量需要1万件以上时再转向中国。

comments.author: syntaxing
comments.content: As a MechE turned SWE, always a fun read when SWE try hardware.> Blink and you’ll get a different measurement.This means your environment is not controlled enough. Also quality control is usually done in terms of statistics. You might want to read something called gauge R&R. That being said, you should be proud of being able to ship a physical product!As for quality checks, software quality teams pales in comparison to hardware quality teams. Mainly as you said, there’s a lot checks you can do in software. For hardware, bigger companies have to have their vendors qualified. The vendors have to follow their customer guidelines and do outgoing inspection. Then the company has a division to do incoming inspection. There’s a traveler that follows the kit (of parts) and there’s usually subassembly quality checks. Then final full build checks before it leaves the door.

comments.author: starky
comments.content: A lot of success in working with suppliers in China (and really anywhere in Asia) is in building a relationship with them where they know exactly what your expectations are and holding them to it until they understand that it is just easiest for them to do it right to start.I've got suppliers who I can send a difficult part to and know that I'm going to get exactly what I expect, faster and cheaper than just about anyone else. It took a few years to get to that point, but these few vendors make it really hard to go with anyone else, much to the chagrin of the sourcing team who rightly recognize it a risk to rely on just a few suppliers.Once you get to a certain type of supplier you end up running into the problem where their processes are such that they won't do anything without you clearly documenting it. They simply refuse to make any assumptions on your behalf. They can be so frustrating when you are used to the other way of doing it. I simply cannot answer some questions because I'm so used to my other suppliers just doing it correctly and haven't ever asked about it.
comments.content_cn:
在中国（乃至整个亚洲地区）与供应商成功合作的关键在于建立稳固的关系，让他们清晰了解你的期望并坚持要求，直到他们明白从一开始就按要求行事才是最省力的方式。我有一些供应商，即使寄去复杂部件，也能确保获得完全符合预期的产品，速度更快、成本更低，几乎无人能及。虽然达到这种默契需要数年时间，但这几家供应商让我很难再考虑其他选择，这让采购团队颇为苦恼——他们正确地意识到过度依赖少数供应商存在风险。

当你与某些类型的供应商合作时，会遇到这样的问题：他们的流程要求你必须提供明确书面说明，否则绝不采取任何行动。他们完全拒绝替你做出任何假设。如果你习惯了另一种合作方式，这种情况会令人非常沮丧。有些问题我根本无法回答，因为我早已习惯其他供应商能直接正确处理，从未被问及此类细节。

posts.title: Xcode 26.3 – Developers can leverage coding agents directly in Xcode
posts.author: davidbarker
posts.title_cn: Xcode 26.3 – 开发者可直接在 Xcode 中利用编码助手
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕Xcode 26.3版本更新展开，核心话题是开发者对Xcode集成AI编程助手功能（Coding Agents）的反应及对Xcode工具本身的长期评价。多数用户对Xcode本身持批评态度，有人认为Xcode稳定性差、体验糟糕，甚至比喻为“噩梦”，也有用户指出其长期存在基础性问题，急需专注于修复漏洞和优化而非追逐新功能。部分开发者对AI功能表示期待，认为自主运行的编码代理能提升效率，尤其适合长期任务。讨论中提到版本更新信息不透明，有用户质疑实际改进内容被营销宣传模糊。分歧点在于：一方认为AI集成是积极进步，另一方则批评苹果忽视基础质量。共识是Xcode作为开发工具存在显著缺陷，社区对其可靠性普遍不满。此外，有用户讽刺性地将AI部门进展与前高管离职关联，并担忧AI生成的代码可能降低应用质量。

comments.author: AJRF
comments.content: (Context: I was an iOS dev for 10 years on well known, large iOS apps - I can't explain how much I dislike Xcode).I recently started working for a startup, and they wanted an app.What I shipped was a react native app (so I don't need to go in to Xcode to build), that renders a full screen web browser that points to our website. I've sprinkled in bits of injected JS to capture our cookies and local/session storage - which then gets saved to device storage and reinjected on app startup.There are a few native-ish bits sprinkled in - onboarding, notifications, error screens, loading indicators, etc - but for the most part we don't need to worry about our API borking old versions (which is moving extraordinarily fast).The only semi tricky bit was native auth integration - that needs treated with a bit more care, and stored securely, but it took a few days.I ship the app to TestFlight and the AppStore using Fastlane from the command line, match handles the certs, and I never have to open Xcode.It is honestly bliss, and i've heard a lot of app developers moving to this model (interestingly it normally follows a failed SDUX implementation)
comments.content_cn: （背景：我曾作为iOS开发者，在知名大型iOS应用上工作了十年——我无法形容自己有多讨厌Xcode）。最近我加入了一家初创公司，他们需要一款应用。我交付的是一个React Native应用（这样我就不必用Xcode来构建），它渲染了一个全屏网页浏览器，直接指向我们的网站。我加入了一些注入的JavaScript代码来捕获我们的cookie和本地/会话存储——这些数据随后会保存到设备存储中，并在应用启动时重新注入。应用中还融入了一些原生功能，比如新手指引、通知、错误界面、加载指示器等——但大部分情况下，我们无需担心API与旧版本不兼容的问题（因为我们的迭代速度非常快）。唯一稍显棘手的部分是原生身份验证集成——这需要更谨慎地处理，并安全存储，但只花了我几天时间。我通过命令行使用Fastlane将应用发布到TestFlight和AppStore，match工具处理证书，而我完全不需要打开Xcode。说实话，这简直是天堂，而且我听说很多应用开发者都在转向这种模式（有趣的是，这通常是在SDUX实施失败之后发生的）。

Dennis Ritchie solved this.Why, Apple, in 40 years, could you not ship a lightweight dev-oriented text viewer? You had NeXTSTEP. You had the DNA of the most elegant Unix workstation ever built.And you gave us... this behemoth? An app whose launch time rivals a full Gentoo stage 1 install ( see: https://niden.net/post/gentoo-stage-1-installation )TextEdit is not the answer.I've used Xcode for native iOS development and honestly, once you get past the Stockholm Syndrome phase, it's just fine.- The interface is learnable.- The debugger mostly works.But the load times -- on every high-end MBP I've ever owned -- suggest that somewhere deep in the Xcode binary, there's a sleep(rand()) that someone committed in 2006 and no one has had the courage to git blame.FWIW, I fear someone here tells me I've been missing a launch flag. comments.author: r2vcap
comments.content:
From my years of iOS development—and based on https://xcodereleases.com typically ships two major Xcode updates each year:- X.0 (September): bumps Swift, SDK versions, etc. It also tends to have a noticeably longer beta cycle than other releases.
- X.3 or X.4 (around March): bumps Swift again and raises the minimum required macOS version.Other releases in between are usually smaller updates that add features or fix bugs, but they don’t involve major toolchain-level or fundamental changes.Today’s release doesn’t bump the Swift version, which suggests the core toolchain is essentially the same as Xcode 26.2—so it makes sense that the minimum macOS version wasn’t raised either.
comments.content_cn:
根据我多年的iOS开发经验，并参考https://xcodereleases.com的信息，Xcode通常每年发布两次重大更新：
- X.0版本（9月）：更新Swift和SDK版本等。与其他版本相比，其测试周期往往明显更长。
- X.3或X.4版本（约3月）：再次更新Swift并提高最低macOS系统要求。
期间的其他版本通常是添加功能或修复漏洞的小幅更新，不涉及工具链层面或根本性变更。
今日发布的版本未更新Swift版本，这表明其核心工具链与Xcode 26.2基本相同——因此未提高最低macOS系统要求也在情理之中。

comments.author: Aloisius
comments.content: While I don't quite have the same problems as others have, there are some pain points.Stepping through the debugger too fast will sometimes put the debugger in a weird state where step never breaks again and all other breakpoints stop working.Git pull through the UI with stash and merge can blow away your local changes if there is a conflict. The changes aren't stashed. They're just gone.Xcode likes to sometimes recompile files that haven't changed slowing everything down, sometimes significantly depending on the file. No idea why.It can get very confused if you're missing a parenthesis in the wrong place in  a SwiftUI View leading to opaque swift compiler errors about code being too complex.Even mildly complex use of a swift #Predicate will cause an error about it being too complex forcing you to break them down into smaller pieces and even then it takes far too long to build even on a brand new machine.The simulators are quite slow to start/update/run and xcode sometimes fails to shut them down completely when quitting leading to them just continually running eating memory unless you kill the processes manually.The simulators also are really limited in their functionality. No background processes, spotlight, network degradation simulation, out of memory killer, etc.The profiler sometimes just fails to start an app correctly, immediately ending a run forcing you to close the profiler and reopen it again before it'll start working.Symbol refactor (rename) can be painfully slow where the UI just locks up until it can find all the references.Xcode likes to duplicate package dependencies in xcodeproj. It just creates new hashes for the same library and adds it as a dependency over and over again, so when the link phase happens, it adds libraries repeatedly over and over and over again unless you manually clear them out. Not sure what causes this, perhaps updating the version or merges between users.
comments.content_cn: 虽然我没有遇到和其他人完全相同的问题，但确实存在一些痛点。调试器步进过快时，有时会使其进入异常状态，导致单步调试无法中断且所有断点失效。通过界面执行带贮藏合并的Git拉取操作时，若存在冲突可能直接清除本地修改——这些改动不会被贮藏，而是彻底消失。Xcode有时会重新编译未更改的文件，严重拖慢速度，具体影响取决于文件大小，原因不明。在SwiftUI视图中括号位置错误时，可能引发晦涩的编译器报错（提示代码过于复杂），令人困惑。即使中等复杂度的Swift #Predicate使用也会触发“过于复杂”的错误，迫使开发者拆解代码片段，且即使在全新设备上编译耗时也异常漫长。模拟器启动/更新/运行速度迟缓，Xcode退出时有时无法完全关闭模拟器进程，导致其持续占用内存，需手动终止进程。模拟器功能存在严重局限：不支持后台进程、全局搜索、网络降级模拟、内存耗尽终止机制等。性能分析器有时无法正常启动应用，会立即结束运行，必须重启分析器才能恢复工作。符号重构（重命名）功能运行速度可能极其缓慢……

comments.author: trinix912
comments.content: Mostly the fact that for the past 10 years they've been adding new features but never finished them and taken the time to properly bugfix them along the way. Just a few I ran into recently:- Interface Builder is stuck in early 2010s. Not only is the property panel missing half of options we now take for granted everywhere else (like corner radius), it also randomly won't read fonts in the current project, will crash the entire IDE if you Cmd-Z a big change (things like unembedding a view) and half the UI is still not rendered the way it will be on the phone. Yes, Swift UI exists, but most bigger apps are still XIBs and Storyboards and it's going to remain that way for quite some time.- Autocomplete is a hit or miss. Very much like the mid-90s Microsoft IDEs where you'd get totally useless results until you've typed the whole line out already. It can be done well, look at AppCode.- Syntax highlighting feels pretty much the same. Randomly flashes on and off, often doesn't highlight until return is pressed, takes a long time to load on large files etc.- Git integration is by far the worst I've seen out of any IDE and I've seen many. I'd go as far as to say that SourceSafe integration in VB6 was done better. Just the whole layout, modal-on-modal returning to the first modal on an error in the second and so on. It's crashed when rebasing a few times too, I don't trust it with larger operations since.- Documentation browser is this annoying little window with semi-useful search. But don't worry, the docs in there are useless anyways. I could go on and on about their approach to docs but maybe next time.Don't even get me started on performance. Things like switching file tabs should be instant by now but there are still noticeable delays for larger files and IB screens. Plus there's now two kinds of tabs (app-level and file-level) to add to the mess.
comments.content_cn: 主要是过去十年里他们一直在添加新功能，却从未真正完成这些功能，也没有花时间在开发过程中妥善修复漏洞。仅举几个我最近遇到的例子：界面构建器还停留在2010年代初期的水平。不仅属性面板缺失了如今在其他地方习以为常的一半选项（比如圆角半径），还会随机无法读取当前项目中的字体，如果你用Cmd-Z撤销一个大改动（比如取消嵌入视图）就会导致整个IDE崩溃，而且一半的UI渲染效果仍与手机端显示不一致。是的，Swift UI确实存在，但大多数大型应用仍在使用XIB和Storyboard，这种情况还会持续相当长的时间。自动补全功能时好时坏，很像90年代中期微软的IDE——在你完整输入整行代码前，给出的建议结果基本没用。这方面明明可以做得更好，看看AppCode就知道了。语法高亮功能也差不多：随机闪烁开关，经常要按回车键才高亮显示，大文件加载耗时极长等等。Git集成是我在所有IDE中见过最差的（我用过很多IDE），甚至可以说VB6的SourceSafe集成做得都比这强。整个布局设计、模态窗口层层嵌套出错时跳回原模态窗口等问题层出不穷。我在变基操作时也遇到过几次崩溃，现在根本不敢用它处理大型操作。文档浏览器是个恼人的小窗口，搜索功能半残不全……

comments.author: flohofwoe
comments.content: My pain points are mostly in the CPU debugger (since I'm not using much of the actual "IDE features" of Xcode except the regular edit-compile-debug loop anyway.Starting a 'cold' debug session into a UI application may take 10-ish seconds until applicationDidFinishLaunching is reached, and most of that time seems to be spent with loading the symbols for hundreds of framework DLLs which are loaded during application start (which I never even need because I can't step into system frameworks anyway) - and seriously, why are there even hundreds of system DLLs in a more or less hello-world-style Metal application with minimal UI? This problem seems to go back to the ancient times, but it gets worse and worse the bloatier macOS UI processes become (e.g. the more system frameworks they load at start).The debugger variable view panel is so bare bones that it looks like it's ripped out straight from an 80's home computer monitor program.When debug-stepping, the debugger frontend is quite often stuck for 10s of seconds at completely unpredictable places waiting for the debugger to respond (it feels like a timeout).Step-debugging in general feels sluggish even compared to VSCode with lldb.For comparison, VS2026 isn't exactly a lightweight IDE either, but debugging sessions start instantly, debug-stepping is immediate, and the CPU debugger is much more feature rich than Xcode's. While in Xcode, everything feels like it's been added as a checklist item, but then never actually used by the Xcode team (I do wonder what they're using to develop Xcode, I doubt that they are dogfooding their own work).The one good and useful thing about Xcode is the Metal debugger though.
comments.content_cn:
我的痛点主要集中在CPU调试器上（毕竟除了常规的编辑-编译-调试循环外，我基本没怎么使用Xcode的实际“IDE功能”）。启动一个“冷”调试会话进入UI应用程序可能需要大约10秒才能到达applicationDidFinishLaunching，其中大部分时间似乎都花在了加载数百个框架DLL的符号上——这些DLL在应用程序启动时被加载（而我根本不需要它们，因为反正我也无法进入系统框架进行单步调试）。说真的，为什么在一个近乎“Hello World”风格、只有最简UI的Metal应用程序中，竟然会有数百个系统DLL？这个问题似乎可以追溯到远古时代，但随着macOS UI进程变得越来越臃肿（例如启动时加载的系统框架越来越多），情况也愈发恶化。

调试器的变量查看面板极其简陋，看起来像是直接从80年代的家用电脑监控程序中扒出来的。在调试单步执行时，调试器前端经常会在完全无法预测的位置卡住10多秒，等待调试器响应（感觉像是超时）。即使与使用lldb的VSCode相比，整体单步调试也显得迟钝。

作为对比，VS2026也算不上轻量级IDE，但调试会话可以即时启动，调试单步执行响应迅速，而且CPU调试器的功能远比Xcode丰富得多。而在Xcode中，所有功能都像是为了凑清单而添加的，但实际根本没人使用……

comments.author: Eric_WVGG
comments.content: Like you, I think that Xcode maybe gets a worse rap than it deserves, but it's also endlessly frustrating.First, the performance is just bad. The responsiveness compared to apps like VSC or Panic’s Nova is night-and-day.The attention given to the design of new features is piss-poor. Placing the AI functionality on the left sidebar makes no sense; all the other tools on the left are project management; the "let me run weird functions and interact with stuff" UIs like terminal, debug and logs are in the bottom panel. Or maybe a new tab in the main workspace area?The SwiftUI preview canvas can't be floated as a separate window, making it all but useless on anything smaller than a 16" MBP (and only barely usable there). In fact, I think it might be impossible to use Xcode in multiple screens altogether…?Old simulator versions and cache files hang around forever, you need a third-party app like DevCleaner just to keep your storage from filling with nonsense. Cryptic messages like "copying symbols to device"… clear-cache that doesn't seem to clear-cache, that stupid list UI for info.plist…I never thought I'd have anything nice to say about PNPM package management, but you can always just delete `node_modules` and reinstall and count on things working. Swift package management is a cryptic mess, and their insistence on using a GUI instead of a basic JSON manifest just compounds it. Like the info.plist thing, a lot of Xcode is based on a developer UI philosophy from the Mac Classic days that has mostly been abandoned by the rest of the world.Mostly, I think the vitriol surrounding Xcode is that Apple seems to think they're doing a good job; meanwhile their most ardent and adept users are insisting that they are not. Same boat as MacOS, really.

comments.author: aylmao
comments.content: If you told people in 2006 that 20 years later the best open-source IDE would be open-source, web-based and come from Microsoft, they would've thought you're crazy.Back then Apple had made waves introducing Safari, which was not only great and cross-platform, but had an open-source renderer (WebKit), and JavaScript engine (JSC). Safari was crushing web standards while IE lagged, seemingly trying to purposefully choke the web to stop it from canibalizing Windows software. Apple was betting on web: one of the big features on their brand-new Mac OS 10.4 Tiger was the Dashboard with widgets that were all built with HTML/CSS/JS, and they were shipping a new, free IDE (Dashcode) to build them too.Mac OS X was heavily marketed for being UNIX vs Microsoft's proprietary and closed Windows NT. They were building Safari and iTunes for Windows, and had just introduced the first Intel Macs; it seemed like they were out to put a fight against a very closed, very walled, and very incompatible Microsoft who had gotten too comfortable with the Wintel and IE monopolies.Fast-forward two decades, and not only can you now run a native GNU/Linux environment on Windows, but the best IDE out there is web-based and open-source Microsoft software while Apple lags behind on developer experience. They seems to have missed the bus on web technologies too. They went from leading charge with a stellar browser pushing web standards forward, to being an obstacle out of fear Safari might canibalize iOS software.Apple hasn't gone full early-2000s Microsoft (thankfully) and Microsoft hasn't gone full early-2000s Apple (unfortunately) but times have really changed.
comments.content_cn:
如果在2006年告诉人们，20年后最好的开源集成开发环境将是开源的、基于网页的，并且来自微软，他们一定会觉得你疯了。那时候苹果公司凭借推出Safari浏览器掀起波澜，它不仅优秀且跨平台，还拥有开源渲染引擎（WebKit）和JavaScript引擎（JSC）。Safari当时正大力推动网页标准，而IE却落后了，似乎有意阻碍网络发展以保护Windows软件市场。苹果当时正押注于网络技术：其全新Mac OS 10.4 Tiger系统的一大亮点是Dashboard组件，这些组件完全由HTML/CSS/JS构建，他们还推出了免费的集成开发环境Dashcode来支持开发。

Mac OS X当时以UNIX系统的开放性为卖点，与微软封闭的Windows NT形成鲜明对比。苹果不仅为Windows开发Safari和iTunes，还刚刚推出了首批英特尔芯片的Mac电脑；看起来他们正全力挑战那个因Wintel联盟和IE垄断而安于现状、封闭且兼容性差的微软。

二十年后的今天，不仅能在Windows上运行原生的GNU/Linux环境，最好的集成开发环境竟是微软开发的基于网页的开源软件，而苹果在开发者体验方面却落后了。他们似乎也错过了网络技术的发展浪潮，从曾经凭借卓越浏览器引领网页标准推进的先锋，变成了因担心Safari影响iOS软件生态而阻碍进步的障碍……

posts.title: Banning lead in gas worked. The proof is in our hair
posts.author: geox
posts.title_cn: 禁止汽油加铅成效显著，证据就在我们的头发中。
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕含铅汽油禁令的有效性展开，核心话题是环境法规对公共健康的积极影响。多数用户认同禁令显著降低了人体铅含量，认为这是环境监管的成功案例，并支持加强类似措施。讨论中提到，有用户指出历史上有企业故意掩盖含铅汽油危害，强调监管的必要性；也有用户认为当前美国政治人物可能受铅中毒影响，导致政策推进不足。分歧点在于环境法规的范围与力度：部分人主张区分有效与有害的监管，避免“一刀切”；另有用户担忧特朗普政府削弱铅相关法规，并提到香料掺假等新的铅暴露风险。共识在于，铅禁令被普遍视为一项关键的健康保护成就，但执行速度和监管持续性仍是关注焦点。

comments.author: cfiggers
comments.content: In my opinion it is obvious and should be uncontroversial that some environmental regulations work and are great and should if anything be reinforced, while other environmental regulations do more harm than good and need to be reigned in or eliminated.Turning "environmental regulation" into a unified bloc that must be either supported or opposed in totality is a manipulative political maneuver and it should be forcefully rejected.Regulations are not people, and they don't have rights. It is fair and reasonable to demand that environmental regulation justify its existence with hard, scientifically verifiable data or else get chopped. Clearly, banning leaded gasoline has that kind of justification, and therefore I'm strongly in favor of maintaining that ban and extending it wherever it isn't in place yet. The same reasonable standard should be applied to other regulations across the board.
comments.content_cn: 在我看来，某些环境法规行之有效且意义重大，甚至应当进一步加强；而另一些环境法规则弊大于利，需要加以约束或废除——这是显而易见且不应存在争议的。将“环境法规”塑造成一个必须全盘支持或全盘反对的统一阵营，实为一种操纵性的政治手段，我们应当坚决抵制。法规不是人，不享有权利。要求环境法规必须凭借确凿可靠、可科学验证的数据证明其存在的合理性，否则就应被废除，这是公平且合理的。显然，禁止含铅汽油就具备这样的正当依据，因此我坚决支持维持这项禁令，并将其推广至尚未实施的地区。同样的合理标准也应普遍适用于其他所有法规。

comments.content: Humans were able to successfully fry food for hundreds of years before Teflon was invented.I still like non-stick pans for eggs, but for almost everything else, I prefer stainless steel, cast iron, or enameled cast iron. You do have to pay a little more attention to technique (knowing what temperature to heat the pan to before you put food on, etc.), but the end result is just about as good as a non-stick pan with many advantages:* You don't have to be obsessive about never letting a metal utensil scratch the pan. (I hope you aren't using a metal spatula or fork with your non-stick!)* You can scrape the hell out of the pan while you cook and get all that delicious crispy fond into what you're making. If I'm doing a pan sauce, it's always in the Dutch oven so I can get that fond into the gravy.* They last a lot longer. Even if you are careful, a non-stick pan will lose its coating and need to be replaced after a handful of years. I got my cast iron skillet for $15 at an antique store. It's older than me and will outlive me.* You're not, you know, eating forever chemicals.

comments.author: throwway120385
comments.content: It's really easy to sit and demand evidence before regulating something. But consider that if we waited for hard evidence to accumulate before banning lead in gasoline, we likely never would have banned it because the hard evidence wouldn't exist.I also don't agree on the principle that regulations are "harmful" or "helpful."  Rather, you have to define who the regulation harms, and who it helps. For example antitrust enforcement harms shareholders and some employees of very large firms, but it helps many employees and arguably improves the landscape for competition between many smaller firms. So whether a regulation is preferable comes down to values.In the case of leaded gas, it harms basically everybody, but it helps fuel companies, so it was an easy thing to change.

posts.title: Agent Skills
posts.author: mooreds
posts.title_cn: 代理技能
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕AI代理技能（Agent Skills）的标准化与实用价值展开。核心争议在于技能文档（如AGENTS.md）的必要性与形式。有人认为这类文档与普通英文说明无异，强调编写清晰文档的原则并未改变；也有用户指出技能格式的真正价值在于渐进式披露，通过轻量索引让代理按需调用指令，从而节省上下文资源。讨论中提到，技能可作为获取未明言领域规则的有效方式，迫使开发者记录隐性知识，并反馈给LLM公司用于训练。部分用户主张标准化技能文件夹结构，而另一些则建议将技能内容融入README.md等人可读文档，实现人机共用。尽管存在分歧，社区普遍认同技能应设计为完整、自包含的工作流，而非被动背景信息，且当前代理常需显式调用才能使用技能。

comments.author: clarity_hacker
comments.content: The real value isn't the format itself — it's progressive disclosure. When you dump everything into one monolithic doc, you're burning context tokens on instructions the agent doesn't need for the current task.Skills as a pattern let the agent scan a lightweight index of descriptions, then pull in the full instructions only when relevant. Whether that's a .skills/ folder or a README index pointing to separate docs doesn't matter much. What matters is the separation between "what capabilities exist" and "how to execute this specific one."The standardization part is mostly useful for distribution — being able to install and share skills across projects without manually wiring them up. Same reason we standardize package formats even though you could just copy-paste code.
comments.content_cn:
真正的价值不在于格式本身，而在于渐进式呈现。当你把所有内容堆砌在单一文档中时，实际上是在为智能体当前任务不需要的指令消耗上下文资源。

技能作为一种模式，允许智能体先扫描轻量级的描述索引，仅在相关时调用完整指令。无论是采用.skills/文件夹形式，还是通过README索引指向独立文档，这些形式差异并不重要。关键在于区分“存在哪些能力”与“如何执行特定能力”这两个层面。

标准化部分的主要价值在于分发——能够跨项目安装和共享技能，而无需手动配置。这就像我们之所以标准化软件包格式，即便直接复制粘贴代码也能实现相同功能。

comments.author: Soerensen
comments.content: The observation about agents not using skills without being explicitly asked resonates. In practice, I've found success treating skills as explicit "workflows" rather than background context.The pattern that works: skills that represent complete, self-contained sequences - "do X, then Y, then Z, then verify" - with clear trigger conditions. The agent recognizes these as distinct modes of operation rather than optional reference material.What doesn't work: skills as general guidelines or "best practices" documents. These get lost in context or ignored entirely because the agent has no clear signal for when to apply them.The mental model shift: think of skills less like documentation and more like subroutines you'd explicitly invoke. If you wouldn't write a function for it, it probably shouldn't be a skill.
comments.content_cn:
关于智能体不被明确要求就不使用技能的观察确实引起共鸣。在实践中，我发现将技能视为明确的"工作流程"而非背景信息更为有效。成功的模式是：将技能设计为完整、独立的操作序列——"先做X，再做Y，然后做Z，最后验证"——并设置清晰的触发条件。智能体会将这些识别为特定的操作模式，而非可选的参考资料。

无效的做法是：将技能作为通用指导原则或"最佳实践"文档。这些内容往往淹没在上下文中或被完全忽略，因为智能体没有明确信号指示何时应该应用它们。

思维模式的转变是：将技能看作更像是需要显式调用的子程序，而非文档资料。如果你不会为某个操作编写函数，那它很可能也不应该成为一个技能。

comments.author: DonHopkins
comments.content: You've nailed the core insight about progressive disclosure. MOOLLM extends this into what we call the Semantic Image Pyramid (or MOO-Maps ;), borrowing from Mip-Maps in graphics. Four resolution levels, each serving different needs.GLANCE.yml is the smallest, 5-70 lines. Just enough to answer "is this relevant?" You can inject all glances into every prompt because they're tiny. The LLM scans them like a table of contents.CARD.yml is the interface layer, 50-200 lines. No implementation, just what the skill offers Capability advertisements, activation conditions, scoring, what it composes with. Think of it like The Sims "advertisement" system or CLOS generic function dispatch. The LLM sniffs this to decide whether to load the full SKILL.md implementation.SKILL.md is the Anthropic-style skill file, 200-1000 lines. The actual instructions, the how. Only loaded when the skill is activated.README.md is the largest, 500+ lines, and it's for humans. History, design rationale, examples. The LLM can dive in when developing the skill or when curious, but it's not burned on every invocation.Reading rule: never load a lower level without first loading the level above. Start with GLANCE, sniff the CARD, load SKILL only if needed.Even more compact than concatenating all glances:We also found INDEX.md beats INDEX.yml for the skill catalog. YAML repeats the same keys for every entry. Markdown allows narrative explanation of how skills relate, which clusters matter for what tasks, making it both more compact and more useful.INDEX.yml: 711 lines, 2061 words, 17509 chars, ~4380 tokens, machine readable structurehttps://github.com/SimHacker/moollm/blob/main/skills/INDEX.y...INDEX.md: 124 lines, 1134 words, 9487 chars, ~2370 tokens, human readable prosehttps://github.com/SimHacker/moollm/blob/main/skills/INDEX.m...INDEX.md is 83% fewer lines, 45% fewer words, 46% fewer chars for 121 skills. YAML repeats keys like id, tagline, why for every entry. Markdown uses headers and prose, compresses better, allows narrative grouping of related skills.And it's simply more meaningful to both LLMs and humans, telling a coherent story instead of representing raw data!The Semantic Image Pyramid:https://github.com/SimHacker/moollm/blob/main/designs/LEELA-...Same principle applies to code. A skill can wrap a sister-script that IS the documentation. A Python script with argparse defines the CLI once, readable by both humans (--help) and LLMs (sniff the top of the python file). No separate docs to maintain, no drift between what the code does and what the docs claim.sister-script: https://github.com/SimHacker/moollm/blob/main/skills/sister-...Sniffable-python structures code so the API is visible in the first 50 lines. Imports, constants, CLI structure up front. Implementation below the fold. The LLM can decide relevance and understand the API without reading the whole file. Single source of truth, progressive disclosure, don't repeat yourself.sniffable-python README.md: https://github.com/SimHacker/moollm/blob/main/skills/sniffab...sniffable-python SKILL.md: https://github.com/SimHacker/moollm/blob/main/skills/sniffab...

你精准把握了渐进式披露的核心思想。MOOLLM将这一理念延伸为我们所称的语义图像金字塔（或称MOO-Maps，借鉴了图形学中的Mip-Maps概念）。它包含四个分辨率层级，各满足不同需求。

GLANCE.yml是最精简的，约5-70行。它刚好能回答“这个内容相关吗？”的问题。由于体量极小，你可以将所有概览文件注入每个提示中。大语言模型会像浏览目录一样扫描它们。

CARD.yml是接口层，约50-200行。它不包含具体实现，只描述技能提供的能力——功能说明、激活条件、评分标准、可组合性。可以类比为《模拟人生》的“广告”系统或CLOS泛型函数调度机制。大语言模型通过嗅探这一层来决定是否加载完整的SKILL.md实现文件。

SKILL.md是遵循Anthropic风格的技能文件，约200-1000行。包含实际的操作指南和实现方法，仅在技能激活时加载。

README.md是最大型的文档，500行以上，面向人类读者。涵盖历史背景、设计原理和示例说明。大语言模型在开发技能或需要深入理解时可以查阅，但不会在每次调用时载入。

阅读规则：必须按层级顺序加载，不可跳过上级直接加载下级。从GLANCE开始，嗅探CARD，仅在需要时加载SKILL。

比简单拼接所有概览更精妙的是：
我们还发现对于技能目录，INDEX.md的表现优于INDEX.yml。YAML格式需要为每个条目重复相同键名，而Markdown允许叙述性说明技能间的关联性，解释哪些技能集群对特定任务更重要，这使得……

我理解你的怀疑态度，这确实是经典模式的再现——人们总是习惯将旧范式中的做法生搬硬套到新范式上，并期待它能奏效。某些方面或许相似，但随着新范式（无论好坏）运行逻辑的本质差异逐渐显现，这种套用往往会导致颠覆性结果，相关实践必须重新构思。事实上，我怀疑整个“智能体”概念也存在同样问题。这似乎是对现实运行机制认知模式的一种倒退。

我们最初持有的认知模型可能更接近真相：即“将任务输入单一的无定形引擎”。我认为智能体概念的核心本质是拟人化倾向——试图用我们熟悉的“管理者”“团队”“专业化分工”等现有认知框架，来理解人工智能执行任务的方式。虽然某些场景下这种做法有效，但这很可能不是理解本质的正确思路，甚至可能产生反效果。这不过是一种具有局限性的抽象概括。

比如当我看到大型咨询公司宣称部署了成千上万个智能体时，不禁质疑这种表述的实际意义——或许这只是为了让咨询服务购买者更容易理解和接受概念而设计的营销话术，毕竟将计费工时对应到具体实体总是更易操作。

comments.author: empath75
comments.content: They're basically all trade-offs between context-size/token-use and flexibility.  If you can write a bash or a python script, or an api or an MCP to do what you want, then write a bash or python script to do it.  You can even include it in the skill.My general design principle for agents, is that the top level context (ie claude.md, etc) is primarily "information about information", a list of skills, mcps, etc, a very general overview, and a limited amount of information that they always need to have with every request.  Everything more specific is in a skill, which is mostly some very light touch instructions for how to use various tools we have (scripts, apis and mcps).I have found that people very often add _way_ to much information into claude.md's and skills.  Claude knows a lot of stuff already!  Keep your information to things specific whatever you are working on that it doesn't already know.  If your internal processes and house style are super complicated to explain to claude and it keeps making mistakes, you might want to adapt to claude instead of the other way around.  Claude itself makes this mistake!  If you ask it to build a claude md, it'll often fill it with extraneous stuff that it already knows.  You should regularly trim it.
comments.content_cn:
这些本质上都是在上下文长度/令牌使用量与灵活性之间做权衡。如果你能用bash或Python脚本、API或MCP实现想要的功能，那就直接写脚本处理。你甚至可以把脚本集成到技能里。

我设计智能体的核心原则是：顶层上下文（比如claude.md等文件）主要承载“关于信息的信息”——比如技能列表、MCP配置等概览性内容，以及每个请求都必须携带的少量核心信息。所有具体功能都应放在技能中实现，技能文件通常只需简要说明如何使用各类工具（脚本、API和MCP）。

我发现人们经常在claude.md和技能文件里塞进_过量_信息。Claude本身已经具备大量知识！请只保留与你当前工作相关且Claude尚未掌握的具体信息。如果你的内部流程和规范体系对Claude来说过于复杂难懂，导致频繁出错，或许应该调整你的工作方式去适应Claude，而非强求Claude适应你。Claude自己也会犯这种错误！如果你让它生成claude.md文件，它往往会填入大量冗余的已知信息。你需要定期精简这些内容。

posts.title: 221 Cannon is Not For Sale
posts.author: mecredis
posts.title_cn: "221 加农炮" 非卖品
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕房产诈骗问题展开，用户分享了个人经历与应对建议。核心话题涉及虚假房产信息在Facebook等平台传播，导致业主受到骚扰或产权风险。

多数用户认为平台方（如Facebook）对虚假广告缺乏有效监管，投诉常被忽视。有用户建议通过法律途径直接联系平台法务部门，利用其规避风险的心理推动处理。也有用户指出，主动在房产平台（如Zillow）申明产权或设置实体告示牌可能起到警示作用。

讨论中提到，不同地区对此类诈骗的防范机制存在差异。例如英国用户提及土地登记系统的邮件通知功能可提供预警，而印度案例则显示跨国产权欺诈难以追责。部分用户主张采取“钓鱼执法”手段诱捕诈骗者，但此做法存在争议。

共识在于，房产诈骗已成为跨国性现象，平台责任与产权保护制度是关键争议点。分歧则体现在具体应对策略上，从技术防范到主动反击，观点不一。

comments.author: ivraatiems

Facebook completely ignores any and all attempts by me to report this malfeasance -- even though these ads literally have my personal home address on them!It's a huge safety risk to me and not due to anything I did whatsoever; all I did was buy a house that was on the market and then move into it. It's a nightmare.
comments.content_cn: 有人根据Facebook上的一则虚假帖子找到我家，询问是否出租，那帖子用的是Zillow上我买房之前的照片。我的房产经纪人帮我删除了照片，但Facebook上的相关广告至今仍在。尽管这些广告明确显示了我的家庭住址，Facebook却完全无视我举报此恶意行为的所有尝试！这对我构成了巨大的安全风险，而原因与我本人所作所为毫无关系；我只是买了一套挂牌出售的房子然后搬了进去。这简直是一场噩梦。

comments.author: angry_octet
comments.content: The best remedy for this is a Land Title Registry, which is a secure database of who owns a parcel of land, and a mandated verification of identity (VoI) standard. You no longer require title deeds, notaries, or title insurance. It isn't totally proof against sophisticated social engineering and gullibility of course, but it is a lot safer.For registry titles you can also add caveats, that require sign-off from another party before transactions can occur. Unfortunately the contact address is still purely snail mail, no email or phone numbers. If you title has a bank mortgage that will appear as a caveat, requiring the debt to be discharged before it can be removed, and that also involves more ID verification.https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Torrens_titlehttps://www.firstlinks.com.au/why-our-torrens-title-property...
comments.content_cn: 解决这一问题的最佳方案是建立土地产权登记制度，即建立一个记录每块土地所有者的安全数据库，并强制执行身份验证标准。这样一来，就不再需要地契、公证或产权保险。当然，这并不能完全防范复杂的社会工程学和轻信行为，但安全性已大幅提升。对于登记产权，还可以添加限制条款，要求交易必须获得另一方签署同意。遗憾的是，联系地址仍仅限于传统邮寄方式，不提供电子邮件或电话号码。如果产权涉及银行抵押，则会以限制条款形式显示，需在债务清偿后方可解除，此过程还需进行更多身份验证。

posts.title: Claude is a space to think
posts.author: meetpateltech
posts.title_cn: Claude是一个思考空间
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕Anthropic公司发布的“Claude是一个思考空间”博客文章展开，核心话题是AI助手Claude的商业模式和价值观定位，特别是其“无广告”承诺与OpenAI等竞争对手的差异。社区观点呈现多元：有人认为这是公司在顺境时的价值观宣传，类似谷歌早期“不作恶”口号，未来可能难以坚持；也有用户指出无广告模式更符合AI作为“思考工具”的定位，避免行为操纵，并赞赏Anthropic专注于企业订阅的可持续商业模式。讨论中提到部分用户实际欢迎搜索引擎中“标注清晰的广告”，认为能提供商业意图信息，反对仅由SEO优化的内容主导结果。共识方面，多数用户肯定Claude在代码开发和商业自动化中的实用性，认为其与ChatGPT的聊天机器人定位形成差异化；同时肯定Anthropic在AI可解释性、支持监管等方面的积极姿态。分歧主要在于对“无广告”承诺的长期信任度，以及AI中广告是否必然有害的认知差异。

comments.author: 4corners4sides
comments.content: This is one of those “don’t be evil” like articles that companies remove when the going gets tough but I guess we should be thankful that things are looking rosy enough for Anthropic at the moment that they would release a blog like this.The point about filtering signal vs. noise in search engines can’t really be stated enough. At this point using a search engine and the conventional internet in general is an exercise in frustration. It’s simply a user hostile place – infinite cookie banners for sites that shouldn’t collect data at all, auto play advertisements, engagement farming, sites generated by AI to shill and produce a word count. You could argue that AI exacerbates this situation but you also have to agree that it is much more pleasant to ask perplexity, ChatGPT or Claude a question than to put yourself through the torture of conventional search. Introducing ads into this would completely deprive the user of a way of navigating the web in a way that actually respects their dignity.I also agree in the sense that the current crop of AIs do feel like a space to think as opposed to a place where I am being manipulated, controlled or treated like some sheep in flock to be sheared for cash.
comments.content_cn: 这属于那种公司遇到困难时就会删除的“不作恶”式文章，但我想我们应该庆幸Anthropic目前形势大好，才会发布这样的博客。关于搜索引擎中信号与噪音过滤的重要性怎么强调都不为过。如今使用搜索引擎乃至整个传统互联网简直令人沮丧——这完全是个对用户充满敌意的环境：本不该收集数据的网站充斥着无穷无尽的cookie弹窗、自动播放的广告、刻意制造互动的内容农场，还有AI生成的推销文章只为凑字数。你可以说AI加剧了这种状况，但不得不承认，向Perplexity、ChatGPT或Claude提问的体验，远比忍受传统搜索的折磨愉快得多。若在这种环境中引入广告，将彻底剥夺用户以保有尊严的方式浏览网络的权利。我也认同当前这批AI确实让人感觉像是思考的空间，而不是被操纵控制、像待剪毛的绵羊般被榨取金钱的场所。

comments.author: sdrinf
comments.content: Besides the editorial control -which openai openly flagged to want to remain unbiased- there is a deeper issue with ads-based revenue models in AI: that of margins. If you want ads to cover compute & make margins -looking at roughly $50 ARPU at mature FB/GOOG level- you have two levers: sell more advertisement, or offer dumber models.This is exactly what chatgpt 5 was about. By tweaking both the model selector (thinking/non-thinking), and using a significantly sparser thinking model (capping max spend per conversation turn), they massively controlled costs, but did so at the expense of intelligence, responsiveness, curiosity, skills, and all the things I've valued in O3. This was the point I dumped openai, and went with claude.This business model issue is a subtle one, but a key reason why advertisement revenue model is not compatible (or competitive!) with "getting the best mental tools" -margin-maximization selects against businesses optimizing for intelligence.
comments.content_cn: 除了OpenAI公开宣称要保持无偏见的编辑控制外，基于广告的AI营收模式还存在一个更深层的问题：利润空间。若想通过广告覆盖计算成本并实现盈利——参考成熟阶段脸书和谷歌约50美元的单用户平均收入——你只有两个杠杆：要么出售更多广告，要么提供更愚钝的模型。这正是ChatGPT5采取的策略。通过同时调整模型选择器（思考型/非思考型）并采用显著稀疏的思考模型（限制每轮对话最高支出），他们大幅控制了成本，但代价却是牺牲了智能性、响应速度、好奇心、技能以及我在O3版本中珍视的所有特质。这正是我放弃OpenAI转向Claude的关键转折点。这个商业模式问题看似微妙，却是广告营收模式与“获取最佳思维工具”无法兼容（甚至缺乏竞争力）的核心原因——利润最大化机制天然排斥以智能优化为目标的商业选择。

comments.author: panarky
comments.content: Before Google, web search was a toxic stew of conflicts of interest. They consciously structured the company like a newspaper, to prevent the information side from being polluted and distorted by the money-making side.Here's a snip from their IPO letter [0]:Google users trust our systems to help them with important decisions: medical, financial and many others. Our search results are the best we know how to produce. They are unbiased and objective, and we do not accept payment for them or for inclusion or more frequent updating. We also display advertising, which we work hard to make relevant, and we label it clearly. This is similar to a well-run newspaper, where the advertisements are clear and the articles are not influenced by the advertisers’ payments. We believe it is important for everyone to have access to the best information and research, not only to the information people pay for you to see.Anthropic's statement reads the same way, and it's refreshing to see them prioritize long-term values like trust over short-term monetization.It's hard to put a dollar value on trust, but even when they fall short of their ideals, it's still a big differentiator from competitors like Microsoft, Meta and OpenAI.I'd bet that a large portion of Google's enterprise value today can be traced to that trust differential with their competitors, and I wouldn't be surprised to see a similar outcome for Anthropic.Don't be evil, but unironically.[0] https://abc.xyz/investor/founders-letters/ipo-letter/default...

posts.title: Voxtral Transcribe 2
posts.author: meetpateltech
posts.title_cn: Voxtral转录2
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕Mistral AI发布的Voxtral Transcribe 2语音转录模型展开。核心话题是评估其性能表现、成本优势及多语言支持能力。

多数用户对模型的实时转录准确性和低成本表示赞赏。有人认为其实时转录效果远超以往体验，且价格仅为亚马逊服务的八分之一，优势明显。也有用户指出，尽管官方标注3%的词错误率在成本上极具竞争力，但对长音频而言错误累积可能影响实用体验。

讨论中出现了几点分歧：在语言支持方面，有用户称赞其英语表现和实时语言切换能力，但也有用户反映其对乌克兰语识别不佳，会错误转写为俄语。在性能对比上，部分用户询问其是否优于Nvidia Parakeet V3等竞品，另有用户呼吁需要更独立的第三方评测来验证实际效果。还有用户建议应提供针对专业领域术语的专项测试基准，因为日常对话与专业场景的表现可能存在差异。

社区普遍认同这是一个有突破性的开源模型，但在具体应用场景中的可靠性仍需进一步验证。

comments.author: qingcharles
comments.content: I did transcription for a while in 2021. It is absurdly hard. Especially as these days humans only get the difficult jobs that AI has already taken a stab at.The hardest one I did was for a sports network where it was a motorcross motorbike event where most of what you could hear was the roar of the bikes. There were two commentators I had to transcribe over the top of that mess and they were using the slang insider nicknames for all the riders, not their published names, so I had to sit and Google forums to find the names of the riders while I was listening. I'm not even sure how these local models would even be able to handle that insanity at all because they almost certainly lack enough domain knowledge.

comments.author: antirez
comments.content: Different representations at the same bitrate may have features that make one a lot more resilient to errors. This thing about Italian, you fill find in any benchmark of vastly different AI transcribing models. You can find similar results also on the way LLMs mostly trained on English generalize usually very well with Italian. All this despite Italian accounting for marginal percentage of the training set. How do you explain that? I always cringe when people refute evidence.
comments.content_cn: 相同比特率下的不同编码方式可能具备某些特性，使其对传输错误具有更强的耐受性。关于意大利语的这种现象，你可以在各种差异巨大的人工智能转录模型测试中找到。同样，在以英语为主要训练数据的大语言模型中，也能观察到它们对意大利语通常表现出极佳的泛化能力——尽管意大利语在训练集中所占比例微乎其微。这该如何解释？每当有人无视证据进行反驳时，我总感到十分尴尬。

posts.title: What's up with all those equals signs anyway?
posts.author: todsacerdoti
posts.title_cn: "这些等号到底是怎么回事？"
posts.abstract:
该HackerNews帖子围绕电子邮件编码中“等号”（quoted-printable编码）的异常处理问题展开讨论。核心话题是用户在处理旧邮件时，因错误解码QP编码导致邮件内容出现大量等号乱码的现象。

讨论中提到，这被普遍视为“一知半解反而危险”的典型案例：有人指出，问题源于开发者知道邮件非纯文本，却误用手动替换方式解码QP编码，这与用正则表达式解析HTML的漏洞类似。也有用户质疑为何邮件服务器要限制行长度，认为应由客户端处理换行。

社区共识是电子邮件标准虽概念简单，实际解析却异常复杂，尤其面对多年积累的边缘情况。分歧点在于问题突然涌现的原因，部分用户推测是近期社交媒体流行分享旧邮件片段所致，另有人则关注相关技术博客是否因访问激增而瘫痪。

多位用户引用资深开发者Lars Ingebrigtsen的博客和Gnus手册，强调邮件解析需要深厚专业知识。整体讨论呈现出对历史技术细节的追忆与对编码实践严谨性的共同关注。

comments.author: ruhith
comments.content: The real punchline is that this is a perfect example of "just enough knowledge to be dangerous." Whoever processed these emails knew enough to know emails aren't plain text, but not enough to know that quoted-printable decoding isn't something you hand-roll with find-and-replace. It's the same class of bug as manually parsing HTML with regex, it works right up until it doesn't, and then you get congressional evidence full of mystery equals signs.
comments.content_cn: 真正的讽刺在于，这完美诠释了“一知半解最危险”。处理这些邮件的人知道邮件不是纯文本，却不知道引用可打印编码不能靠简单的查找替换手动完成。这和用正则表达式手动解析HTML是同一类错误——看似能用，一旦失效就会导致国会证据中充满莫名其妙的等号。

comments.author: topspin
comments.content: What happened here is what always happens with all printed and digital material that goes through some evidentiary process.The shot-callers demand the material, which is a task fobbed off onto some nobody intern who doesn't matter (deliberately, because the lawyers and career LEOs don't want any "officer of the court" or other "party" to put eyes on things they might need to deny knowing about later.)  They use only the most primitive, mechanical method possible, with little to no discretion.  The collected mass of mangled junk is then shipped to whoever, either in boxes or on CD-ROM/DVD (yes, still) or something.  Then, the reverse process is done, equally badly, again by low-level staff, also with zero discretion and little to no technical knowledge or ability, for exactly the same reasons, to get the material into some form suitable for filing or whatever.Through all of this, the subtle details of data formats and encodings are utterly lost, and the legal archive fills with mangled garbage like raw quoted-printable emails.  The parties involved have other priorities, such as minimizing the number of people involved in the process, and tight control over the number of copies created.  Their instinct is not to bring in a bunch of clever folk that might make the work product come out better, because "better" for them is different than "better" for Twitter or Facebook.  Also, these disclosures are inevitably and invariably challenged by time: the obligation to provide one thing or another is fought to the last possible minute, and when the word does finally go out there is next to no time to piddle around with details.In the Epstein case, the disclosures were done years ago, the original source material (computers, accounts, file systems, etc.) have all long since been (deliberately) destroyed, and what the feds have is the shrapnel we see today.

comments.author: layer8
comments.content: Mails are (or used to be) processed line-by-line, typically using fixed-length buffers. This avoids dynamic memory allocation and having to write a streaming parser. RFC 821 finally limited the line length to at most 1000 bytes.Given a mechanism for soft line breaks, breaking already at below 80 characters would increase compatibility with older mail software and be more convenient when listing the raw email in a terminal.This is also why MIME Base64 typically inserts line breaks after 76 characters.
comments.content_cn: 邮件（或曾经）是逐行处理的，通常使用固定长度的缓冲区。这避免了动态内存分配和编写流式解析器的需要。RFC 821最终将行长度限制在最多1000字节。考虑到软换行机制，在低于80个字符处换行将提高与旧版邮件软件的兼容性，并在终端中列出原始邮件时更加方便。这也是为什么MIME Base64通常在76个字符后插入换行符。

posts.title: Microsoft's Copilot chatbot is running into problems
posts.author: fortran77
posts.title_cn: 微软Copilot聊天机器人运行遇阻
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕微软Copilot聊天机器人的市场表现和产品问题展开。核心话题是Copilot用户采用率低、付费转化不佳以及微软的AI战略受到质疑。

社区观点呈现明显分歧。有人认为微软过于追求市场渗透率而忽视产品实际体验，其AI整合策略被形容为“慢动作车祸”。也有用户指出关键问题在于企业“数据孤岛”普遍，这影响了Copilot等企业级AI工具的效果。讨论中提到，付费用户流失率上升，实际使用率从18.8%降至11.5%，而竞品Gemini已实现反超。

部分用户批评微软将Copilot强制捆绑进企业环境，限制其他AI工具使用，有用户将其比喻为“被敲掉20个智商点的ChatGPT”。同时，有观点认为微软对AI的过度专注已形成路径依赖，导致Windows等核心产品出现AI相关问题时难以回头。

共识在于社区普遍认为Copilot当前面临严峻的产品力与市场接受度挑战，但对其根本原因和解决方案存在不同判断。

comments.author: _fat_santa
comments.content: The biggest issue I see is Microsoft's entire mentality around AI adoption that focuses more on "getting the numbers up" then actually delivering a product people want to use.Most of the announcements I hear about Copilot, it's always how they've integrated it into some other piece of software or cut a deal with yet another vendor to add it to that vendors product offering. On the surface there's nothing wrong with doing that but that just seems to be the ONLY thing Microsoft is focused on.Worse yet, most of these integrations seem like a exercise in ticking boxes rather than actually thinking through how integrating Copilot into a product will actually improve user experience. A great example was someone mentioned that Copilot was now integrated into the terminal app but beyond an icon + a chat window, there is zero integration.Overall, MS just reeks of an organization that is cares more about numbers on a dashboard and pretty reports than they are on what users are actually experiencing.
comments.content_cn: 我认为最大的问题在于微软采纳AI的整体思路，他们更关注“提升数据指标”而非真正交付用户想要的产品。我听到的大多数关于Copilot的公告，总是关于他们如何将其集成到其他软件中，或是与另一家供应商达成协议，将其添加到该供应商的产品中。表面上看这样做没什么问题，但这似乎成了微软唯一专注的事情。更糟糕的是，大多数这类集成看起来更像是为了完成任务而打勾，而非真正思考将Copilot集成到产品中如何实际改善用户体验。一个很好的例子是有人提到Copilot现已集成到终端应用中，但除了一个图标和一个聊天窗口外，没有任何实质性的整合。总体而言，微软给人的感觉是一个更关心仪表盘上的数据和漂亮报告，而非用户实际体验的组织。

与此同时，微软内部三个不同部门都拥有名为"Copilot"的产品，且彼此互不沟通。而Anthropic仅用10天就推出Cowork，随即引爆市场。

Because it turns out that's a lot of what they do is navigating these bureaucratic and political hurdles to unlock access to the data: https://nabeelqu.co/reflections-on-palantirIt gets even worse if you consider this data is going to be extremely messy, with multiple bespoke, partially-duplicate / overlapping, potentially conflicting versions of the data with varying levels of out-of-datedness, scattered across these silos. (I would know, in a past life, I worked on a months-long project called, self-explanatorily enough, "Stale Docs".)Yeah, untangling these bureaucratic webs and data horrors is not a quarter-long or year-long project, so investors are gonna be waiting a long time for the impact of AI to be visible. comments.author: ChuckMcM
comments.content: I expect this is the crux of the problem.There aren't any "AI" products that have enough value.Compare to their Office suite, which had 100 - 150 engineers working on it, every business paid big $$ for every employee using it, and once they shipped install media their ongoing costs were the employees. With a 1,000,000:1 ratio of users to developers and an operating expense (OpEx) of engineers/offices/management. That works as a business.But with "AI", not only is it not a product in itself, it's a feature to a product, but it has OpEx and CapEx costs that dominate the balance sheet based on their public disclosures. Worse, as a feature, it demonstrably harms business with its hallucinations.In a normal world, at this point companies would say, "hmm, well we thought it could be amazing but it just doesn't work as a product or a feature of a product because we can't sell it for enough money to both cover its operation, and its development, and the capital expenditures we need to make every time someone signs up. So a normal C staff would make some post about "too early" or whatever and shelve it. But we don't live in a normal world, so companies are literally burning the cash they need to survive the future in a vain hope that somehow, somewhere, a real product will emerge.
comments.content_cn:
我认为这就是问题的症结所在。目前没有任何“人工智能”产品具备足够的价值。以他们的Office套件为例，曾有100到150名工程师参与开发，每家企业为每位使用该软件的员工支付高昂费用，一旦发布安装介质，后续成本主要就是员工开支。用户与开发者的比例达到100万比1，运营支出包括工程师薪酬、办公场地及管理成本。这种模式作为商业运作是可行的。

但“人工智能”不仅本身算不上独立产品，它只是产品的附加功能，而且根据公开披露的信息，其运营支出和资本支出在财务报表中占据主导地位。更糟糕的是，作为一项功能，它因产生幻觉问题而明显损害了业务运营。

在正常情况下，企业此时会说：“嗯，我们原以为它会很出色，但事实证明它既不能作为独立产品，也无法成为产品的有效功能，因为我们无法以足够高的价格销售它来覆盖运营成本、开发成本，以及每次用户注册时所需的资本支出。”因此，正常的管理层会发表一些“为时过早”之类的声明，然后将其搁置。但我们所处的并非正常环境，企业正在消耗未来生存所需的资金，徒劳地希望某个地方、以某种方式能诞生出真正的产品。

posts.title: China Moon Mission: Aiming for 2030 lunar landing
posts.author: rbanffy
posts.title_cn: 中国探月工程：目标2030年实现载人登月
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕中国计划2030年前实现载人登月的新闻展开，核心话题是新一轮“太空竞赛”的前景与意义。多数用户认为此次竞赛与美苏时期不同，中国拥有更稳定的经济与技术基础，即使落后也可能持续投入。讨论中提到，有人认为美国项目（如星舰）更具野心但执行风险较高，也有人指出机器人探测可能比载人任务更经济高效。对于登月意义，部分用户强调其地缘政治属性，而非纯粹技术竞争；另有用户质疑美国重返月球的拖延，并提及阿波罗计划在部分地区的质疑声音。共识在于，新一轮竞赛可能推动太空探索，但技术路径与实际效益仍是争议焦点。

comments.author: hdivider
comments.content: This space race is different for one core reason: China is more stable than the Soviet Union was in the 1960s.If we beat the Chinese somehow, I don't think they'll just dismantle their space program and focus on Earth. They'll keep going, and they have the economic base to expand their program.I think we're seeing the beginning of a new kind of space race. It's likely to be much longer term and grander in scale over time, as we compete for the best spots on the Moon and the first human landing on Mars in the decades to come.

comments.author: GMoromisato
comments.content: China has a chance of landing humans on the moon before Artemis, but if it does, it will be because America's space program is more ambitious, not less.Lanyue, which masses 26 metric tons, can land two (maybe four?) astronauts on the moon plus a 200 kg rover. Space X's Starship is designed to land 100 tons on the moon--that's 100 tons of payload.Let's say you want to build a small moon base, one that's maybe 100 tons (ISS is 400 tons). How many Lanyue launches would be necessary? Maybe 10? Now remember that each launch is expendable. It will cost China between $500 and $1 billion per launch. That's $5 to $10 billion for a moon base, not counting the cost of the base itself!Starship is designed to be fully re-usable. Their goal is to get each launch to cost $10 to $20 million total. To land 100 tons on the moon, they will have to refuel in orbit by launching between 10 and 20 tanker flights. That means one trip to the moon costs $200 to $400 million maximum. Even assuming that Starship underperforms and can only land 50 tons on the moon, we still only need two launches for a total cost of $800 million maximum.That is literally 10 times cheaper than Chinese capabilities; alternatively, it is 10x the payload at the same cost.Of course, there are two major developments that Space X still needs to demonstrate: rapid re-use (to bring the cost down) and in-space refueling. And that's why it's taken so long.But if/when they pull it off, it won't really matter if China lands first. The American program is much more ambitious.

中国有可能在阿尔忒弥斯计划之前将人类送上月球，但如果实现，那将是因为美国的太空计划更具雄心，而非相反。揽月号重达26吨，可搭载两名（或许是四名？）宇航员登月，并携带一辆200公斤的月球车。而SpaceX的星舰设计目标是在月球着陆100吨载荷——整整100吨的有效载荷。

假设要建造一个约100吨的小型月球基地（国际空间站为400吨）。需要多少次揽月号发射？可能10次？请记住每次发射都是消耗性的。中国每次发射成本将在5亿至10亿美元之间。这意味着仅发射成本就达50亿至100亿美元，还不包括基地本身的建造费用！

星舰设计为完全可重复使用。其目标是将每次发射总成本控制在1000万至2000万美元。为了在月球着陆100吨载荷，需要通过10到20次燃料补给飞行在轨道上加注燃料。这意味着单次月球任务最高成本仅为2亿至4亿美元。即使假设星舰性能未达预期，只能在月球着陆50吨，也仅需两次发射，总成本最高8亿美元。

这实际上比中国的方案便宜10倍；或者说，在相同成本下运载能力提高10倍。

当然，SpaceX仍需证明两项关键技术：快速重复使用（以降低成本）和太空燃料加注。这正是进展缓慢的原因。

但当他们成功实现时，中国是否率先登月已不再重要。

posts.title: Notepad++ supply chain attack breakdown
posts.author: natebc
posts.title_cn: Notepad++供应链攻击事件剖析
posts.abstract:
本次HackerNews讨论围绕Notepad++供应链攻击事件展开，核心议题是软件更新机制的安全风险及Windows生态下的软件分发问题。社区普遍认同供应链攻击危害严重，因其利用用户对更新渠道的信任，且具有隐蔽性（如本次攻击存在6个月潜伏期）。

讨论中主要观点包括：有人认为Windows缺乏统一可靠的包管理器，导致许多软件（包括开源软件）通过广告充斥的网站分发，且各自为政的更新方式加剧了安全风险；也有用户指出，当前安全实践存在矛盾——既要及时更新以修复漏洞，又要警惕更新带来的供应链攻击，实际操作中难以平衡。多位用户分享了防护措施，例如在沙盒中运行工具、使用防火墙严格管控网络访问，或直接在企业环境中禁用涉事软件。

分歧点主要体现在应对策略上：部分用户倾向于依赖安全软件扫描检测，另一些则更强调主动隔离和权限控制。此外，有用户对攻击溯源提出疑问，注意到病毒平台早期扫描记录可能关联攻击者。整体上，社区对软件供应链脆弱性表示担忧，并呼吁更安全的更新与分发机制。

comments.author: Soerensen
comments.content: The WinGUp updater compromise is a textbook example of why update mechanisms are such high-value targets. Attackers get code execution on machines that specifically trust the update channel.What's concerning is the 6-month window. Supply chain attacks are difficult to detect because the malicious code runs with full user permissions from a "trusted" source. Most endpoint protection isn't designed to flag software from a legitimate publisher's update infrastructure.For organizations, this argues for staged rollouts and network monitoring for unexpected outbound connections from common applications. For individuals, package managers with cryptographic verification at least add another barrier - though obviously not bulletproof either.
comments.content_cn: WinGUp更新程序被入侵事件完美诠释了为何更新机制会成为高价值攻击目标。攻击者能在明确信任该更新渠道的机器上执行代码。令人担忧的是其长达六个月的潜伏窗口。供应链攻击之所以难以察觉，是因为恶意代码以完全用户权限从"可信"来源运行。大多数终端防护系统不会对来自合法发行商更新基础设施的软件发出警告。对企业而言，这要求采用分阶段部署策略，并对常见应用的异常外联进行网络监控。对个人用户来说，具备加密验证功能的包管理器至少能增加一道防线——尽管显然也并非万无一失。

comments.author: the_harpia_io
comments.content:
This attack highlights a broader pattern: developers and users increasingly trust code they haven't personally reviewed.Supply chain attacks work because we implicitly trust the update channel. But the same trust assumption appears in other places:- npm/pip packages where we `npm install` without auditing
- AI-generated code that gets committed after a quick glance
- The growing "vibe coding" trend where entire features are scaffolded by AIThe Notepad++ case is almost a best-case scenario — it's a single binary from a known source. The attack surface multiplies when you consider modern dev workflows with hundreds of transitive dependencies, or projects where significant portions were AI-generated and only superficially reviewed.Sandboxing helps, but the real issue is the gap between what code can do and what developers expect it to do. We need better tooling for understanding what we're actually running.
comments.content_cn:
这次攻击揭示了一个更广泛的模式：开发者和用户越来越信任他们未曾亲自审查的代码。供应链攻击之所以得逞，是因为我们默认信任更新渠道。但同样的信任假设也出现在其他地方：  
- 未经审计就直接`npm install`的npm/pip软件包  
- 匆匆一瞥后就提交的AI生成代码  
- 日益兴起的"氛围编程"趋势，即整个功能都由AI搭建脚手架  

Notepad++事件几乎是最理想的情况——它只是来自已知来源的单个二进制文件。当你考虑到现代开发流程中数百个传递依赖，或者项目中大量代码由AI生成且仅经过表面审查时，攻击面就会成倍增加。沙箱技术有所帮助，但真正的问题在于代码的实际能力与开发者预期之间的差距。我们需要更好的工具来理解我们实际运行的内容。

comments.author: ziml77
comments.content: I'd say it's more true on Linux that malware can hide anywhere if you allow a sudo prompt (which people have been unfortunately been trained is normal when installing software).Windows enforces driver signing and has a deeper access control system that means a root account doesn't even truly exist. The SYSTEM pseudo-account looks like it should be that, but you can actually set up ACLs that make files untouchable by it. In fact if you check the files in System32, they are only writable by TrustedInstaller. A user's administrative token and SYSTEM have no access those files.But when it comes down to it, I wouldn't trust any system that has had malware on it. At the very least I'd do a complete reinstall. It might even be worth re-flashing the firmware of all components of the system too, but the chances of those also being infected are lower as long as signed firmware is required.
comments.content_cn:
我认为在Linux系统上更常见的情况是，如果你允许sudo提权（不幸的是，人们已经习惯在安装软件时认为这是正常的），恶意软件可以隐藏在任意位置。Windows系统强制要求驱动程序签名，并拥有更深入的访问控制机制，这意味着真正的root账户甚至不存在。SYSTEM伪账户看似拥有最高权限，但实际上你可以设置访问控制列表，使其无法访问某些文件。事实上，如果你查看System32目录中的文件，会发现它们仅允许TrustedInstaller进行写入操作。用户的Administrator权限令牌和SYSTEM账户都无法访问这些文件。

但归根结底，我不会信任任何曾感染过恶意软件的系统。至少我会选择完全重装系统。甚至值得考虑重新刷写系统所有组件的固件，不过只要固件要求签名验证，这些组件被感染的概率就会低得多。

posts.title: A case study in PDF forensics: The Epstein PDFs
posts.author: DuffJohnson
posts.title_cn: "PDF取证案例分析：爱泼斯坦PDF文件"
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕爱泼斯坦案件PDF文件的法证分析展开。用户主要关注文件的技术特征，特别是图像处理和OCR识别问题。有人认为文件中缺乏真实扫描文档应有的噪点，可能表明文件经过人工处理；也有用户指出司法部避免使用JPEG格式可能是为了规避元数据泄露风险，但质疑这种处理方式是否过于简单。讨论中提到OCR识别结果存在不一致，有用户尝试使用开源模型进行比对。部分用户对文件中的异常字符（如随机“=”符号）提出猜测，认为可能是为了干扰文本搜索功能。虽然存在技术细节的探讨，但普遍共识是这些文件分析工作量大且复杂，有用户期待将分析方法扩展到新发布的数百万页文件中。此外，个别用户表达了获取银行账户等核心信息的兴趣，或调侃了网页的cookie提示按钮文字。

comments.author: anigbrowl
comments.content: I found this part interesting:There are also other documents that appear to simulate a scanned document but completely lack the “real-world noise” expected with physical paper-based workflows. The much crisper images appear almost perfect without random artifacts or background noise, and with the exact same amount of image skew across multiple pages. Thanks to the borders around each page of text, page skew can easily be measured, such as with VOL00007\IMAGES\0001\EFTA00009229.pdf. It is highly likely these PDFs were created by rendering original content (from a digital document) to an image (e.g., via print to image or save to image functionality) and then applying image processing such as skew, downscaling, and color reduction.

comments.author: tombrossman
comments.content:
GNOME Desktop users can put this in a Bash script in ~/.local/share/nautilus/ for more convincing looking fake PDF scans, accessible from your right-click menu. I do not recall where I copied it from originally to give credit so thanks, random internet person (probably on Stack Exchange). It works perfectly.  ROTATION=$(shuf -n 1 -e '-' '')$(shuf -n 1 -e $(seq 0.05 .5))

  for pdf in "$@";
    do magick  -density 150 $pdf \
              -linear-stretch '1.5%x2%' \
              -rotate 0.4 \
              -attenuate '0.01' \
              +noise  Multiplicative \
              -colorspace 'gray' \
              "${pdf%.*}-fakescan.${pdf##*.}"
  done

posts.title: Deno Sandbox
posts.author: johnspurlock
posts.title_cn: Deno 沙箱
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕Deno Sandbox这一产品展开，核心话题是其如何通过沙箱环境安全地执行用户生成的代码（尤其是LLM生成的代码），同时保护API密钥等敏感信息。讨论中提到，其创新点在于使用“密钥占位符”机制，仅当沙箱向授权主机发起出站请求时才动态注入真实密钥，从而防止密钥泄露，这一设计被部分用户认为很巧妙。

社区观点存在分歧。有人认为该产品解决了LLM应用场景中代码安全执行的痛点，且支持多语言客户端；也有用户指出潜在问题，如可能破坏OAuth、JWT等依赖密钥变换的协议语义，或引发HTTP语义问题。关于部署方式，不少用户询问是否有本地或自托管版本，并质疑其30分钟运行时限和完全依赖云端的设定。此外，用户对免费服务的可持续性表示担忧，并与其他沙箱产品（如Modal、Cloudflare等）进行比较，讨论生产环境中的适用性。

共识方面，社区普遍认可密钥占位符的设计思路，但对实际兼容性、部署灵活性和长期可靠性仍存疑虑。

comments.author: simonw
comments.content:
Note that you don't need to use Deno or JavaScript at all to use this product. Here's their Python client SDK: https://pypi.org/project/deno-sandbox/  from deno_sandbox import DenoDeploy
  
  sdk = DenoDeploy()
  
  with sdk.sandbox.create() as sb:
      # Run a shell command
      process = sb.spawn("echo", args=["Hello from the sandbox!"])
      process.wait()
  
      # Write and read files
      sb.fs.write_text_file("/tmp/example.txt", "Hello, World!")
      content = sb.fs.read_text_file("/tmp/example.txt")
      print(content)

Looks like the API protocol itself uses websockets: https://tools.simonwillison.net/zip-wheel-explorer?package=d...

We can move the service anywhere we can get hardware virtualisation.As for the situation with credentials, our method is to generate CLIs on the fly and expose them to the LLMs and then they can shell script them whichever way they want. All they know is that they can do$ some-skillset search-gmail-messages -q "emails from Adrian"In our own experiments we find that this approach works better and it just makes sense given most of the latest models are trained as coding assistants. posts.title: The Codex app illustrates the shift left of IDEs and coding GUIs
posts.author: straydusk
posts.title_cn: Codex应用展示了IDE和编码GUI的左移趋势。
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕Codex应用引发的IDE和编程GUI“左移”趋势展开。核心争议在于AI辅助编程工具是否改变了编程的本质以及开发者的角色。有人认为AI编码工具将重点转向需求、约束和架构等“生产代码的系统”，代码本身成为实现细节，这类似于向瀑布开发模式的回归。也有用户指出过度依赖AI可能导致开发者不再阅读和理解代码，当出现bug时难以排查，形成“黑箱”风险。讨论中提到，部分用户认为这类工具更适合新手或小型项目，因为缺乏代码引用追踪等专业IDE功能；而支持者则认为技术娴熟的用户最能从中受益，可以更高效地管理代码生成流程。普遍共识是AI正在改变编程工作流，但对于这是否削弱了开发者对代码的控制和理解，社区存在明显分歧。

comments.author: jkhdigital

For a while they were right, but improved compiler design and the relentless performance increases in hardware made it so that even an extra 10-20% boost you might get from perfectly hand-crafted assembly was almost never worth the developer time.There is an obvious parallel here, but it’s not quite the same. The high-level language is effectively a formal spec for the abstract machine which is faithfully translated by the (hopefully bug-free) compiler. Natural language is not a formal spec for anything, and LLM-based agents are not formally verifiable software. 在过去大约10到20年编写的系统中，我目睹了它们经历剧烈的变更频率，有时每隔几年就会彻底重写。这似乎与敏捷开发的兴起（并非谴责或赞同）密切相关——人们预期快速变更成为常态，而且系统所用的技术本身也往往在飞速迭代。

我不确定这是否是美好的未来，也不确定它明天就会到来，但这或许不会超过未来20年的时间范围，甚至可能更早发生。
