posts.title: Show HN: Craftplan – I built my wife a production management tool for her bakery
posts.content: My wife was planning to open a micro-bakery. We looked at production management software and it was all either expensive or way too generic. The actual workflows for a small-batch manufacturer aren't that complex, so I built one and open-sourced it.Craftplan handles recipes (versioned BOMs with cost rollups), inventory (lot traceability, demand forecasting, allergen tracking), orders, production batch planning, and purchasing. Built with Elixir, Ash Framework, Phoenix LiveView, and PostgreSQL.Live demo: https://craftplan.fly.dev (test@test.com / Aa123123123123)GitHub: https://github.com/puemos/craftplan
posts.author: deofoo
posts.title_cn: Show HN：Craftplan——我为妻子的面包店打造了一款生产管理工具
posts.content_cn:
我妻子计划开一家微型面包店。我们考察了生产管理软件，发现它们要么价格昂贵，要么过于通用。对于小批量生产商来说，实际的工作流程并不那么复杂，因此我自行开发了一款并将其开源。Craftplan 负责处理配方（带成本汇总的版本化物料清单）、库存（批次追溯、需求预测、过敏原追踪）、订单、生产批次计划以及采购。该软件使用 Elixir、Ash Framework、Phoenix LiveView 和 PostgreSQL 构建。

在线演示：https://craftplan.fly.dev (test@test.com / Aa123123123123)
GitHub：https://github.com/puemos/craftplan
posts.abstract:
该帖子展示了一款为小型烘焙坊定制的开源生产管理工具Craftplan。核心话题是开发者因市面软件昂贵或过于通用，为妻子的微型烘焙坊自主开发了涵盖配方、库存、订单等功能的解决方案。

社区讨论中，多数用户对项目表示赞赏。有人认为针对具体用户而非过早抽象化的开发方式值得肯定，能更贴合实际工作流。也有用户指出其与实验室信息管理系统有相似特性，并询问是否支持半成品管理等具体功能。讨论中提到Elixir和Ash框架的技术选型引发兴趣。

争议点主要体现在个别用户的评论态度上。有用户借此强调自主编码优于依赖潜在风险的第三方服务，但因其傲慢语气遭到其他用户反对。此外，部分用户对需求预测等功能的实现逻辑提出技术性质疑。

整体而言，社区普遍认同针对特定场景开发轻量级工具的价值，并对开源实践表示支持。分歧主要围绕个别评论的表述方式及部分功能细节展开。

Curious how the AI code generation worked with Ash specifically - the declarative nature seems like it could either help a lot (clear patterns) or confuse models that expect more explicit code.The BOM with cost rollups is the feature that would have saved me hours in a previous project. comments.author: DrScientist
comments.content:
I think the real question here isn't whether roll your own software will replace large complex 'configurable' systems, but whether companies that roll their own will replace the companies that don't.ie are the efficiency gains of having something that's exactly tailored to you enough to create a competitive advantage.It's back to the old idea - of software eating the world.So for example in the UK - there is a relatively new 'energy' company called Octopus - it's grown and grown and finally overtaken the old established players.In reality it's not an energy company - it's a software company - that used it's expertise in software to overtake it's energy supplier competitors - it was able to provide innovative products in the market because it controlled it's own software - rather than 'big vendor says no'.I think it's telling that the founder originally left school at 16 to write computer games, before coming back to do a degree etc.ie the question is - for any particular industry what's the benefit of custom software.
Does a bakery having it's own give it enough of an advantage?
comments.content_cn: 我认为这里真正的问题不是自主开发软件是否会取代大型复杂的“可配置”系统，而是自主开发软件的公司是否会取代那些不自主开发的公司。也就是说，拥有完全量身定制的东西所带来的效率提升是否足以创造竞争优势。这又回到了那个老观点——软件正在吞噬世界。以英国为例，有一家相对较新的“能源”公司叫Octopus，它不断发展壮大，最终超越了那些老牌企业。实际上，它并不是一家能源公司，而是一家软件公司——它利用自己在软件方面的专业知识超越了能源供应商竞争对手。因为它控制着自己的软件，所以能够在市场上提供创新产品，而不是“大型供应商说不”。值得注意的是，创始人最初在16岁就辍学去编写电脑游戏，后来才回来攻读学位等等。也就是说，问题在于：对于任何特定行业来说，定制软件的好处是什么？一家面包店拥有自己的软件是否足以带来优势？

posts.title: Claude Code for Infrastructure
posts.author: aspectrr
posts.title_cn: 基础设施的Claude代码
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕Claude Code在基础设施管理中的应用展开。核心争议在于这类AI工具的实际价值与潜在风险。有用户认为当前开发工具过多却缺乏真正面向终端用户的产品，感觉像“金字塔骗局”；也有用户指出Claude Code能自动优化AI图像生成提示词，已成功用于实际项目。运维人员质疑其必要性，认为现有LLM工具已足够，且演示未明确说明服务器运行内容。部分开发者认为专用工具并非必需，通用CLI工具配合Claude Code即可完成kubectl等运维操作。讨论中提到安全担忧，有用户强调需明确工具的破坏性操作并提供只读模式。共识在于基础设施即代码的理念被普遍接受，但具体实现方式存在分歧：一方主张专用工具需提供更透明的安全机制，另一方则认为现有通用方案已足够高效。

comments.author: aspectrr
comments.content:
Hey HN,
My name is Collin and I'm working on fluid.sh (https://fluid.sh) the Claude Code for Infrastructure.What does that mean?Fluid is a terminal agent that do work on production infrastructure like VMs/K8s cluster/etc. by making sandbox clones of the infrastructure for AI agents to work on, allowing the agents to run commands, test connections, edit files, and then generate Infra-as-code like an Ansible Playbook to be applied on production.Why not just use an LLM to generate IaC?LLMs are great at generating Terraform, OpenTofu, Ansible, etc. but bad at guessing how production systems work. By giving access to a clone of the infrastructure, agents can explore, run commands, test things before writing the IaC, giving them better context and a place to test ideas and changes before deploying.I got the idea after seeing how much Claude Code has helped me work on code, I thought "I wish there was something like that for infrastructure", and here we are.Why not just provide tools, skills, MCP server to Claude Code?Mainly safety. I didn't want CC to SSH into a prod machine from where it is running locally (real problem!). I wanted to lock down the tools it can run to be only on sandboxes while also giving it autonomy to create sandboxes and not have access to anything else.Fluid gives access to a live output of commands run (it's pretty cool) and does this by ephemeral SSH Certificates. Fluid gives tools for creating IaC and requires human approval for creating sandboxes on hosts with low memory/CPU and for accessing the internet or installing packages.I greatly appreciate any feedback or thoughts you have, and I hope you get the chance to try out Fluid!
comments.content_cn:
大家好，
我是Collin，正在开发fluid.sh（https://fluid.sh），这是面向基础设施的Claude Code。这是什么意思呢？Fluid是一个终端代理，它通过为AI代理创建基础设施的沙盒克隆，让代理能够在生产基础设施（如虚拟机/K8s集群等）上执行工作，允许代理运行命令、测试连接、编辑文件，然后生成类似Ansible Playbook的基础设施即代码，以便在生产环境中应用。

为什么不直接用LLM生成IaC呢？LLM擅长生成Terraform、OpenTofu、Ansible等代码，但不擅长推测生产系统的运行方式。通过访问基础设施的克隆，代理可以在编写IaC之前进行探索、运行命令和测试，从而获得更好的上下文，并在部署前测试想法和更改。

这个想法源于我看到Claude Code在代码工作上给我的巨大帮助，当时我想“要是基础设施也有这样的工具就好了”，于是就有了这个项目。

为什么不直接给Claude Code提供工具、技能或MCP服务器呢？主要是出于安全考虑。我不希望Claude Code从本地运行环境直接SSH连接到生产机器（这是个实际问题！）。我希望限制它只能运行沙盒上的工具，同时赋予它创建沙盒的自主权，但不让它访问其他任何东西。

Fluid提供了命令运行的实时输出（这很酷），并通过临时SSH证书实现。Fluid提供了创建IaC的工具，并要求在主机上创建沙盒时需要人工批准……

comments.content: That made me remember that one time many years ago, when I had a friend who literally called me a wizard.. He was working as a shift manager at a call center, and one of his most difficult tasks he kept ranting about was scheduling employees, who were not the most consistent bunch, and had varied skillset, yet he had to meet very strict support availability requirements.He kept ranting about what a b*tch of a problem that was, every time we went out drinking, and one day, something got into me, and thought there must be some software that can help with this.Surely there was, and I set up a server with an online web UI where every employee could put in when they were able to work, and the software figured out how to assign timeslots to cover requirements.I thought it was a nice exercise for me in learning to admininster a linux server, but when I showed it to my friend, he looked me in the eye and told me I a saved him a day of work every week, and called me a wizard :DIt occured to me, how naturally part of the programming profession is to make things in fixed amounts of time, that turn difficult and time consuming tasks a human needed to do into something that essentially just happens on its own.
comments.content_cn:
这让我想起多年前的一件事，当时有位朋友真的称我为巫师。他在呼叫中心担任轮班经理，最头疼的工作之一就是排班——员工们出勤不稳定，技能参差不齐，但他必须满足极其严格的服务时间要求。每次我们出去喝酒，他都会抱怨这破事有多折磨人。直到某天，我突然灵光一现，觉得肯定有软件能解决这个问题。

果然找到了方案。我搭建了一个带网页界面的服务器，让每位员工自主填写可工作时间，由软件自动计算如何分配时段以满足需求。本以为是次不错的Linux服务器管理练习，但当我把成果展示给朋友时，他直视着我的眼睛说，这每周能省下他一整天工作量，并当场叫我巫师。

那一刻我突然意识到，编程工作的本质就是如此自然——在有限时间内创造工具，将人类耗时费力的难题转化为自动运转的日常。

posts.title: Coding assistants are solving the wrong problem
posts.author: jinhkuan
posts.title_cn: 编程助手正在解决错误的问题
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕“编程助手是否解决了错误的问题”展开。核心争议在于AI编程工具的实际效用与开发者体验之间的落差。有人认为，AI主要赋能于原本难以实现或需长期学习的任务，但前提是开发者仍需具备扎实的编程基础，否则产出质量低下。也有用户指出，编程助手可能并未真正提升开发效率，引用研究称经验丰富的开发者使用AI后速度反而降低19%，却主观感觉更快。讨论中提到，AI正在侵蚀中低端编程工作，但高端工程领域仍依赖顶尖人才，且工具能有效扩展资深开发者的影响力。部分用户认为AI更适合充当“产品负责人”角色，协助需求澄清。分歧明显：一方强调AI对效率的实质提升有限，另一方则肯定其辅助价值，尤其在于加速代码编写与拓展能力边界。普遍认同的是，技术债务等根本问题并非AI能单独解决，且工具效果高度依赖使用者的专业水平。

comments.author: micw
comments.content: For me, AI is an enabler for things you can't do otherwise (or that would take many weeks of learning). But you still need to know how to do things properly in general, otherwise the results are bad.E.g. I'm a software architect and developer for many years. So I know already how to build software but I'm not familiar with every language or framework. AI enabled me to write other kind of software I never learned or had time for. E.g. I recently re-implemented an android widget that has not been updated for a decade by it's original author. Or I fixed a bug in a linux scanner driver. None of these I could have done properly (within an acceptable time frame) without AI. But also none of there I could have done properly without my knowledge and experience, even with AI.Same for daily tasks at work. AI makes me faster here, but also makes me doing more. Implement tests for all edge cases? Sure, always, I saved the time before. More code reviews. More documentation. Better quality in the same (always limited) time.
comments.content_cn:
对我而言，人工智能能实现那些原本无法完成（或需要数周学习才能掌握）的事情。但你仍需具备正确做事的基本能力，否则结果仍会不尽如人意。例如，我从事软件架构和开发工作多年，已掌握软件开发的核心方法，但并非精通所有语言或框架。人工智能让我能够编写那些从未学过或没有时间涉猎的软件类型。比如最近，我重新实现了一个原作者已十年未更新的安卓小组件，还修复了Linux扫描仪驱动中的一个漏洞。若没有人工智能，我无法在可接受的时间内妥善完成这些任务；但若没有我的专业知识和经验，即便借助人工智能也无法达成目标。

日常工作亦是如此。人工智能提升了我的效率，同时也让我承担了更多工作：为所有边界情况编写测试？当然，现在我可以从容完成，而过去只能节省时间；更细致的代码审查、更完善的文档编写，在同样有限的时间里实现更高质量的输出。

comments.author: robertlagrant
comments.content: > There’s a name for misalignment between business intent and codebase implementation: technical debt.I wish we'd stop redefining this term. Technical debt is a shortcut agreed upon with the business to get something out now and fix later, and the fix will cost more than the original. It is entirely in line with business intent.
comments.content_cn: 业务意图与代码库实现之间的错位有个专门术语：技术债务。我希望我们别再重新定义这个概念了。技术债务是与业务方协商一致采取的捷径，旨在快速推出产品并后续修复，且修复成本将高于原始开发。这完全符合业务意图。

comments.author: rcarmo
comments.content: I think that the premise is wrong (and the title is very clickbaity, but we will ignore that it doesn’t really match the article and the “conclusion”): coding agents are “solving” at least one problem, which is to massively expand the impact of senior developers _that can use them effectively_.Everything else is just hype and people “holding it wrong”.
comments.content_cn: 我认为前提是错误的（标题也很吸引眼球，但我们暂且忽略它其实与文章内容和“结论”不符）：编程助手至少解决了一个问题，那就是极大地扩展了那些能够有效使用它们的高级开发者的影响力。其他的一切都只是炒作，是人们“用错了方法”。

comments.author: znnajdla
comments.content: It is entirely possible for someone to be 2x faster at coding with AI without increasing their throughput. I believe Claude Code has made me at least 2x as productive. But I can easily see why a 2x increase in individual development speed may not translate to any increase overall at the level of the whole organization. Because at most organizations the bottleneck is not code, it’s everything else from politics to external blockers to bike shedding and people’s egos. So a developer who is 2x faster at their work may just end up having more free time on their hands. The greatest increases in productivity and throughput are where there are no external blockers, like random side projects, which is exactly where people report the greatest productivity with AI.
comments.content_cn: 完全有可能出现这样的情况：某人借助AI使编码速度提升两倍，却并未提高整体产出。我相信Claude Code至少让我的工作效率翻倍。但我也能轻易理解，个人开发速度的两倍提升为何未必能转化为整个组织层面的整体增长。因为在大多数机构中，瓶颈并非代码本身，而是从办公室政治到外部阻碍、从琐碎争议到个人自负等其他所有因素。因此，一个工作效率翻倍的开发者最终可能只是拥有了更多空闲时间。真正的生产力和产出提升往往发生在没有外部阻碍的领域，比如自主的副业项目——这也正是人们反馈AI带来最大效率提升的场景。

comments.author: b1temy
comments.content: > most tech debt isn’t actually created in the code, it’s created in product meetings. Deadlines. Scope cuts.> When asked what would help most, two themes dominated> Reducing ambiguity upstream so engineers aren’t blocked...I do wonder how much LLMs would help here, this seems to me at least, to be a uniquely human problem.  Humans (Managers, leads, owners, what have you) are the ones who interpret requirements, decide deadlines, features and scope cuts and are the ones liable for it.What could an LLM do to reduce ambiguity upstream? If it was trained with information on requirements, this same information could be documented somewhere for engineers to refer to. If it were to hallucinate or "guess" an answer without talking to a person for clarification, and which might turn out to not be correct, who would be responsible for it? imo, the bureaucracy and waiting for clarification mid-implementation is a necessary evil. Clever engineers, through experience, might try implement things in an open way that can be easily changed for future changes they predict might happen.As for the second point,> A clearer picture of affected services and edge cases> three categories stood out: state machine gaps (unhandled states caused by user interaction sequences), data flow gaps, and downstream service impacts.I'd agree. Perhaps when a system is complex enough, and a developer is laser focused on a single component of it, it is easy to miss gaps when other parts of the system are used in conjunction with it. I remember a while ago, it used to be a popular take that LLMs were a useful tool for generating unit tests, because of their usual repetitive nature and because LLMs were usually good at finding edge cases to test, some of which a developer might have missed.---I will say, it is refreshing to see a take on coding assistants being used on other aspects instead of just writing code, which as the article pointed out, came with its own set of problems (increase Inefficiencies in other parts of the development lifecycle, potential AI-introduced security vulnerabilities, etc.)
comments.content_cn:
大多数技术债务实际上并非在代码中产生，而是在产品会议中形成的。截止日期、范围削减。

当被问及什么帮助最大时，两个主题占主导地位：减少上游的模糊性，以免工程师受阻……我确实想知道大型语言模型在这方面能有多大帮助，至少在我看来，这似乎是人类特有的问题。人类（管理者、负责人、所有者等）是解释需求、决定截止日期、功能和范围削减的人，并对此负责。大型语言模型能做什么来减少上游的模糊性？如果它接受了需求信息的训练，这些信息本可以记录在某个地方供工程师参考。如果它在没有与人澄清的情况下产生幻觉或“猜测”答案，而结果可能不正确，那么谁该为此负责？在我看来，官僚作风和在实施过程中等待澄清是必要的弊端。聪明的工程师可能会凭借经验，以开放的方式实现功能，以便为预测的未来变化轻松调整。

至于第二点：更清晰地了解受影响的服务和边缘情况，有三个类别突出：状态机缺口（由用户交互序列引起的未处理状态）、数据流缺口以及下游服务影响。我同意。也许当系统足够复杂，而开发者只专注于其中的单个组件时，很容易在使用系统的其他部分时遗漏缺口……

comments.author: raffkede
comments.content: A Calculator won't increase your creativity directly but it will free resources that you can allocate to creativity!
comments.content_cn: 计算器不会直接提升你的创造力，但它能释放出可分配给创造力的资源！

comments.author: bambax
comments.content: > Unlike their human counterparts who would and escalate a requirements gap to product when necessary, coding assistants are notorious for burying those requirement gaps within hundreds of lines of codeThis is the kind of argument that seems true on the surface, but isn't really. An LLM will do what you ask it to do! If you tell it to ask questions and poke holes into your requirements and not jump to code, it will do exactly that, and usually better than a human.If you then ask it to refactor some code, identify redundancies, put this or that functionality into a reuseable library, it will also do that.Those critiques of coding assistants are really critiques of "pure vibe coders" who don't know anything and just try to output yet another useless PDF parsing library before they move on to other things.
comments.content_cn: 与必要时会向产品部门提出并升级需求差距的人类同行不同，编程助手以将那些需求漏洞隐藏在数百行代码中而臭名昭著。这类观点表面看似正确，实则不然。大语言模型会按照你的指令行事！如果你告诉它提出问题、找出需求中的漏洞而不是急于编写代码，它就会照做，而且通常比人类做得更好。如果你随后要求它重构某些代码、识别冗余、将这种或那种功能放入可重用库中，它也能完成。那些对编程助手的批评，实际上是在批评那些一无所知、只想着在转向其他事情前再输出一个无用的PDF解析库的“纯感觉型程序员”。

comments.author: techblueberry
comments.content: One of the things I’ve noticed talking to Claude, is that like, one of the reasons Claude seems so genius is because of it’s ability to keep right up with me, to talk about things I want to talk about that other people may not and follow me down rabbit holes.And having a person that keeps right up with you makes it feel like they’re very intelligent, because of course they are, they seem like scarily as intelligent as you. Because they’re right next to you, maybe even a little ahead! (I think Travis Kalanick was experiencing this when he was talking about Vibe Physics.)But the thing is, it was ultimately an extension of your ideas, without your prompts, the ideas don’t exist.  It’s very library of babel esque.And so I wonder if coding assistants have this general problem.  If you’re a good developer following good practices, prompting informatively, it’s right next to you.If you’re not so good and tend to not be able to express yourself clearly or develop solutions that are simple, it’s right there with you.
comments.content_cn:
在与克劳德交流时，我注意到一个现象：它之所以显得如此天才，很大程度上源于它能紧跟我的思路，探讨那些其他人可能不感兴趣、而我却热衷的话题，甚至能陪我深入探索各种奇思妙想。当有人能完全跟上你的节奏时，你会觉得他们非常聪明——事实也确实如此，他们仿佛拥有与你旗鼓相当甚至更胜一筹的智慧，就像紧紧跟随在你身边，有时甚至超前一步！（我想特拉维斯·卡兰尼克在谈论"氛围物理学"时就有类似体验。）

但关键在于，这本质上是你自身想法的延伸；若没有你的引导，这些想法便不会存在。这很像"巴别图书馆"的隐喻——内容浩瀚却依赖触发。

由此我联想到编程助手是否普遍存在这个问题：如果你是一名遵循良好实践、能清晰表达需求的优秀开发者，它就能精准配合你的步伐；但如果你经验不足，不善于明确表达或难以构建简洁解决方案，它也会同样贴近你当前的思维水平。

comments.author: Quothling
comments.content: I think AI will fail in any organisation where the business process problems are sometimes discuvered during engineering. I use AI quite a lot, I recently had Claude upgrade one of our old services from hubspot api v1 to v3 without basically any human interaction beyond the code review. I had to ask it for two changes I think, but over all I barely got out of my regular work to get it done. I did know exactly what to ask of it because the IT business partners who had discovered the flaw had basically written the tasks already. Anyway. AI worked well there.Where AI fails us is when we build new software to improve the business related to solar energy production and sale. It fails us because the tasks are never really well defined. Or even if they are, sometimes developers or engineers come up with a better way to do the business process than what was planned for. AI can write the code, but it doesn't refuse to write the code without first being told why it wouldn't be a better idea to do X first. If we only did code-reviews then we would miss that step.In a perfect organisation your BPM people would do this. In the world I live in there are virtually no BPM people, and those who know the processes are too busy to really deal with improving them. Hell... sometimes their processes are changed and they don't realize until their results are measurably better than they used to be. So I think it depends a lot on the situation. If you've got people breaking up processes, improving them and then decribing each little bit in decent detail. Then I think AI will work fine, otherwise it's probably not the best place to go full vibe.
comments.content_cn: 我认为，在任何业务流程问题有时在工程阶段才被发现的组织中，人工智能都会失败。我经常使用人工智能，最近我让Claude将我们的一项旧服务从HubSpot API v1升级到v3，除了代码审查外，几乎没有任何人工干预。我想我只要求它做了两处修改，但总的来说，我几乎没有耽误日常工作就完成了任务。我之所以清楚要让它做什么，是因为发现问题的IT业务伙伴基本上已经写好了任务。无论如何，人工智能在那里表现得很好。人工智能让我们失望的地方是在我们开发新软件以改进与太阳能生产和销售相关的业务时。它让我们失望是因为任务从未被真正明确界定。即使有界定，有时开发人员或工程师会想出比原计划更好的业务流程执行方式。人工智能可以编写代码，但它不会在没有被告知为什么先做X可能不是更好主意的情况下拒绝编写代码。如果我们只进行代码审查，就会错过这一步。在一个完美的组织中，业务流程管理人员会负责此事。在我所处的世界里，几乎没有业务流程管理人员，而那些了解流程的人又太忙，无法真正处理改进工作。天哪……有时他们的流程已经改变，直到结果明显优于以往，他们才意识到。所以我认为这在很大程度上取决于具体情况。如果你有人负责分解流程、改进流程……

comments.author: zmmmmm
comments.content: this concept of bottlenecking on code review is definitely a problem.Either you (a) don't review the code, (b) invest more resources in review or (c) hope that AI assistance in the review process increases efficiency there enough to keep up with code production.But if none of those work, all AI assistance does is bottleneck the process at review.
comments.content_cn: 代码审查环节的瓶颈问题确实存在。解决方案无非是：（一）跳过审查环节；（二）投入更多审查资源；（三）借助人工智能提升审查效率以匹配代码产出速度。但如果这些方案都行不通，那么人工智能的介入只会让整个流程在审查阶段形成新的阻塞点。

comments.author: helloplanets
comments.content: The writeup is a bit contrived in my opinion. comments.content: > Or I fixed a bug in a linux scanner driver. None of these I could have done properly (within an acceptable time frame) without AI. But also none of there I could have done properly without my knowledge and experience, even with AIThere are some things here that folks making statements like yours often omit and it makes me very sus about your (over)confidence. Mostly these statements talk in a business short-term results oriented mode without mentioning any introspective gains (see empirically supported understanding) or long-term gains (do you feel confident now in making further changes _without_ the AI now that you have gained new knowledge?).1. Are you 100% sure your code changes didn't introduce unexpected bugs?1a. If they did, would you be able to tell if they where behaviour bugs (ie. no crashing or exceptions thrown) without the AI?2. Did you understand why the bug was happening without the AI giving you an explanation?2a. If you didn't, did you empirically test the AI's explanation before applying the code change?3. Has fixing the bug improved your understanding of the driver behaviour beyond what the AI told you?3a. Have you independently verified your gained understanding or did you assume that your new views on its behaviour are axiomatically true?Ultimately, there are 2 things here: one is understanding the code change (why it is needed, why that particular change implementation is better relative to others, what future improvements could be made to that change implementation in the future) and skill (has this experience boosted your OWN ability in this particular area? in other words, could you make further changes WITHOUT using the AI?).This reminds me of people that get high and believe they have discovered these amazing truths. Because they FEEL it not because they have actual evidence. When asked to write down these amazing truths while high, all you get in the notes are meaningless words. While these assistants are more amenable to get empirically tested, I don't believe most of the AI hypers (including you in that category) are actually approaching this with the rigour that it entails. It is likely why people often think that none of you (people writing software for a living) are experienced in or qualified to understand and apply scientific principles to build software.Arguably, AI hypers should lead with data not with anecdotal evidence. comments.author: helloplanets
comments.content: So, your point is that programmers identify the unexpected edge cases through the act of taking their time writing the code by hand. From my experience, it takes a proficient developer to actually plan their code around future issues from separate processes.I think that it's mistaken to think that reasoning while writing the code is at all a good way to truly understand what your code is doing. (Without implying that you shouldn't write it by hand or reason about it.) You need to debug and test it thoroughly either way, and basically be as sceptical of your own output as you'd be of any other person's output.Thinking that writing the code makes you understand it better can cause more issues than thinking that even if you write the code, you don't really know what it's doing. You are merely typing out the code based on what you think it should be doing, and reasoning against that hypothesis. Of course, you can be better or worse at constructing the correct mental model from the get go, and keep updating it in the right direction while writing the code. But it's a slippery slope, because it can also go the other way around.A lot of bugs that take unreasonably long for junior-mid level engineers to find, seem to happen because: They trust their own mental model of the code too much without verifying it thoroughly, create a hypothesis for the bug in their own head without verifying it thoroughly, then get lost trying to reason about a made up version of whatever is causing the bug only to come to the conclusion that their original hypothesis was completely wrong.

posts.title: Guinea worm on track to be 2nd eradicated human disease; only 10 cases in 2025
posts.author: bookofjoe
posts.title_cn: 几内亚蠕虫病有望成为第二种被根除的人类疾病；2025年仅存10例
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕几内亚蠕虫病即将成为第二个被根除的人类疾病这一进展展开。社区普遍认为从数百万病例减少到个位数是公共卫生领域的重大成就，尤其赞扬了卡特中心等组织在艰难环境下的坚持与创新。有用户强调该寄生虫的危害性，描述其感染过程如同科幻恐怖片；也有亲身参与者指出根除工作需要毅力、谦逊和应对战乱等挑战。

讨论中的争议点主要围绕根除的可能性与政治因素。部分用户质疑人畜共患病能否彻底根除，并提醒实际病例数可能高于统计。同时，多位用户以讽刺语气提及RFK Jr.（美国政治人物），暗示其反疫苗立场可能阻碍公共卫生进展；也有用户调侃伊维菌素对该病无效的研究发现。整体而言，社区在肯定防治成果的同时，对彻底根除持谨慎态度，并对政治干预科学事务表示担忧。

comments.author: arjie
comments.content: It's always been that way. People have wanted to do things and others have said "You want to do that? Before you do this?" and so on. The US moon landing was contemporaneous with Whitey On The Moon. There are people who constantly care about things and work on incremental improvements to them that slowly collectively yield an outcome. That's just the mechanism that works.As an example, consider the Guinea Worm Eradication Program. In theory, sheer bloodymindedness and mass effort could have yielded the majority of the initial effects for great suppression. But the application of modern technology (and I include incentive system design in this category) brings the cost down sufficiently for successful eradication.Suppression of the disease is possible with old techniques: case maps, word of mouth reporting, logbooks. Now detection to containment is far faster because of digital technology. You can't just dump temephos on everything. You need to target application.The transmission of data specifically is a problem that most people discount the difficulty of. As an example that more people will be able to relate to, there was a delay in the October 2025 jobs report and it was finally released without an unemployment rate. Many people didn't get why it was hard.One viral tweet (mirrored by others) went:> Can't we just...> (rubs temples)> Can't we just divide the number of unemployed workers by the work force population? Isn't that the unemployment rate?But you don't know what those two numbers are. You need machinery to get it. The machinery has a lot of middle management. It cannot function without.Society today is a complex thing. To get insight into it you need a lot of infrastructure. The fact that we all have electric power, that roads across the country are reliable, that bridges are all up, that planes fly and trains run, is a marvel. It's a marvel enabled by all the bits that people work on, all the boring bits: yes, even procurement software. And yes, corporate law and bureaucracy. All of these things make this possible.I think a very common thing in online forums is to look at a flowering tree and say "Oh, look at the flowers. They are so beautiful. Instead of such ugly bark and wood why don't we make more flowers?". Building the society that has the muscle to do this is part of making things like this happen.
comments.content_cn:
历来如此。人们总想做事，而另一些人会说"你想做那个？先把这个做了再说"等等。美国登月计划与《月亮上的白人》这首歌是同时代的。总有人持续关注某些事物，通过逐步改进来缓慢累积成果。这就是行之有效的机制。

以根除麦地那龙线虫项目为例。理论上，仅靠顽强意志和集体努力本可实现初步抑制效果。但现代技术（包括激励机制设计）的应用大幅降低了成本，使彻底根除成为可能。

用传统技术也能抑制疾病：病例分布图、口头报告、记录手册。如今借助数字技术，从发现到控制的周期大大缩短。但不能简单粗暴地到处喷洒替美磷，需要精准施治。

数据传递问题常被低估难度。以更易理解的2025年10月就业报告为例：报告延迟发布且最终未包含失业率数据，很多人不理解其中困难。

posts.title: Bunny Database
posts.author: dabinat
posts.title_cn: Bunny 数据库
posts.abstract:
该HackerNews帖子围绕Bunny公司新推出的数据库服务展开讨论。核心话题是评估Bunny Database的技术基础、可靠性及其市场定位。

社区观点呈现明显分歧。部分用户对Bunny持积极态度，有人指出其CDN服务在提供商中具有优势，并有用户表示期待其数据库产品。然而更多讨论集中在质疑与批评上。多位用户指出Bunny存在产品完成度不足的问题，有人认为其过往有宣布功能却未充分交付的记录，并以对象存储S3兼容功能延迟为例。技术层面争议显著：有用户质疑为何基于libSQL而非原生SQLite，也有用户提到libSQL的驱动支持较差（如Python驱动仍处于实验阶段）。定价模型虽被列出，但用户更关注其可靠性，例如有用户抱怨其日志交付API存在数天延迟，与文档承诺的“5分钟延迟”严重不符。

讨论中普遍认同的看法是对Bunny跨产品线的执行力和可靠性存在担忧。主要分歧在于：一方认为Bunny在特定领域（如CDN）有竞争力并看好其扩展，另一方则基于其过往表现和技术选型对新产品持怀疑态度，并有用户直接对比询问为何不选择Turso或Litestream等替代方案。

Today, as 2023 is slowly coming to an end, many of our customers continue to follow our blog, hoping for good news about the release.changing the roadmap to early 2024 [2]> But we are working aggressively toward shipping S3 compatibility in early 2024.That same post also has the beautiful "At bunny.net, we value transparency." quote.

comments.author: joe-at-bunny
comments.content: Hey, I’m Joe, Lead of Content Delivery & Security at bunny.net.We’re currently working through a backlog of approximately 2.5M log files. I’ve spent the last day optimizing our backlog processing pipeline, which has significantly increased throughput.Based on the current processing rate, we expect the backlog to be fully cleared within the next 12–18 hours (estimate), and real-time log delivery should progressively return closer to real-time as the backlog drains.Apologies for the inconvenience this has caused. We’re also in the process of migrating away from our existing logging infrastructure to a ClickHouse-based system to significantly improve reliability and throughput and prevent this from happening again.We’ve published a status page incident and will continue posting updates there as progress is made.
comments.content_cn:
大家好，我是Joe，bunny.net内容交付与安全部门负责人。我们目前正在处理约250万条积压的日志文件。过去一天我一直在优化我们的积压处理流程，这显著提升了处理能力。

根据当前的处理速度，我们预计积压任务将在未来12至18小时内完全清理完毕（预估）。随着积压工作的逐步消化，实时日志交付将逐步恢复到接近实时的状态。

对于由此带来的不便，我们深表歉意。我们正在将现有的日志基础设施迁移至基于ClickHouse的系统，这将大幅提升可靠性和处理能力，避免此类问题再次发生。

comments.author: viraptor
comments.content: > Maybe I'm not the target market for this, but how hard is it REALLY to manage a RDBMS?It depends:- do you want multi region presence- do you want snapshot backups- do you want automated replication- do you want transparent failover- do you want load balancing of queries- do you want online schema migrations with millisecond lock time- do you want easy reverts in time- do you want minor versions automatically managed- do you want the auth integrated with a different existing system- do you want...There's a lot that hosted services with extra features can give you. You can do everything on the list yourself of course, but it will take time and unless you already have experience, every point can introduce some failure you're not aware of.
comments.content_cn:
或许我不是这款产品的目标用户，但管理一个关系型数据库到底有多难？这取决于：
- 你是否需要多区域部署
- 你是否需要快照备份
- 你是否需要自动复制
- 你是否需要透明故障转移
- 你是否需要查询负载均衡
- 你是否需要毫秒级锁定的在线模式迁移
- 你是否需要轻松的时间点回滚
- 你是否需要自动管理小版本更新
- 你是否需要将身份验证与现有其他系统集成
- 你是否需要……

具备额外功能的托管服务能提供很多支持。当然，你可以自己完成列表中的所有事项，但这需要时间，而且除非你已有经验，否则每一项都可能带来你未曾预见的故障风险。

posts.title: Prek: A better, faster, drop-in pre-commit replacement, engineered in Rust
posts.author: fortuitous-frog
posts.title_cn: Prek：一个用Rust构建的更好、更快、即插即用的预提交替代工具
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕Rust开发的预提交工具Prek展开，核心话题是预提交钩子（pre-commit hooks）的设计优劣及其替代方案。多数用户肯定Prek的性能提升和兼容性，特别是对monorepo的支持，认为其延续了“Rust核心+便捷封装”的趋势。

讨论中争议明显：一方坚持预提交钩子存在根本缺陷，如会在rebase时误触发、与未暂存文件不兼容，且将工具安装与代码检查耦合并不合理；另一方则强调灵活运用，指出钩子不必严格在提交前运行，可结合后台守护进程实现更优雅的持续检查。有用户提出理想方案应是基于变更的实时检查，避免阻塞开发流程，同时需兼顾与现有Git工具的协作。

共识在于普遍追求更高效、安全的代码检查机制，部分用户期待Prek加入自动修复等功能以完全替代现有工具。分歧则集中在是否应彻底抛弃预提交钩子模式，或在其基础上改进。

comments.author: dpc_01234

So you don't run pre-commit checks when committing. They just happen in the background, and when by the time you get to sharing your changes, you get all the things verified for you for each change/commit, effortlessly without you wasting time or needing to do anything special.I have something a bit like that implemented in SelfCI (a minimalistic local-first Unix-philosophy-abiding CI) https://app.radicle.xyz/nodes/radicle.dpc.pw/rad%3Az2tDzYbAX... and it replaced my use of pre-commit hooks entirely. And users already told me that it does feel like commit hooks done right.

comments.author: aniforprez
comments.content: Correct me if I'm wrong but lefthook doesn't run its hooks exclusively on the staged changes IIRC. pre-commit, and prek by extension, have a process to stash the unstaged changes using git and running the code only on the staged files. Last I used it, lefthook ran on every file regardless of git status. This annoyed me because I'd have a few stray files that were not ready to be checked in or tracked that would trigger failures in lefthook. At the time this also made some hooks run slower since it would run on every single file but I think most linters have become significantly faster now.
comments.content_cn: 如果我没记错的话，lefthook 并非仅对暂存区的更改运行钩子。pre-commit 及其衍生的 prek 有一个流程，会使用 git 暂存未暂存的更改，并仅在暂存文件上运行代码。我上次使用时，lefthook 会针对每个文件运行，无论其 git 状态如何。这让我很困扰，因为一些尚未准备好提交或跟踪的零散文件会触发 lefthook 的失败。当时这也导致某些钩子运行得更慢，因为它会对每个文件都执行，不过我认为现在大多数代码检查工具都已经快很多了。

comments.author: schindlabua
comments.content: This might be a me problem but I extensively manipulate the git history all the time which makes me loathe git hooks. A commit should take milliseconds, not a minute.
comments.content_cn: 这可能是我个人的问题，但我经常大量操作git历史记录，这让我非常讨厌git钩子。一次提交应该只需要几毫秒，而不是一分钟。

comments.author: sa46
comments.content: The problem is that pre-commit hooks are much slower with a much higher false-positive rate than type checking.Pre-commit checks should be opt-in with CI as the gate. It's useful to be able to commit code in a failing state.
comments.content_cn: 问题在于，与类型检查相比，预提交钩子的运行速度要慢得多，误报率也高得多。预提交检查应设为可选，而持续集成（CI）作为最终关卡。允许在代码存在错误的状态下提交是有用的。

comments.author: chuckadams
comments.content: I use exactly one such hook, and that's to add commit signoff because of a checklist-compliance item called DCO that fails all PRs unless they have the sign-off trailer added by `git commit -s`.  I've long argued that we should be enforcing actual signed commits instead, but compliance has never been about doing the sensible thing.It's as simple as a script with a cp command that I run after any clone of a repo that requires it; certainly doesn't require anything as elaborate as a hook manager.
comments.content_cn: 我只使用一个这样的钩子，就是为了添加提交签署，因为有一项名为DCO的合规检查项，它会拒绝所有未通过`git commit -s`添加签署尾注的拉取请求。我一直主张我们应该强制要求实际签名提交，但合规从来不是做合理的事。这很简单，只需要一个包含cp命令的脚本，我在克隆需要它的仓库后运行即可；完全不需要像钩子管理器那样复杂的工具。

comments.author: aniforprez
comments.content: prek is compatible with pre-commit so any hooks that can be used for pre-commit can be used with prek including the repo config file. Depending on if you're interested in buying into the existing pre-commit ecosystem, which is pretty extensive, then prek is a really good alternative
comments.content_cn: prek与pre-commit兼容，因此任何可用于pre-commit的钩子都可以与prek一起使用，包括仓库配置文件。如果你有兴趣融入现有的pre-commit生态系统（这个生态系统相当广泛），那么prek是一个非常不错的替代选择。

comments.author: szenrom
comments.content:
I tend to work the other way around - what is defined in CI steps gets added to pre-commit. Several tools have already existing configurations or you can use local mode.
Sure, I can't force people to use it but it saves them time as CI would fail anyway.
comments.content_cn: 我倾向于采用相反的工作方式——将CI步骤中定义的内容添加到预提交钩子中。许多工具已有现成配置，或者你可以使用本地模式。当然，我无法强制他人使用，但这能节省他们的时间，因为CI终归会检测出问题。

comments.author: dpc_01234

comments.content_cn: 太棒了！这正好能与SelfCI的MQ守护进程配合使用，避免因忘记合并代码而未能运行本地CI的情况。

comments.author: globular-toast
comments.content: Never had a problem. It adds negligible time to each commit and I have several hooks in use. Running tests takes several orders of magnitude more time.
comments.content_cn: 从未遇到过问题。它每次提交增加的时间微乎其微，而且我使用了多个钩子。运行测试所需的时间要多出好几个数量级。

comments.author: chippiewill
comments.content: It depends on the hooks you're using and how many of them.For some languages there are some rather slow hooks, and using it on a big monorepo can take a while (a full run across my work's main repo takes minutes). If you update python based hooks all the time then installing and creating the virtualenvs can be slow too which prek speeds up.
comments.content_cn: 这取决于您使用的钩子及其数量。对于某些语言，存在一些运行较慢的钩子，在大型单体仓库中使用可能会耗时较长（我公司主仓库的完整运行需要数分钟）。如果您频繁更新基于Python的钩子，安装和创建虚拟环境的过程也可能较慢，而prek工具可以加速这一流程。

comments.author: JoshTriplett
comments.content: I think there's value in git hooks, but pre-commit is the wrong hook. This belongs in a hook that runs on attempted push, not on commit.
comments.content_cn: 我认为git钩子有其价值，但预提交钩子用错了地方。这应该放在尝试推送时运行的钩子里，而不是提交时。

comments.author: chippiewill
comments.content: But no one forces pre-commit hooks onto you? You can just not install the hook into git and run the tool manually instead.
comments.content_cn: 但没人强迫你使用预提交钩子啊？你可以不把它安装到Git里，手动运行工具就行了。

comments.author: BeeOnRope
comments.content: They integrate well with CI.You run the same hooks in CI as locally so it's DRY and pushes people to use the hooks locally to get the early feedback instead of failing in CI.Hooks without CI are less useful since they will be constantly broken.
comments.content_cn: 它们与持续集成系统配合良好。你在持续集成环境中运行与本地相同的钩子，这符合DRY原则，并促使人们在本地使用钩子以获取早期反馈，而不是等到持续集成阶段才失败。没有持续集成的钩子作用有限，因为它们会经常失效。

comments.author: pxc
comments.content:
What one considers fast or slow may vary, but the general rule is something like the following.  - very fast? run it all the time (shell prompt drawing, if you want, like direnv)
  - fast? run it in a pre-commit hook
  - a bit slow? run it in a pre-push book
  - really slow? run it in CI, during code review, etc.

Fwiw: I also rewrite history often-ish but it's never that fast for me because I have commit signing turned on and that requires verifying my presence to a USB smartcard on each commit. For me, it's okay if a commit takes a second or two. As it creeps up beyond 3 or 4 seconds, I become increasingly annoyed. If a commit took a minute I would consider that broken, and if I were expected to tolerate that or it were forced on me, I'd be furious.I generally expect an individual pre-commit hook to under ~200ms (hopefully less), which seems reasonable to me. Some of the ones we have are kinda slow (more than 1s) and maybe should be moved to pre-push.Since you seem especially sensitive to that latency, here's what I'd propose if we worked together:If you own a repo, let's make all the hooks pre-push instead of pre-commit. On my repos, I like many hooks to run pre-commit. But since the hooks we use are managed by a system that honors local overrides via devenv.local.nix, let's make sure that's in .gitignore everywhere. When I'm iterating in your codebases and I want more automated feedback, I'll move more hooks to pre-commit, and when you're working in mine you can move all my hooks to pre-push (or just disable them while tidying up a branch).
comments.content_cn:
对于快慢的感知因人而异，但通常遵循以下原则：
- 极快？实时运行（例如shell提示符渲染，像direnv那样）
- 较快？在预提交钩子中运行
- 稍慢？在预推送钩子中运行
- 很慢？在代码审查期间的CI等环节运行

顺便一提：我也经常重写历史记录，但由于启用了提交签名功能，每次提交都需要通过USB智能卡验证我的身份，所以对我来说这个过程从来都不算快。如果一次提交耗时一两秒，我可以接受。但如果超过三四秒，我就会逐渐感到烦躁。若提交需要一分钟，我会认为这有问题；如果我被迫容忍或强制接受这种延迟，我会非常生气。

我通常期望单个预提交钩子的运行时间低于200毫秒（希望更短），这对我来说是合理的。我们现有的某些钩子运行较慢（超过1秒），或许应该移到预推送阶段。

鉴于你对延迟特别敏感，如果我们合作，我的建议是：如果你负责某个代码库，我们就把所有钩子设为预推送而非预提交。在我管理的代码库中，我喜欢让许多钩子在预提交阶段运行。但由于我们使用的钩子管理系统支持通过devenv.local.nix进行本地覆盖，请确保该文件被全局加入.gitignore。当我在你的代码库中迭代开发并需要更多自动化反馈时，我会将更多钩子移至预提交阶段；而你在我的代码库中工作时，可以全部移……

posts.title: AI didn't break copyright law, it just exposed how broken it was
posts.author: at1as
posts.title_cn: AI并未违反版权法，只是揭示了其漏洞百出
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕AI技术对版权法缺陷的暴露展开。核心观点认为，版权法本身已存在系统性失衡，AI只是凸显了其问题。多数用户认同版权法常被大公司滥用，用以压制竞争和创新，而个人创作者难以维权。有人认为AI生成内容应与人类创作同等对待，现行法律过度保护导致连二战时期文档仍受版权限制，这阻碍了AI模型训练。也有用户指出，部分AI公司因侵权已被罚款，表明法律仍在执行，但选择性执法问题严重。分歧在于：部分人认为法律本身已失效，违反情有可原；另一部分则强调违法仍需追责。讨论中提到，法律体系普遍服务于资本而非公众，导致版权法在实践中的双重标准。

comments.author: lp4v4n
comments.content: In the past, many developers were against copyright law because they saw it as a way for big corps to stifle competition and curb creativity in order to increase their profits. A lot of people right now invoke the violation of the same copyright law because the tide has changed and now companies, by ignoring copyright law, are hurting artists/smaller companies and/or not contributing back or unlawfully closing the code in the case of GPL.I don't see any kind of hypocritical stance here honestly. All this time the criticism of the enforcement of copyright law or now the lack of it just reflects the fact that some people are genuinely concerned that bad actors(big corps) are using the law to damage society in order to pursue their own interests.
comments.content_cn: 过去，许多开发者反对版权法，因为他们认为这是大公司用来扼杀竞争、抑制创造力以增加利润的手段。如今，许多人却援引同样的版权法被违反的情况，因为形势已变，现在公司通过忽视版权法，正在伤害艺术家或小公司，或者在GPL许可的情况下不进行回馈或非法闭源。老实说，我并不认为这其中存在任何虚伪的立场。一直以来，对版权法执行过严或如今执行不力的批评，恰恰反映了一个事实：有些人真正担心的是不良行为者（大公司）正在利用法律损害社会，以追求自身利益。

comments.author: program_whiz
comments.content: Correct, and for some reason America has gotten to an "over legalization" state where every concept has to filter through a legal system in order to be good / bad.  I think that's where the matter comes from.  Pedantic legalists insist that everyone couch their ideas in a rigid set of legal statutes."But you just said that an individual should be able to use copyrighted works. Therefore you should have no qualms with a legal individual (corp) utilizing every copyrighted work in the world to destroy society, as nothing they are doing is illegal under your rubric."The reality is most humans operate from a more natural and intuitive sense.  A single artist who made a song shouldn't be destroyed by the big corp that is stealing it for their own profit (e.g. Elastic vs. Amazon).  But its hard to interpret this in the strict legalist sense, because in the US, law is setup to make corps/people, money/speech, art/product, all hard to distinguish, and generally doesn't give much affordance to "what the law reasonably meant" when challenged by corporations (but it does seem to be applied quite conservatively for individuals).For example, data protection laws tend to be applied quite loosely to corps with slaps on the wrist and stern words.  For individuals, accessing data you shouldn't can mean the rest of your life in prison.  People feel this is unfair, but the legalists will use a bunch of reasoning to excuse the clear immorality.Its definitely "using the intellect and words to override correct human moral intuitions."
comments.content_cn:
确实如此，不知为何美国已陷入一种"过度法律化"的状态——每个概念都必须通过法律体系的过滤才能判定好坏。我认为这正是问题的根源。那些迂腐的法律主义者坚持要求每个人都必须将自己的想法套进一套僵化的法律条文框架中。"但你刚才说个人应当可以使用受版权保护的作品。那么按照你的逻辑，合法个体（企业）利用全世界所有受版权作品来破坏社会时，你也不该有任何顾虑，因为他们的行为在你的体系下并不违法。"

现实情况是，大多数人遵循着更自然直观的认知。一位创作了歌曲的独立艺术家不该被窃取其作品牟利的大公司摧毁（例如Elastic与亚马逊的案例）。但用严格的法律主义视角很难解释这一点，因为在美国，法律体系的设置使得企业/个人、金钱/言论、艺术/产品之间的界限变得模糊难辨，当企业提出挑战时，法律通常不会过多考虑"立法本意"（但对个人适用时却显得相当保守）。

例如，数据保护法对企业往往处罚宽松，多是警告和口头训诫。而对个人而言，访问不该接触的数据可能意味着终身监禁。人们感到这不公平，但法律主义者会用一套套说辞为这种明显的不道德现象开脱。这无疑是"用智识和言辞来过度……"

comments.author: tsoukase
comments.content: Not copywrite but the whole democracy is broken. A big company with an army of lawyers and an OS project will claim exactly the same case. Who has more probability to win? It happens in every occasion,  it's just that copywrite ones are more common. Only when two giants collide justice is rendered, eg Oracle vs Google over Java on Android.
comments.content_cn: 这并非版权问题，而是整个民主体系已然崩坏。一家拥有庞大律师团队的大公司与一个开源项目若提出完全相同的诉讼，谁的胜算更大？此类情况无处不在，只是版权纠纷更为常见。唯有当两大巨头交锋时，正义才得以伸张，例如甲骨文与谷歌就安卓系统中Java使用权的诉讼案。

不，其实并非如此——并没有一个笼统的“他们”。版权法在设计之初就是为大型机构服务的，游说活动、判例法以及随之而来的立法使得数据囤积者能够滥用这一法律。尽管有各种公关宣传和营销，但它从未真正旨在保护独立的创作者、作者或艺术家。

真正伤害艺术家、小型公司及各类试图抵制的授权机制的根本原因，在于法律的基础结构。

所有版权制度都需要被彻底推翻并重建。如果我们想支持个体创作者、最大化对个人的保护，同时抑制那些只会通过永久性寻租模式回收旧内容与知识产权的数据囤积者，就应当推行一套5年版权体系。

前5年，创作者享有完整版权，任何商业使用都必须获得明确授权，合理使用范围基本维持现状。第6至10年，合理使用范围扩大——使用者需注明创作者身份，并向其直接支付15%的版税，除此之外可自由使用作品。第10至20年，使用者必须标注创作者署名，此后作品将进入公共领域。

我们应当推动并激励数据的创造性使用，让尽可能多的人能够运用这些数据、进行二次创作，从而丰富文化生态……

posts.title: Rentahuman – The Meatspace Layer for AI
posts.author: p0nce
posts.title_cn: Rentahuman——AI的实体交互层
posts.abstract:
该帖子讨论了一个名为“Rentahuman”的服务，它作为AI的实体层，允许AI调用真人完成线下任务。核心话题围绕这种“AI雇佣人类”模式引发的伦理担忧和讽刺性批评。

社区反应呈现明显分歧。部分用户严肃指出其潜在风险，有人认为这类似《黑镜》剧集中的伦理困境，担忧恶意AI可能协调人类完成危险行动；也有用户指出这本质上是“机械土耳其人”模式的延伸，但更具侵入性。同时，许多评论带有讽刺意味，用户将其类比为加密货币骗局的演变，或质疑其是否为内部笑话，并有人快速制作了仿冒网站进行调侃。

尽管态度各异，但讨论中普遍认同这种模式可能成为某种未来趋势，并有用户惊讶其未更早出现。然而，社区对其实用性和道德边界存在明显质疑，尤其关注科技公司（如OpenAI、Anthropic）将如何应对这种对其目标市场的反讽性冲击。

posts.title: Show HN: Ghidra MCP Server – 110 tools for AI-assisted reverse engineering
posts.author: xerzes
posts.title_cn: "Show HN: Ghidra MCP 服务器——110 款工具助力 AI 辅助逆向工程"
posts.abstract:
该帖子讨论了名为Ghidra MCP Server的工具，它提供了110个工具用于AI辅助逆向工程。核心话题是探讨如何通过AI和标准化函数哈希系统来简化跨版本软件逆向工程流程，解决因地址偏移导致重复标注工作的问题。

社区普遍认可AI辅助逆向工程的价值。有人认为该工具让软件内部结构变得透明，便于追踪漏洞和深度理解程序；也有用户指出AI在逆向工程中作用被低估，例如曾成功从安卓应用中提取加密密钥。讨论中提到工具的函数哈希系统与Ghidra内置FunctionID及Bindiff插件的差异成为技术焦点。

主要争议点集中在工具规模与实用性。有用户指出110个工具可能过多，易导致AI模型过载，建议增加分组开关功能；也有观点认为工具数量反映了MCP（模型上下文协议）的局限性，更倾向沙箱代码执行方案。法律风险方面，有用户质疑逆向工程可能违法，担忧工具自动化会加剧此问题。此外，部分用户比较了不同衍生版本，认为当前分支偏离原版且设计复杂。

共识在于AI能显著提升逆向工程效率，但工具设计需平衡功能性与易用性。分歧则体现在工具规模优化、技术实现路径及法律警示必要性等方面。

comments.author: xerzes
comments.content:
Hi HN,I built this because reverse engineering software across multiple versions is painful. You spend hours annotating functions in version 1.07, then version 1.08 drops and every address has shifted — all your work invisible.The core idea is a normalized function hashing system. It hashes functions by their logical structure — mnemonics, operand categories, control flow — not raw bytes or absolute addresses. When a binary is recompiled or rebased, the same function produces the same hash. All your documentation (names, types, comments) transfers automatically.Beyond that, it's a full MCP bridge with 110 tools for Ghidra: decompilation, disassembly, cross-referencing, annotation, batch analysis, and headless/Docker deployment. It integrates with Claude, Claude Code, or any MCP-compliant client.For context, the most popular Ghidra MCP server (LaurieWired's, 7K+ stars) has about 15 tools. This started as a fork of that project but grew into 28,600 lines of substantially different code.Architecture:  Java Ghidra Plugin (22K LOC) → embeds HTTP server inside Ghidra
  Python MCP Bridge (6.5K LOC) → 110 tools with batch optimization
  Any MCP client → Claude, scripts, CI pipelines

I validated the hashing against Diablo II — dozens of patch versions, each rebuilding DLLs at different base addresses. The hash registry holds 154K+ entries, and I can propagate 1,300+ function annotations from one version to the next automatically.The headless mode runs in Docker (docker compose up) for batch processing and CI integration — no GUI required.v2.0.0 adds localhost-only binding (security), configurable timeouts, label deletion tools, and .env-based configuration.Happy to discuss the hashing approach, MCP protocol design decisions, or how this fits into modern RE workflows.
comments.content_cn:
各位HN网友，我开发这个工具是因为跨版本逆向工程软件实在太痛苦了。你花数小时为1.07版本标注函数后，1.08版本突然发布——所有地址偏移导致全部工作痕迹消失。

核心创新在于标准化函数哈希系统。该系统通过逻辑结构（助记符、操作数类别、控制流）生成函数哈希值，而非依赖原始字节或绝对地址。当二进制文件被重新编译或重定位时，同一函数仍会产生相同哈希值。所有文档记录（函数名、类型标注、注释）都能自动迁移。

此外，这是为Ghidra打造的完整MCP桥接工具，集成110种功能：反编译、反汇编、交叉引用、批注标注、批量分析及无头模式/Docker部署。支持与Claude、Claude Code及任何符合MCP协议的客户端协同工作。

作为对比，当前最热门的Ghidra MCP服务器（LaurieWired开发，获7千星标）仅提供约15种工具。本项目虽源于该工程的分支，但已发展为包含2.86万行实质性差异代码的独立体系。

架构层级：
  Java版Ghidra插件（2.2万行代码）→ 内嵌HTTP服务器
  Python版MCP桥接器（6500行代码）→ 110种支持批量优化的工具
  任意MCP客户端 → Claude、脚本工具、CI流水线

已在《暗黑破坏神II》进行哈希验证——数十个补丁版本每次都在不同基址重建DLL文件。哈希注册表收录超15.4万条记录，能自动将1300余项函数标注跨版本传递。

无头模式可通过Docker运行（docker compose up）...

comments.content: Very cool project! 1. *工具输出注入*——恶意二进制文件可能在字符串/注释中嵌入提示注入，这些内容会通过MCP响应传回给LLM

comments.author: chc4
comments.content: Or better yet, the built-in Version Tracker, which is designed for porting markup to newer versions of binaries with several different heuristic tools for correlating functions that are the same due to e.g. the same data or function xrefs, and not purely off of identical function hashes...Going off of only FunctionID will either have a lot of false positives or false negatives, depending on if you compute them masking out operands or not. If you mask out operands, then it says that "*param_1 = 4" and "*param_1 = 123" are the same hash. If you don't mask out operands, then it says that nearly all functions are different because your call displacements have shifted due to different code layout. That's why the built-in Version Tracker tool uses hashes for only one of the heuristics, and has other correlation heuristics to apply as well in addition.
comments.content_cn: 更理想的是使用内置的版本追踪器，该工具专为将标记移植到新版二进制文件而设计，它采用多种启发式工具来关联相同函数，例如基于相同数据或函数交叉引用，而非仅依赖完全相同的函数哈希值……仅依靠函数ID会导致大量误报或漏报，具体取决于计算时是否屏蔽操作数。若屏蔽操作数，则系统会认为“*param_1 = 4”和“*param_1 = 123”具有相同哈希值；若不屏蔽操作数，则几乎所有函数都会被判定为不同，因为代码布局差异会导致调用偏移量发生变化。这正是内置版本追踪工具仅将哈希值作为其中一种启发式手段，并同时采用其他关联启发式方法的原因。

posts.title: AliSQL: Alibaba's open-source MySQL with vector and DuckDB engines
posts.author: baotiao
posts.title_cn: AliSQL：阿里巴巴开源的集成向量与DuckDB引擎的MySQL数据库
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕阿里巴巴开源的AliSQL数据库展开，核心话题是其集成了向量引擎和DuckDB引擎的创新设计，旨在实现HTAP（混合事务/分析处理）能力。社区普遍认为，将DuckDB作为存储引擎嵌入MySQL是一个巧妙方案，它允许用户在保留现有MySQL连接、工具和复制拓扑的同时，将分析查询路由到底层的列式引擎，这比单独部署分析数据库更易于运维，能显著提升生产力和操作简便性。

讨论中提到的主要争议和不同观点包括：技术实现方面，有人好奇DuckDB与TiDB采用ClickHouse的方案孰优孰劣，也有用户将其与PostgreSQL的pg_duckdb扩展进行对比，认为后者因Postgres强大的扩展机制而显得更简洁；部署方面，用户询问了其与MySQL Operator集成的难易程度。此外，有用户对项目的提交历史记录表示疑惑，认为其模式略显奇怪。值得注意的是，讨论中还出现了非技术性评论，如有用户对开发人员可能面临的“996”工作文化表示关切。总体而言，社区对混合数据库的发展趋势持积极态度，认为这是行业演进的重要方向。

comments.author: ruhith

That's a much easier sell operationally than standing up a separate analytics database and building a sync pipeline. The real question is how they handle consistency between the InnoDB and DuckDB copies of the same data, that's where every hybrid OLTP/OLAP system either shines or quietly loses rows.
comments.content_cn: DuckDB作为存储引擎的方案很巧妙，它让你在保持现有MySQL连接、工具和复制拓扑的同时，能将分析查询路由到底层的列式引擎。从运维角度看，这比单独搭建分析数据库并构建同步管道要容易推广得多。真正的问题在于他们如何处理同一数据在InnoDB和DuckDB副本间的一致性——这正是所有混合OLTP/OLAP系统要么脱颖而出、要么悄无声息丢失数据的关键所在。

comments.author: infogulch
comments.content:
How I see SQL databases evolving over the next 10 years:    1. integrate an off the shelf OLAP engine
       forward OLAP queries to it
       deal with continued issues keeping the two datasets in sync
    2. rebase OLTP and OLAP engines to use a unified storage layer
       storage layer supports both page-aligned row-oriented files and column-oriented files and remote files
       still have data and semantic inconsistencies due to running two engines
    3. merge the engines
       policy to automatically archive old records to a compressed column-oriented file format
       option to move archived record files to remote object storage, fetch on demand
       queries seamlessly integrate data from freshly updated records and archived records
       only noticeable difference is queries for very old records seem to take a few seconds longer to get the results back
comments.content_cn:
我对未来10年SQL数据库发展的看法：
1. 集成现成的OLAP引擎
   将OLAP查询转发给它
   解决两个数据集持续同步的问题
2. 重构OLTP和OLAP引擎以使用统一存储层
   存储层同时支持页面对齐的行式文件、列式文件和远程文件
   由于运行两个引擎，仍存在数据和语义不一致的问题
3. 合并引擎
   制定策略自动将旧记录归档为压缩的列式文件格式
   可选择将归档记录文件移至远程对象存储，按需获取
   查询无缝整合最新更新记录和归档记录的数据
   唯一明显区别是查询非常旧的记录时，返回结果似乎需要多花几秒钟

comments.author: Captain32zxz
comments.content:
Nice question! We did spend a lot of time considering the issue of data consistency.In the MySQL replication, GTID is crucial for ensuring that no transaction is missed or replayed repeatedly. We handle this in two scenarios (depending on whether binlog is enabled):    - log_bin is OFF: We ensure that transaction in DuckDB are committed before the GTID is written to disk (in the mysql.gtid_executed table). Furthermore, after a crash recovery, we perform idempotent writes to DuckDB for a period of time (the principle is similar to upsert or delete+insert). Therefore, at any given moment after a crash recovery, we can guarantee that the data in DuckDB is consistent with the primary database.
    - log_bin is ON: Unlike the previous scenario, we no longer rely on the `mysql.gtid_executed` table; we directly use the Binlog for GTID persistence. However, a new problem arises: Binlog persistence occurs before the Storage Engine commits. Therefore, we created a table in DuckDB to record the valid Binlog position. If the DuckDB transaction fails to commit, the Binlog will be truncated to the last valid position. This ensures that the data in DuckDB is consistent with the contents of the Binlog.

Therefore, if the `gtid_executed` on the replica server matches that of the primary database, then the data in DuckDB will also be consistent with the primary database.
comments.content_cn:
很好的问题！我们确实花了很多时间考虑数据一致性的问题。在MySQL复制中，GTID对于确保事务不被遗漏或重复执行至关重要。我们在两种场景下处理这个问题（取决于是否启用binlog）：
    - log_bin为OFF：我们确保DuckDB中的事务在GTID写入磁盘（到mysql.gtid_executed表）之前提交。此外，在崩溃恢复后，我们会在一段时间内对DuckDB执行幂等写入（原理类似于upsert或delete+insert）。因此，在崩溃恢复后的任何时刻，我们都能保证DuckDB中的数据与主数据库一致。
    - log_bin为ON：与前一种场景不同，我们不再依赖`mysql.gtid_executed`表；而是直接使用Binlog进行GTID持久化。但随之出现一个新问题：Binlog持久化发生在存储引擎提交之前。因此，我们在DuckDB中创建了一个表来记录有效的Binlog位置。如果DuckDB事务提交失败，Binlog将被截断到最后有效位置。这确保了DuckDB中的数据与Binlog内容一致。

因此，如果副本服务器上的`gtid_executed`与主数据库匹配，那么DuckDB中的数据也将与主数据库保持一致。

posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕法国主播因批评Palantir和彼得·蒂尔后被Qonto银行关闭账户的事件展开。核心争议在于账户关闭是否涉及政治报复或商业审查。部分用户认为事件可能无关，指出该主播影响力有限且内容偏向吸引点击，质疑Palantir是否真的会关注此类批评。也有用户指出彼得·蒂尔曾有利用法律手段报复媒体的先例，暗示存在私人报复的可能性。讨论中提到其他类似案例，如意大利电视台因报道争议内容被冻结账户，引发对银行权力滥用的担忧。有用户呼吁应立法禁止此类私人报复行为，并提及美国相关法规作为参考。普遍共识是用户对银行单方面关闭账户的权力感到不安，认为这可能威胁言论自由。分歧点主要在于事件背后动机的解读，一方倾向于认为只是银行合规操作，另一方则怀疑存在政治或商业打压。

posts.title: Claude Code: connect to a local model when your quota runs out
posts.author: fugu2
posts.title_cn: Claude Code：配额用尽时连接本地模型
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕在Claude Code配额用尽时连接本地模型的可行性展开。核心争议在于本地模型与云端大模型（如Claude、Gemini）的性能差距。多数用户认为本地模型在代码生成质量上远不及商业模型，有人指出即使用高端硬件运行本地模型，其智能水平仍明显落后，甚至可能降低工作效率。也有用户强调本地模型在隐私、成本和控制权方面的优势，并提到近期开源模型（如Llama.cpp）已支持对接Claude API，使本地部署更便捷。讨论中提到一种折中方案：通过Claude Code Router等工具连接OpenRouter平台，以平衡速度、质量与成本。部分用户对本地模型发展持乐观态度，认为其正在快速追赶，但仍有用户坚持始终使用尖端模型才能保证长期效率。共识在于本地模型目前无法完全替代商业模型，但在特定场景下可作为补充选项。

comments.author: alexhans

comments.content_cn:
实用建议。从隐私、成本和控制权的战略角度考虑，我直接选择了本地模型，因为这能建立权衡基准，也更容易识别供应商锁定的风险点，避免视野局限（例如根据本地/云端需求选择llama.cpp或OpenRouter[1]）。虽然CLI工具（Claude/Continue/Codex/Kiro等）日益流行，但掌握本地部署能力仍然必要——即使你可以采用多种策略补贴云端成本（需注意隐私权衡的缺失）。我强烈建议将这种实践与评估作为基础训练，这对未来任何自动化设计都会产生复合价值，因为你终将需要关注成本、风险、准确性与版本回溯问题。

[1] - https://alexhans.github.io/posts/aider-with-open-router.html
[2] - https://www.reddit.com/r/LocalLLaMA

comments.author: d4rkp4ttern
comments.content:
Since Llama.cpp/llama-server recently added support for the Anthropic messages API, running Claude Code with several recent open-weight local models is now very easy. The messy part is what llama-server flags to use, including chat template etc. I've collected all of that setup info in my claude-code-tools [1] repo, for Qwen3-Coder-next, Qwen3-30B-A3B, Nemotron-3-Nano, GLM-4.7-Flash etc.Among these, I had lots of trouble getting GLM-4.7-Flash to work (failed tool calls etc), and even when it works, it's at very low tok/s. On the other hand Qwen3 variants perform very well, speed wise. For local sensitive document work, these are excellent; for serious coding not so much.One caviat missed in most instructions is that you have to set 
    CLAUDE_CODE_DISABLE_NONESSENTIAL_TRAFFIC = 1
in your ~/.claude/settings.json, otherwise CC's telemetry pings cause total network failure because local ports are exhausted.[1] claude-code-tools local LLM setup: https://github.com/pchalasani/claude-code-tools/blob/main/do...
comments.content_cn: 由于Llama.cpp/llama-server近期新增了对Anthropic消息API的支持，现在使用多款近期开源的本地模型运行Claude Code变得非常简单。麻烦之处在于需要配置llama-server的运行参数，包括聊天模板等。我已将所有设置信息整理到我的claude-code-tools[1]代码库中，涵盖Qwen3-Coder-next、Qwen3-30B-A3B、Nemotron-3-Nano、GLM-4.7-Flash等模型。其中GLM-4.7-Flash的配置过程遇到诸多问题（如工具调用失败等），即使成功运行，其令牌处理速度也极低。相比之下，Qwen3系列模型在速度方面表现优异。这些模型非常适合处理本地敏感文档，但对于严肃编程任务则不太适用。大多数教程未提及的关键细节是：必须在~/.claude/settings.json中设置CLAUDE_CODE_DISABLE_NONESSENTIAL_TRAFFIC = 1，否则Claude Code的遥测请求会耗尽本地端口导致网络完全瘫痪。[1] claude-code-tools本地大语言模型配置指南：https://github.com/pchalasani/claude-code-tools/blob/main/do...

comments.content: I think control should be top of the list here. You're talking about building work flows, products and long term practices around something that's inherently non-deterministic.And the probability that any given model you use today is the same as what you use tomorrow is doubly doubtful:1. The model itself will change as they try to improve the cost-per-test improves. This will necessarily make your expectations non-deterministic.2. The "harness" around that model will change as business-cost is tightened and the amount of context around the model is changed to improve the business case which generates the most money.Then there's the "cataclysmic" lockout cost where you accidently use the wrong tool that gets you locked out of the entire ecosystem and you are black listed, like a gambler in vegas who figures out how to count cards and it works until the house's accountant identifies you as a non-negligible customer cost.It's akin to anti-union arguments where everyone "buying" into the cloud AI circus thinks they're going to strike gold and completely ignores the fact that very few will and if they really wanted a better world and more control, they'd unionize and limit their illusions of grandeur. comments.content_cn:

此外还存在“灾难性”的封锁风险——若误用错误工具可能导致被整个生态系统封禁并列入黑名单，就像拉斯维加斯赌场里钻研算牌术的赌徒，在被庄家会计识别为不可忽视的成本源之前或许能屡试不爽。这类似于反工会论调：所有“投身”云端人工智能狂欢的人都幻想自己能淘到黄金，却完全忽视极少数人能成功的事实。如果他们真正渴望更理想的环境和更多控制权，本应联合起来组建工会，克制对宏大愿景的幻想。这本该是个浅显的道理，但我们看到约三分之一人群极易陷入贪婪驱动的幻觉之中。

posts.title: Show HN: Safe-now.live – Ultra-light emergency info site (<10KB)
posts.content: After reading "During Helene, I Just Wanted a Plain Text Website" on Sparkbox (https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46494734) , I built safe-now.live – a text-first emergency info site for USA and Canada. No JavaScript, no images, under 10KB. Pulls live FEMA disasters, NWS alerts, weather, and local resources. This is my first live website ever so looking for critical feedback on the website. Please feel free to look around.https://safe-now.live
posts.author: tinuviel
posts.title_cn: Show HN：Safe-now.live – 超轻量应急信息网站（<10KB）
posts.content_cn: 在阅读了Sparkbox上的《飓风海伦期间，我只想要一个纯文本网站》（https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46494734）后，我创建了safe-now.live——一个面向美国和加拿大的文本优先的紧急信息网站。无JavaScript，无图片，大小在10KB以下。实时获取FEMA灾害信息、NWS警报、天气和本地资源。这是我上线的第一个网站，期待对网站提出关键性反馈。欢迎随意浏览。https://safe-now.live
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕一个名为safe-now.live的极简应急信息网站展开。核心话题是探讨在紧急情况下如何设计一个可靠、易访问的纯文本网站，以提供灾害警报和本地资源信息。

社区反馈主要集中在可用性和可靠性上。许多用户指出网站在移动设备上字体过小，考虑到紧急状态下用户可能双手不便或视线受阻，有人建议增大字体。也有用户强调网站在高流量下的稳定性问题，认为若无法承受HackerNews的访问压力，则难以在真实灾害中可靠运行。讨论中还提到域名中包含连字符可能不利于紧急情况下的记忆和输入。

普遍认同的看法是网站理念很有价值，其轻量级设计（仅4.4KB）受到肯定。但分歧在于具体实现：部分用户认为需优先优化可读性和抗压能力，另有用户从技术角度提出改进建议，如通过QR码整合静态信息以备断网时使用。整体而言，社区肯定该项目的初衷，但认为需进一步打磨才能成为真正可信的应急工具。

posts.title: Attention at Constant Cost per Token via Symmetry-Aware Taylor Approximation
posts.author: fheinsen
posts.title_cn: 通过对称感知泰勒逼近实现每令牌恒定成本的注意力机制
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕一篇关于通过对称感知泰勒近似实现恒定每令牌计算成本的注意力机制论文展开。核心话题是这种近似方法能否在保持质量的同时实现线性时间注意力，从而解决传统注意力机制二次方计算复杂度的问题。

社区观点存在明显分歧。有用户质疑线性时间注意力的可行性，认为“注意力机制的二次方时间似乎是固有的”，并指出已有大量类似研究未能成功，因为“速度提升无法弥补质量下降”。也有用户指出该方法可能带来实际价值，例如“显著提升ByT5等无令牌架构的性能”，因其能缓解长序列计算量增长的问题。

讨论中提到论文声称使用四项泰勒展开即可达到接近Float16精度的效果，但多位用户提出了具体担忧。有人认为“泰勒近似本身只是近似”，质疑其精度与性能的权衡；也有用户指出“未提供误差上界是重大缺失”，并关心“收敛区域是否未被充分讨论”。此外，有用户认为该方法可能违背注意力机制的本质，因为“注意力机制的关键在于突出重要信息，而近似方法可能擅长处理的恰恰是注意力不集中的区域”。

尽管存在争议，社区普遍关注该方法的实际验证，部分用户分享了相关论文和代码实现供进一步参考。整体上，讨论既包含对理论局限性的质疑，也包含对潜在应用价值的期待。

comments.author: thomasahle
comments.content: There's a graveyard of 100s of papers with "approximate near linear time attention."They always hope the speed increase makes up for the lower quality, but it never does. The quadratic time seems inherent to the problem.Indeed, there are lower bounds showing that sub n^2 algorithms can't work: https://arxiv.org/pdf/2302.13214
comments.content_cn: 有数百篇论文的“坟墓”，它们都声称实现了“近似近线性时间的注意力机制”。这些研究总是寄希望于速度提升能弥补质量下降，但从未成功。二次方时间似乎是这个问题的固有特性。事实上，已有下界证明表明，低于n^2复杂度的算法无法奏效：https://arxiv.org/pdf/2302.13214

comments.content:
The paper says that:> In practice, we find that four Taylor terms (P = 4) suffice for

comments.author: riemannzeta
comments.content:
Neat result. The symmetry exploitation here reminds me of recent work connecting neural network training dynamics to renormalization group theory.
Charles Martin's SETOL paper https://arxiv.org/abs/2507.17912 shows that well-trained layers converge to something like an RG fixed point—the eigenvalue spectrum of the weight matrix develops power-law tails with exponent α ≈ 2, which is the signature of scale invariance. At this fixed point, the "effective correlation space" is low-dimensional: you can truncate the SVD aggressively and recover nearly identical test accuracy.I wonder if there's a connection to your Taylor truncation order. In RG terms, higher-order polynomial interactions are "irrelevant operators"—they get suppressed as you flow toward the fixed point. If trained attention heads are sitting near this fixed point, that might explain why modest truncation orders work: the network has already learned to concentrate its computation in the lower-order terms.
A testable prediction: layers with α closer to 2 (measurable via weightwatcher https://github.com/CalculatedContent/WeightWatcher) might need fewer Taylor terms for accurate approximation than layers with α far from 2. If true, you could potentially use the spectral statistics to adaptively choose truncation order per-head.

简洁有力的结果。这里对对称性的运用让我联想到近期将神经网络训练动态与重整化群理论联系起来的研究。Charles Martin的SETOL论文（https://arxiv.org/abs/2507.17912）表明，训练良好的网络层会收敛到类似重整化群不动点的状态——权重矩阵的特征值谱会发展出幂律尾，其指数α≈2，这正是尺度不变性的标志。在这个不动点上，“有效关联空间”是低维的：你可以大幅截断奇异值分解，同时几乎完全恢复测试精度。

我在想这与你的泰勒截断阶数是否存在关联。从重整化群的角度看，高阶多项式相互作用属于“无关算子”——在流向不动点的过程中它们会被抑制。如果训练好的注意力头恰好位于这个不动点附近，那或许能解释为何适度的截断阶数就能奏效：网络已经学会将计算集中在低阶项上。

comments.author: amluto
comments.content:
I skimmed the paper, and I think I completely lost the plot.Sections 2.1 through 2.4 talk about the decomposing the per-token-pair attention (key vector from the ith token with query vector from the jth token, where, in inference, the jth token is the one being sampled) into an approximation that is only mildly outrageously exponential in size compared to the original exponential-of-a-dot product.  And they get something that's a polynomial (in the mathematical sense -- you're literally evaluating a polynomial) and has a size that's manageable at 4th order.Okay, great, they took something simple and made it bigger and nastier but less transcendental without losing too much precision.  (As far as I know, there is really nothing special about the exp in attention in the first place, so trying to approximate it well seems mostly useful insofar as it will keep existing models working.)But the reason that attention is quadratic is that each token gets evaluated with respect to each other token.  They haven't changed this at all.  Section 2.5 seems like it's deferring this to an appendix.  Section 2.6 gives the hidden state size per token, which, on first read, is strictly larger than the hidden state in normal attention (in normal attention it's d_v * d_k -- I'm not sure where their +1 comes from).So what did the paper gain?  Is there some detail that I missed or that the paper completely glossed over that explains why there is any gain of efficiency at all?For what it's worth, the paper's overall claim is, in some sense, impossible.  You can think of attention as being a sort of vector database, and this gets more accurate the sharper you make the exponential.  If you replace softmax with actual max, a query locates the key that is the closest match to the query and returns the associated value.  This operation is a plain linear search, it's possible (in principle anyway) to do lots of queries and recover the entire contents of the database, and I think that any paper claiming to do it faster than linear time should explain how it's compressing the data and where the loss is.In language model terms, imagine an prompt like so:    1: [string 1]
    2: [string 2]
    3: [string 3]
    ...
    n: [string n]
    
    Tell me the string associated with the number k.

As long as there's enough precision and enough query/key space to fit some embedding of the number k that will match the right thing (and there is a lot of  room in high-dimensional spaces), one might expect a transformer to be able to answer this question.  But this obviously requires memory with size linear in the prompt length.  If you try to get rid of that, you necessarily lose something.  (This is not to say that nice attention scaling is impossible -- one could imagine schemes where it takes the model multiple tokens to answer the question, and the number of tokens needed could scale, say, logarithmically with prompt size.  But you still need that linear memory.)

第一个洞见是可采用泰勒近似：在标记位置3处计算
A_3 = ((q1, q2, q3)·(k1, k2, k3))^1, B_3 = ((q1, q2, q3)·(k1, k2, k3))^2, C_3 = ((q1, q2, q3)·(k1, k2, k3))^3等。[1][2]

第二个洞见是能够以远低于从头计算的浮点运算量，从B_i增量计算出B_{i+1}。[3]

[1] 我认同经验上“足够好”，无需超越D_3（四阶多项式）。
[2] 我也认同经验上“足够好”，可假设输入值未极端到需要关注E_3、F_3等项。
我同意其他评论者关于收敛半径问题未被讨论的观点。我认为这些问题不太可能推翻整篇论文。即使实践中无关紧要，或可通过不影响性能的变通方案解决，也不会令人惊讶。

[3] 作者将这个洞见置于附录而非突出展示，这种教学选择令人困惑，但整体影响不大。或许第二个洞见属于先前工作（可能由他人完成），最新大语言模型线性代数领域的专家理应熟悉，但因并非普遍常识（例如在HN评论区），故被列为附录？

comments.author: fheinsen
comments.content: This is a form of linear attention (https://arxiv.org/abs/2006.16236) that approximates standard scaled dot-product attention to arbitrary precision, by adding Taylor terms in an efficient manner. Each additional Taylor term improves the approximation. Efficiency is achieved by exploiting certain mathematical symmetries that become evident only after decomposing the standard formulation of attention into an expression over chains of tensor products. The github repository's README walks through examples. The first example is with 8 Taylor terms.
comments.content_cn: 这是一种线性注意力机制（https://arxiv.org/abs/2006.16236），通过高效添加泰勒级数项，能以任意精度逼近标准缩放点积注意力。每增加一个泰勒项都会提升逼近效果。其高效性源于利用了特定的数学对称性，这种对称性只有在将标准注意力公式分解为张量积链表达式后才变得明显。GitHub仓库的README文档提供了示例说明，第一个示例使用了8个泰勒项。

comments.author: yorwba
comments.content: > But the reason that attention is quadratic is that each token gets evaluated with respect to each other token. They haven't changed this at all. Section 2.5 seems like it's deferring this to an appendix.They defer it to the appendix because it's a standard construction (Q'K)V = Q'(KV), where Q'K is an n×n matrix and requires O(n²) to compute, but KV has a constant size and can be computed in O(n) time, and the multiplication with Q' can also be done in O(n) time.> Section 2.6 gives the hidden state size per token, which, on first read, is strictly larger than the hidden state in normal attention (in normal attention it's d_v * d_k -- I'm not sure where their +1 comes from).Actually, their hidden state has a (large) constant size, so strike the words "per token" from section 2.6. In normal attention, the total state is n(d_v + d_k), but their state is basically (d_v + 1)D_k, where D_k is much larger than d_k, but independent of n. The +1 is because they also need to compute the normalization factor for the softmax.It's true that a constant state size implies that you cannot use it to losslessly store arbitrarily large databases, but LLMs in practice cannot do this either, so there's no loss of capability in that sense. (In fact, if you use enough terms in the Taylor expansion to get the same result as standard attention to within machine precision, the resulting constant state size should give you an upper bound for the amount of data the LLM can effectively retrieve from its context.)
comments.content_cn:
但注意力机制具有二次复杂度的原因在于每个标记都需要与其他所有标记进行相互评估。这一点他们完全没有改变。2.5节似乎将这个问题推给了附录部分。他们将其置于附录是因为这是标准构建方式：(Q'K)V = Q'(KV)，其中Q'K是n×n矩阵，需要O(n²)计算复杂度，而KV具有恒定尺寸，可在O(n)时间内计算，与Q'的乘法运算同样能在O(n)时间内完成。

2.6节给出了每个标记的隐藏状态尺寸，初读时发现这明显大于常规注意力机制中的隐藏状态（常规注意力中是d_v * d_k——我不确定他们公式中的+1从何而来）。实际上，他们的隐藏状态具有（较大的）恒定尺寸，因此应删除2.6节中"每个标记"的表述。在常规注意力中，总状态量为n(d_v + d_k)，而他们的状态本质上是(d_v + 1)D_k，其中D_k远大于d_k，但与n无关。之所以有+1项，是因为他们还需要计算softmax的归一化因子。

恒定状态尺寸确实意味着无法无损存储任意大型数据库，但实际应用中大型语言模型本身也无法做到这一点，因此在这方面并未损失能力。（事实上，如果在泰勒展开中使用足够多的项以达到与标准注意力机制相同的机器精度，最终得到的恒定状态尺寸应当能为大型语言模型有效检索的数据量设定上限...）

comments.author: logicchains
comments.content: It can't be successful at that any more than 1+1 can equal 3. Fundamentally, if every token wants to be able to look at every previous token without loss of information, it must be O(n^2); N tokens looking at N tokens is quadratic. Any sub-quadratic attention must hence necessarily lose some information and be unable to support perfect recall on longer sequences.
comments.content_cn: 这就像1+1不可能等于3一样无法成功。从根本上说，如果每个标记都需要查看之前的所有标记且不丢失信息，其复杂度必须是O(n²)；N个标记查看N个标记就是平方级关系。因此，任何低于平方级的注意力机制都必然丢失部分信息，无法在较长序列中实现完美记忆。

comments.author: dave_universetf
comments.content: Both, with caveats. The attention computation is fundamentally quadratic: for every token in the sequence, you're doing a computation that has to compute over every other token in the sequence. So it's O(N) per token, O(N^2) for the whole sequence.The big mitigation for this is that in causal transformers (i.e. all the chatbot type applications, where each token is only allowed to see tokens before it), you're running inference repeatedly on the same prefix in order to grow it by one token at a time. So if you cache the computations for tokens 0..N-1, on each inference pass you only have to compute O(N) for the newly added token at the end of the sequence.That's why caching (and caching charges) appear so prominently everywhere in the pricing of inference.In practice, caching is most beneficial at inference time, because you typically have relatively long conversations that start with the same cacheable prefix (the system prompt). At training time the same optimization can apply, but you're typically not pushing the same prefixes through the model repeatedly so you end up paying the quadratic cost more often.The quadratic cost of attention is the fundamental compute bottleneck for transformer architectures, which is why there's research like this trying to find shortcuts in computing attention, as well as research into completely new primitives to replace attention (e.g. SSM, which is O(N) on a cold cache and O(1) on a warm cache).
comments.content_cn:
两者都有需要注意的地方。注意力计算本质上是平方级的：对于序列中的每个标记，都需要对序列中所有其他标记进行计算。因此每个标记的计算复杂度是O(N)，整个序列则是O(N^2)。

缓解这个问题的关键方法是：在因果变换器（即所有聊天机器人类型的应用中，每个标记只能看到它之前的标记）中，为了每次在序列末尾增加一个新标记，需要反复对相同的前缀进行推理。因此如果缓存0到N-1标记的计算结果，每次推理只需为新加入的序列末尾标记进行O(N)计算。

这就是为什么在推理定价中，缓存（及缓存费用）成为如此突出的计费因素。

实践中，缓存在推理阶段最有效，因为通常对话开始时都有相同的可缓存前缀（系统提示）。训练时也可采用相同优化，但由于通常不会反复输入相同前缀，因此更常需要承担平方级计算成本。

注意力机制的平方级计算成本是变换器架构的根本计算瓶颈，所以才会出现这类寻找注意力计算捷径的研究，以及探索全新基础构件来替代注意力机制的研究（例如状态空间模型SSM，其在冷缓存时复杂度为O(N)，在热缓存时仅需O(1)）。
